Dialogue:
Person1: Jesus! Listen to this one: "Do you remember me? Airport shuttle, June 7th. You: striking redhead with yellow dress, pearl necklace, brown shoes. I was the bookish fellow in the green cardigan who helped you find your contact lens. Am I crazy, or did we have a moment?"
Person2: God, that's so pathetic. I bet she didn't even notice him.
Person1: I know. And he's like psychotically obsessing over every little detail.
Person2: We should call him and pretend to be the redhead.
Person1: Oh, we totally have to.

Person1: I don't know.
Person2: Don't go.
Person1: I have to... he's a G-34
Person2: You don't have to... I don't trust him.  You ought to file a report.
Person1: No, don't make trouble.  It's nothing.

Person1: You're mine, you know.  I made you.
Person2: I know.
Person1: If you went away, what would become of me?
Person2: I'm grown up now.  I have to leave some time.
Person1: Of course you do, and I want you to... but there's no need to hurry it along, is there?
Person2: I can't help it.
Person1: That's twice this month you've slipped Deadly Night Shade into my tea and run off.  People might get the wrong idea and think you're unhappy at home.

Person1: All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.
Person2: What?
Person1: Shoot to kill, I said.
Person2: I don't know, Fred. There's that reprieve if they ever find out.
Person1: Nobody reprieved that policeman he murdered. Now, do as I tell you.
Person2: Hello, Olsen... Listen...  Shoot to kill... That's the orders pass the word along... No! We dont want him! And listen, Olsen, five- hundred bucks for the guy that does the job... Yes, I'll be right out there.  Well, I hope that's the right thing to do.
Person1: Now take that guilty look off your face, Pete -- and stop trembling like a horse.
Person2: If we didn't have election Tuesday I'd have this on my conscience.

Person1: You're alive! She didn't kill you!
Person2: Who didn't?
Person1: That woman who's after me. She hates you. Because she knows I love you.
Person2: You love me?
Person1: My angel. My goddess. I feel I've always loved you all my life. I'll die if I can't spend the rest of my life just looking at you, holding you in my arms...
Person2: We have to have a long talk about all this.
Person1: I know just the place. Hang a left at the Amalgamated Tower.

Person1: I like you so much. I think you're beautiful. I think if we were together you would love it. You wouldn't believe it.
Person2: How do you know?
Person1: I just know. I know you'll love it.
Person2: But I'm scared Telly.
Person1: I'm telling you. There's nothing in the world to worry about.
Person2: Nothing?

Person1: Pearl, shut up! Pearl, you swore!
Person2: You could save him, little bird.

Person1: You think I'm a fake.
Person2: I think it's what you think.
Person1: No, it isn't what I think.
Person2: Look... You made a very calculated move, and then made me feel embarrassed for responding to you. That wasn't necessary.

Person1: He's dead.
Person2: We bury the body. We disappear into the woods. Nobody knows.
Person1: No. This is the end of the road. There's a dead human being here. For all of his faults, he was a human being, and certainly a victim of his culture as much as anybody.
Person2: Forget him, Lila. We'll disappear. We'll never talk about it again. We'll never talk again period. I love you.
Person1: Puff, what happened to you is as much my fault as Nathan's. Maybe more so, because I knew it was wrong and I went along with it anyway. I'm taking responsibility for the murder. I want you to go back to your old life.
Person2: I won't let you do that. I shot the bastard. And I'm glad.
Person1: No. Go back to the woods. This is a sacrifice I need to make. In my world we have something called penance. It's another abstraction, but I had the concept drummed into my head during my years in the convent. It doesn't exist for you, and it shouldn't. See, I could never be free again anyway, so I might as well be in jail.
Person2: Then I'll live for both of us, Lila. I'll be the most free, truest animal in the whole forest. For both of us.
Person1: That's what I'm counting on.
Person2: But first I'll live among them, just long enough to testify before congress about the waywardness of humankind.
Person1: Okay. If you think it will help.

Person1: No, don't Jack, don't.
Person2: Who sent you, Thorpey?
Person1: Brumby!

Person1: It was necessary.
Person2: Last night.  You knew I was sitting on a fresh grave, didn't you?
Person1: I don't think you understand the full implications of --

Person1: What was all that stuff about enlarged holes and tight cracks?
Person2: I... I didn't think you would have any interest in this get together... I mean if you had told me you were coming I would have warned you -- it's not like a real party or anything.
Person1: You're right about that.  So this is your record collection?
Person2: Oh God no. This is just junk I have for sale or trade. The record room is off-limits.
Person1: Really? Can I see it?
Person2: Yeah, well sure... you can if you want to... it's just I don't want all these guys in there at once... you know...

Person1: I've been waitin' for you Miss Gibson. I want you to know I've decided to take your case.
Person2: Mr. August, I'm not at all sure -
Person1: Look. Don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you and I'm willin' to put up my time to help you. Besides, I think I know where to find your sister.
Person2: Where?
Person1: Wait a minute. This has got a lot of angles. You've got to take it easy. Do you know a Mrs. Redi?
Person2: Yes. She bought my sister's business.
Person1: That's what she told you. I looked it up at the Hall of Records. Your sister deeded her the business as an outright girt.
Person2: Why would Mrs. Redi lie to me?
Person1: That's what I tried to find out.
Person2: You think my sister is there?
Person1: You can't tell.
Person2: Can we go there now?
Person1: Sister, you can't just go breaking into places. There's a night watchman down there and locks on the door.
Person2: If my sister's in that room, it won't make any difference about warrants- and things, I want to go there.
Person1: I don't know if I want to go with you or not.

Person1: Who the hell is taking the time to write letters, spreading this shit about me?
Person2: It's not really important.
Person1: Fine, forget it. It's obvious that we're not going to be friends.
Person2: Why are you being so dramatic?
Person1: Look, I've got a lot of problems and I'm trying to deal with them and the last thing I need is people spreading shit about me.
Person2: Alright, I said I was sorry.  Can we start over again? I think we've gotten off on the wrong foot.

Person1: Now I didn't mean that, you rat.
Person2: Two weeks from tomorrow.
Person1: You're going?
Person2: You're going.

Person1: Are you seeing somebody else, Nathan? I just have to know.
Person2: Of course not.
Person1: It would just be helpful to know.
Person2: No.
Person1: Because, you know, you seem so distant. And you work late every night. And we hardly ever have sex, and when we do, it's... I don't know. It feels different.
Person2: I'm just preoccupied.
Person1: Do you like my new look?
Person2: Yeah. It's nice. It's really good.
Person1: I'm trying, you know.  I'm trying to be what you want. I want to be what you want, Nathan. All I want is to be what you want.
Person2: Shh. It's okay.  It's okay, Lila. You're what I want. You know that. You're exactly what I want.
Person1: Really?
Person2: Sure. Of course.
Person1: Because I'm really trying, you know. Rosie says maybe only another two years of the elctrolysis.
Person2: That's great.
Person1: I've signed up for a ballet class. And look at my nails! A real girl!

Person1: Having fun yet?  No?  I'll give you a hint.  Remember whatshername?
Person2: Shelly?
Person1: Miss her?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Kill the men who killed you both, and the Day of the Dead will be your reunion.

Person1: Why did you cancel my gym membership? I had plans to go with friends this weekend!
Person2: I noticed you've been pushing yourself too hard lately and thought you could use a break.
Person1: That wasn't your decision to make.
Person2: Iâ€™m only doing this for your own good. Sometimes you need someone to force you to take a step back.
Person1: I appreciate your concern, but I need to make those decisions for myself.

Person1: Now Amy
Person2: It's true.
Person1: And who did the voice belong to?
Person2: It was just a voice.
Person1: Now look, this is the last time you come to me with any such stories  I'm sick of this sort of thing.
Person2: Daddy, it's true.
Person1: Let me be the judge of that.

Person1: How much you pay me for my help?
Person2: I think it's more complicated than that little man.
Person1: Put me on the payroll, find out, find out wassup --
Person2: You don't just sign up to be a police officer -- it's about three years of training -- ok?
Person1: I'm trained, I'm ready to go, you wanna buy some candy to help underprivelaged youth in the --
Person2: Sorry, little man.
Person1: You wanna take my statement, I'll perform for you, gotta get paid though, gotta get PAID.
Person2: Why the hell aren't you in school?
Person1: No school today.  My teacher got sick.
Person2: They don't have substitute teachers where you go to school?
Person1: Nope.  So what'd they find out in there?
Person2: That's confidential information, little man.
Person1: Tell me what you know, I'll tell you what I know --
Person2: No Can Do.
Person1: Leave this one to the detectives, they ain't gonna solve shit, I can help you, make you the man with a plan, give you the gift that I flow -- think fast -- you wanna know who killed that guy?

Person1: I noticed you used my designs without giving me any credit during the presentation.
Person2: Oh, that? It's not a big deal. Everyone knew you were a part of it.
Person1: That's not the point. It's about acknowledgment and respect.
Person2: You're making a mountain out of a molehill.
Person1: Proper credit is basic professionalism, Derek.
Person2: Maybe if you weren't so hung up on the little things, you'd go further in your career.

Person1: Please!  I'll never let you down again, Mother.  Never.  I promise.
Person2: Then this shall be our little secret.  Remember that I see into thy soul as God sees.  Thou may fool the world. Even thy father.  But not me, Richard. Never me.
Person1: Mother, think of me always as your faithful dog ...

Person1: Why are you pulling away from me? I've noticed you've been spending more time with your friends than with me.
Person2: It's not like that, Laura. I just need some space sometimes.
Person1: I always put you first, unlike others. Why can't you see that?
Person2: It's not a competition. I appreciate everything you do for me, but it's important to have a balance.
Person1: I just wish you'd recognize the effort I make for us, that's all.

Person1: How's my little cheerleader? Now I know everyone at your high school isn't so uptight, come on.
Person2: Hey really, I don't feel so great.
Person1: Let's do it on the coats. It'll be excellent.

Person1: You mean we get `Dave' to nominate you as Vice President.
Person2: I was a senator, you know.
Person1: Oh, I know. And then when our poor President gets another stroke - - of course much more serious this time - - the newly appointed V.P. becomes the Pres...
Person2: What about containment, Alan?

Person1: You're making it too easy.
Person2: You got time on your side.  Pretty soon they'll be missed and we'll have the law up our ass.
Person1: They saw you kill the driver.
Person2: You're up on your details, aren't you?
Person1: You can rely on them to keep quiet because this is undeclared money that could land Jack there in federal prison.  He can't afford for you to get caught and have this briefcase appear as evidence.
Person2: Keep talking.

Person1: At least you knew about Dr. Judd.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And you knew he'd be here.
Person2: Yes. And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to look for Jacqueline?
Person1: I want you to look for Jacqueline.

Person1: No, see, Neil, if you're messing with one of my friends, then you're messing with me.
Person2: Don't do that.
Person1: What are you going to do? Hm?
Person2: If you hit me...
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: ... my manager will slap an assault charge on your rear faster than you can say AA, okay?
Person1: Your manager?
Person2: Yeah, man, my manager and my lawyer.
Person1: Well, just, you know, have 'em call me. Y-you know where to find me, right?
Person2: Oh, yeah, drunk on the corner, man. Hey, why don't you buy another beer. It's on me, okay?

Person1: Baxter, we're a little disappointed in you -- gratitude-wise.
Person2: Oh, I'm very grateful.

Person1: I hope you're going to invite me in?
Person2: Everybody is at home, it's no good.
Person1: Let's have a look anyway.

Person1: Mary, I swear I wasn't trying to trick you.
Person2: Then what did you do it for?
Person1: I did it because because I'd never stopped thinking about you and if I didn't find you I knew my life would never be good again.

Person1: Wow, I guess I hit a nerve.
Person2: You make it sound like, you know, I have no needs or something.  You think I'm too self-sufficient?
Person1: Now, Hannah, that's not what I meant, you know.  Uh, yeah, everybody relies on you for so much. "You're so giving. It's not a criticism.  We love you. We're grateful."
Person2: You're grateful, but you resent me.
Person1: Oh, wow!  I don't want to have this conversation.  I didn't do anything wrong.

Person1: When you going to let me work with you?  Why you always fucking with me?
Person2: Why am I what?  Excuse me?  I catch you saying the F-word again.  I'll kill you.  That's a serious promise. Now leave out of here.

Person1: I thought I would accompany you to the airport to say bon voyage... and tell you that Marcel will be going with you.
Person2: What?
Person1: This is a considerable move up for you, Daniel. The temptation of having so much money might be too much for you.
Person2: You don't trust me?
Person1: I don't trust anyone. You don't get to the top of this game by trusting people... and after all, you are a thief. It's in your nature to steal. I'm just protecting my investment.

Person1: Well, there was a time  when you were very happy to be only with me.  You wanted to learn everything about poetry, about music.
Person2: Mm-hm.
Person1: Have I really taught you everything I have to give?  I don't think so.

Person1: Noah was my counselor in my freshman year.  That's probably where I got the idea for the icepick.  For my book. Funny how the subconscious works.  Hazel is my friend.
Person2: She wiped out her whole family.
Person1: Yes.  She's helped me understand homicidal impulse.
Person2: Didn't you study it in school?
Person1: Only in theory.  You know all about homicidal impulse, don't you, shooter?  Not in theory -- in practice.

Person1: We know what makes an ant colony strong, don't we?  We know that no ant can be an individual.  No single ant matters, right?
Person2: That's correct, sir!
Person1: Not that one.  Or that one.
Person2: No, sir!

Person1: Yes, what?
Person2: Don't answer me. Say what I say.

Person1: I couldn't help but notice you pain.
Person2: My pain?
Person1: It runs deep. Share it with me.

Person1: I'm your son. And Laureen's son.
Person2: Ain't nobody mentioned that name on this farm for 14 years. My boy was taken from me... far as I'm concerned, he's dead. Now, I ain't gonna ask you again. -- Who are you?!
Person1: Joseph Macdonald... Your son.
Person2: Joseph Macdonald. Damn right, boy. And don't you forget it.

Person1: Hey, remember that time you borrowed a hundred bucks from me and promised to pay it back by the end of the month?
Person2: Hmm, I don't recall that ever happening.
Person1: Seriously? We were at Joe's party, and you were practically begging for it.
Person2: Joe's party? Oh, that was such a crazy night. But I really don't remember any borrowing.
Person1: Come on, it was just last month. You even said you'd pay me back with interest.
Person2: Interest? Are you sure you're not mixing me up with someone else? I think you might be mistaken.
Person1: I distinctly remember you promising, and I could use that money now.
Person2: I wish I could help, but I don't recall that ever happening. Maybe it was someone else who borrowed from you.
Person1: Fine, forget it. But you better remember next time when you need a favor from me.
Person2: Oh, don't worry, I'll remember when it suits me.

Person1: But Doug...There's something I want you to know.  You're the best assignment I ever hand.  Really.
Person2: I'm honored.
Person1: You sure you don't wanna...?  For old time's sake.  If you don't trust me, you can tie me up.
Person2: I didn't know you were so kinky.
Person1: It's time you found out.

Person1: Calm down. Tell me what's wrong.
Person2: Something awful happened last night.
Person1: What do you mean?!
Person2: I... I don't think you want to know.
Person1: Cecile, you have to tell me.
Person2: It involves your brother. He... took advantage of me.
Person1: Does your mother know?
Person2: If she knew, she'd kill me. It happened at your house last night.
Person1: Why didn't you do something?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: So, let me get this straight. You came over to our house late last night and he forced intercourse on you.
Person2: Well... not exactly.
Person1: He made you give him a blow job.
Person2: No.
Person1: Well what then?

Person1: What good can you do? Why are you being so incredibly stupid?
Person2: Maybe I didn't know him like you did. But he's my uncle. And I owe it to him to get some answers. It's a quest like, uh, Hemingway, the Old Man and The Sea. Except instead of an old man I'm a young man, and instead of the sea, it's a bunch of tunnels under Paris. And instead of a big fish it's... who knows? That's what I'm going to find out. Au revoir.

Person1: I'm glad to hear that Zoe's okay.
Person2: Are you still in touch?
Person1: Not really.  The last time I saw her was at that clinic.  That was a long time ago.
Person2: Which one?
Person1: Which one?
Person2: Which clinic?
Person1: I don't remember the name.  It was near a beach.
Person2: Sunnyridge.  That was a long time

Person1: I got in early. I was excited...  Who was that guy?
Person2: Oh, that's Will. He's a friend. You'd like him.
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Ray, we're just friend.
Person1: Every guy in history who tried to pick up a girl did the good-friend thing first.
Person2: Why are you being like this?

Person1: Truth is, besides the headache I've come down with a little lower intestinal havoc. Make my apologies.
Person2: Come on, El, you're a trooper. I'll get you some Pepto, you'll make one of your patented tributes to the common person, then back to Sacramento. This is no time to lay down on the job. I don't care what the polls say, you can't afford to relax. Look what happened to Bush. Tell you what, if you want to blow off the Sacramento speech, fine. But do this one and we'll get out of the smog.

Person1: That's not technically accurate - SIMPSONS murders weren't sexually motivated.
Person2: You know that circulation is down for three months in a row.
Person1: I heard something like that
Person2: Then it's going to be 'I killed for sex'... Listen darling, why won't you let us use your real name for the features - if people knew that it was the ELLEN CARTER writing the features and not just some pseudonym - then we might shift more units. You haven't written anything in four years darling - I know you need this job - and if circulation keeps dropping, there's not going to be a magazine for you to write for...

Person1: And besides, when you say I make tax- deductible excuses you make me out a criminal.
Person2: You couldn't be a criminal if you committed a major crime.
Person1: I wish I were. Not an active criminal but... a nice guy with the conscience of a criminal.  Next best thing to no conscience at all.
Person2: I have to go, Sam.
Person1: I can come down next week.
Person2: No.
Person1: Not even just to see you, to have lunch... in public?
Person2: We can see each other, we can even have dinner... but respectably, in my house with my mother's picture on the mantel and my sister helping me broil a big steak for three!
Person1: And after the steak... do we send Sister to the movies and turn Mama's picture to the wall?
Person2: Sam! No!
Person1: All right.

Person1: I didn't say that.  Why would I say that?
Person2: Well Daddy and I were thinking that sometimes people tell a story about what they wish would happen.
Person1: I don't want that to happen.  Why would I want that to happen?
Person2: Well you're telling your teachers and your friends --
Person1: Mass hysteria.
Person2: Maybe you're upset that Rachel moved in.
Person1: I'm not upset.  Why would I be upset?
Person2: Look if the truth is you don't feel like talking about this right now that's fine. But don't look me in the eye with a big smile on your face and lie to me. Cause there are only so many lies you're allowed to tell before it starts showing on your face.  You wind up looking like...

Person1: Delacroix, wake up, brother man. The reason why they didn't get picked up was because nobody - and I mean NOBODY - niggers and crackers alike wants to see that junk.
Person2: I've never been given a fair shot.
Person1: You got your head stuck up your ass with your Harvard education and your pretentious ways.  Brother man, I'm blacker than you.  I'm keepin' it real and you're frontin', trying to be white.
Person2: I'm an oreo, a sell out?  Because I don't aspire to do HOMEBOYS FROM OUT OF SPACE, SECRET DIARY OF DESMOND PFEIFFER, A PJ's or some as you might put it, some "nigger" show?  I'm a Tom?  I'm whiter than white and you're blacker than black? Is that what you think?
Person1: That's exactly what I think.  I want you to create something that people want to see.  Let's be honest, the majority of the people in the country are deaf, dumb and blind and I'm including 35 million African-Americans.  You know and I know "niggers" set the trend, set the styles.  This is a golden opportunity now.  These idiots have to be led to the water.
Person2: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want.
Person1: You will or you'll be back at BET so quick you'll never know what hit you.  I need a mid-season replacement and pronto.  It will be on the fast track.

Person1: Jessie!  Are you alright?
Person2: I want the money--meet me at the highest point from where you are. Don't do it and we're going to see if your angel here can fly. Copy?
Person1: Copy.  Jessie, go to the top of Bitker ladder.
Person2: Love's a killer, isn't it?

Person1: Your money may have been well invested, my friend. Something important may come of all this.
Person2: Something important has got to come of it! Do you know that the rent on this place isn't paid?
Person1: Is that a fact?
Person2: No -- I'm lying to amuse myself!  Now look here, I've an idea that will get us out of all this. We haven't twopence between us, but we've got these.
Person1: Fire insurance!
Person2: Yes, there's our way out. A fire in this place would give us ten thousand pounds.

Person1: What?
Person2: Don't give up. You're the only one who can help me. I know it.

Person1: But one thing I could never understand, was that she could have everything under control, except for her old pimp boyfriend, Lester Diamond.
Person2: Look, Gin, you know I got other people in this. I got partners. But I want you to understand that I am lookin' out for you in this thing.  Okay? You're going to get yours back... and you're gonna get it back first. Okay?

Person1: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-
Person2: - it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.
Person1: Champion to champion.
Person2: Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.
Person1: Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!
Person2: Very well, plainly and distinctly. Although I consider it unnecessary - because you know as well as I, what I am about to say.  Lloyd may leave Karen, but he will not leave Karen for you.
Person1: What do you mean by that?
Person2: More plainly and more distinctly? I Have not come to New Haven to see the play, discuss your dreams, or to pull the ivy from the walls of Yale! I have come to tell you that you will not marry Lloyd - or anyone else - because I will not permit it.
Person1: What have you got to do with it?
Person2: Everything. Because after tonight, you will belong to me.
Person1: I can't believe my ears...
Person2: A dull cliche.
Person1: Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...
Person2: So does the history of the world for the past twenty years. I don't enjoy putting it as bluntly as this, frankly I had hoped that you would, somehow, have known - have taken it for granted that you and I...
Person1: ... taken it for granted? That you and I...

Person1: Good-bye.  Well, your luck is holding. They sublet your place. You're homeless. Frank's got a line on another place you can use for now.
Person2: Another place where?
Person1: Does it matter?

Person1: Im not a homosexual. I just like women for more than their bodies. I guess you could say I'm the new American male.
Person2: You're a fag or a liar.
Person1: I mean, I am really attracted to you.
Person2: I mean, I am really attracted to you. Jesus, you are a fag. We can share recipes, if you like, Darlene.

Person1: I've noticed you've been distant lately. What's going on?
Person2: It's just... I've been feeling out of place with everyone else. They don't seem to get me.
Person1: Neil, no one understands you like I do. Talk to me. Let me be there for you.
Person2: It's hard to explain. I just feel so different from everyone else.
Person1: It's okay to be different. And I'm here to help you through whatever you're feeling.

Person1: For a price.
Person2: Good God.
Person1: A small price.
Person2: I won't do your portion of kitchen cleanup.
Person1: No.
Person2: And I'm not covering for you when you sneak out to call Dominos.

Person1: You will not set me on another walk down memory lane.  Not this lane. Not today.
Person2: I didn't --
Person1: Why do I tell you this?  I never told David.  I never even remembered it until you got me going.
Person2: You're the one who started it.
Person1: You're very clever, Mr. Boone.  You just sit there and let me talk. What a sorry old man, you're thinking.  What a crazy old poof.  Why are you here?  What do you want from me?
Person2: You asked me to model.  Remember?
Person1: Of course I remember.  Do you think I'm so senile --

Person1: I know you feel awful but it's not your responsibility.
Person2: Then whose is it?
Person1: You gotta just look the other way.
Person2: I'm sorry.  You'll do all right without me.  Keep my share.

Person1: I didn't mean... with me. Alice and Silky, they'll give you one... if you want.
Person2: I... I guess not.  I didn't mean I didn't want one 'cause of you bein' cut up. I didn't mean that.

Person1: Karen and I just don't want an accident-
Person2: I have no intention of having an accident!
Person1: It's not important whether you do. We are wearing long underwear.

Person1: You don't have the demographics.
Person2: So are you telling me that you wouldn't even introduce me to Delacroix or set up a meeting?  I'm talking 'bout me, your only brother, ya own flesh and blood, hook a brother up, youknowwhatI'msayin'.
Person1: That'swhatI'msayin'.  I'm not blowin' my young career, brother or no brother, for you or anybody else.
Person2: There is a name, a term for your kind, the likes of you.  Back in slavery days, you would be classified as a house nigga.

Person2: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm --

Person1: You mean you're not coming back to work here?

Person1: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for --

Person2: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.

Person2: I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!

They just want to cover their asses or meet girls or tear each other down.  Oh, God, this country's in deep trouble, Buddy ... and I have to see this through.  Mother would've wanted no less of me ... I'm sorry, Buddy.

Anyway, this is the wrong time. The kids are home from school -- my in- laws are visiting for the holidays -- I can't bring it up now. Person2: Listen get this straight don't look at me when you say them things. It wasn't my fault what happened to your brother. Fixing Joey wasn't my idea... .

Person2: Well, nobody, I guess. But that Father Barry, I didn't like the way he kept lookin' at me.
Person1: He was looking at everybody the same way. Asking the same question.
Person2: Yeah, yeah... .  This Father Barry, what's his racket?
Person1: His racket?
Person2: You've been off in daisyland, honey. Everybody's got a racket.

Person1: Okay, Starling. Let's have it.
Person2: You haven't said a word today about that garage. Or what I found there.

Person2: He starts this - buzzing in me, in my head. He makes me feel violated... You used me, Mr. Crawford.

Person1: We'll start with your most recent memories and go backwards -- There is an emotional core to each of our memories -- As we eradicate this core, it starts its degradation process -- By the time you wake up in the morning, all memories we've targeted will have withered and disappeared. Like a dream upon waking.
Person2: Is there any sort of risk of brain damage?
Person1: Well, technically, the procedure itself is brain damage, but on a par with a night of heavy drinking. Nothing you'll miss.

Person1: The army needs you.
Person2: The army can survive without me.

Person2: Someday, George, you may need to act for the good of the people no matter what Congress thinks that is.  It may come down to us, or them someday.  You or them.  Cicero was right. Was is "a time when the laws are silent"?
Person1: I hope I never have to believe that.
Person2: Christ, George, Joseph Reed's been writing letters back to Congress attacking you.  Your own aide!

Person1: Excuse me?  Could I say something?

Person1: This had nothing to do with shoes that didn't fit or my relationship with my father who, as you know, made a fortune selling penny loafers in the fifties. These people died because of the criminal actions of my doctor.
Person2: Your doctor?
Person1: Yes.  My psychiatrist didn't insist that I stay on my medication.
Person2: ...so you feel absolutely no responsibility for killing these people?
Person1: It was my finger that pulled the trigger, but I'm not morally responsible.  My psychiatrist knew what I was capable of.  How could I know. I'm not a doctor.
Person2: You seem very savvy for a man who's been found mentally incompetent to stand trial.
Person1: Look, I'm a victim here, too.  I was a year away from getting my masters in Art, now I'll never graduate.  My life has been permanently disrupted.
Person2: Permanently disrupted?  Aren't you selling paintings now for quite a lot of money?  Hasn't this 'incident' as you call it, jump started your career as an artist?
Person1: Look, I'm in here.  You call this a career move?
Person2: And isn't there a movie in the works about you?
Person1: We're in negotiations, that's correct.
Person2: But doesn't the Son of Sam Law prevent criminals from profiting from their crimes?
Person1: That doesn't apply to me because I'm not a criminal.  I'm not a criminal!  I wasn't convicted.

Person1: I was wondering.

Person2: You missed the point, then and now... Only his body was "in death," Kirk! And you were the last one to be with him.

Person1: But -- why?
Person2: Because he asked you to! He entrusted you with his very essence -- with everything was not of the body. He asked you to bring him to us -- and to bring that which he gave you: his Katra. His living spirit.

Person1: Then, how --
Person2: Kirk, I must have your thoughts. May I join your mind?

Person1: After I left...when I was in California, I began to think, what kind of mother was I that I could walk out on my own child. It got to where I couldn't tell anybody about Billy--I couldn't stand that look in their faces when I said he wasn't living with me.  Finally it seemed like the most important thing in the world to come back here and prove to Billy and to me and to the world how much I loved him...And I did ...And I won.  Only...it was just another "should."  ...Sitting in that courtroom. Hearing everything you did, everything you went through... Something happened.  I guess it doesn't matter how much I love him, or how much you love him. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for Billy.  I don't know, maybe that's all love is anyway... Ted, I think Billy should stay with you...
Person2: What?
Person1: He's already got one mother, he doesn't need two...He's yours...  I won't fight you for him any more. He's yours...
Person2: Oh, God...Oh, my God...
Person1: Only can I still see him?
Person2: No more waiting in Coffee Shops ...I promise.

Now, don't get me wrong, he's a man of enormous integrity, but there's a political component to this job that the General just didn't have any patience for.

Person1: Hasn't anyone ever taught you that fighting violence with violence solves nothing.

But have no fear. There will be many other deaths tomorrow...and those will be quite real. I'm afraid these questions of yours put you in a position not unlike a long-tailed tabby in room full of rocking chairs.

Person1: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me.
Person2: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.

Person1: Oh, about six years since I graduated
Person2: And how many people have you killed?
Person1: I don't know
Person2: You don't know?
Person1: No - the police say I've killed fourteen - but I've not - I've killed many more. It amazes me how they just haven't found the bodies. What is society coming to when people just don't get missed. I agree, some of them are well hidden - I probably couldn't even show you where I put them - one girl, number eight I think the press called it - she wasn't even mine - I don't know who did it but I didn't
Person2: Where do you kill them...
Person1: Oh anywhere - whenever I needed to - Do you know how easy it is to take them? You just pick up a hiker, or someone off the streets - they believe so easily you know, 'Look, I have something to show you' I would say - and that would be it. One girl, I think her name is Debbie - she had broken down on the motorway, and I offered to take her to a service station to call for a tow truck - She just got in and I drove away. When I pulled into the layby and took out my knife - she just froze, and said - what do you want? - I said, You know what I want. - But she didn't. Getting rid of the bodies is just as easy - the first I cut up, put in bags with bricks in, and tossed them off Eldridge Bridge in broad daylight.  The real problem with my work is the blood - there is so much of it - and it all spurts out so fast - like a fountain. It made such a mess of
Person1: my car  I stopped working from my car.  She could have stopped me you know - If she really wanted too. That is the difference between the confusion of humanity and the purity of the beast - If a dog attacked you - you could easily kill it without any damage to yourself - Why then do people get bitten by dogs - savaged? Why?
Person2: I don't know
Person1: Because a dog will attack with a ferocity and force that we poses, but centuries of social contamination has run it out of us - that is what sets us aside from the purity of the beasts...Society is rotting - men who once were strong and kept everything working are getting soft - women are making them soft - by the time a pretty girl has reached twenty - she has had three lifetimes worth of fun and attention- so she doesn't deserve any more -
Person2: Didn't DEBBIE deserve anymore?
Person1: No she didn't...
Person2: What did you do with her?
Person1: You know everyone accuses me of being sick - the press, the TV - but I'm not you know - they are - I don't watch it for entertainment every night - I don't sit and watch it whilst eating my dinner - they all say, how could he cut her up? She was dead - I can't hurt something dead - And all this whilst they slobber down their processed beef burgers by the dozen - I couldn't eat one of those burgers, you don't know what has gone in them!

Person1: I mean, to stay away longer -- two months... a year... three years... Yes, I know, it sounds absurd. And I feel awful. The very idea of losing you makes me want to die... And yet... I... I just don't have the same feeling for you any more.

Person1: You're right! Now I remember! It was after the Western regional planners were in town and the meeting went late. The next day I was completely bushed. It was unbelievable.
Person2: If it wasn't for a drunk I would have picked you up. He wanted to go to the DMZ.
Person1: The DMZ?
Person2: South Bronx. The worst. I tried to ditch him, but he was already in the cab, so I had to take him. That's the law. Otherwise I would have picked you up.
Person1: That would have been quite a coincidence.
Person2: You'd be surprised how often you see the same people, get the same fare. People have patterns. They do more or less the same things every day. I can tell.
Person1: Well, I don't go to the Plaza every night.
Person2: I didn't mean you. But just ordinary people. A guy I know -- Dough-Boy -- met his wife that way. They got to talking. She said she usually caught the bus so he started picking her up at the bus stop, taking her home with the flag up.
Person1: That's very romantic. Some of your fares must be interesting. See any stars, politicians, deliver any babies yet?
Person2: Well, no... not really... had some famous people in the cab.  I got this guy who makes lasers. Not regular lasers, not the big kind. Little lasers, pocket sized, small enough to clip your belt like a transistor radio, like a gun, you know. Like a ray gun. Zap.
Person1: What hours do you work?
Person2: I work a single, which means there's no replacement -- no second man on the cab. Six to six, sometimes eight. Seventy-two hours a week.
Person1: You mean you work seventy-two hours a week.
Person2: Sometimes 76 or 80. Sometimes I squeeze a few more hours in the morning. Eighty miles a day, a hundred miles a night.
Person1: You must be rich.
Person2: It keeps ya busy.
Person1: You know what you remind me of?
Person2: What?
Person1: That song by Kris Kristofferson, where it's said "Like a pusher, party truth, partly fiction, a walking contradiction".
Person2: I'm no pusher, Betsy. Honest. I never have pushed.
Person2: I didn't mean that, Travis. Just the part about the contradiction.
Person2: Oh. Who was that again?
Person1: The singer?
Person2: Yeah. Yes. I don't follow music too much.
Person1: Kris Kristofferson.

Person1: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
Person2: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.
Person1: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?
Person2: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.
Person1: Really?
Person2: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.
Person1: No?
Person2: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---
Person1: And?
Person2: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.
Person1: And what do you do -- now?
Person2: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail
Person1: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
Person2: I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief.
Person1: That's a silly joke.
Person2: Please look at me. You must believe me -- you must believe that I love you -- that I have never known what love is -- until last night.

Jesus what did you see in her?  I don't get it -- I just don't get it.

Person2: She upped and married some other cat after I joined the navy. By the time I got my discharge, though, she was divorced. Her husband poked out her eye in a domestic quarrel.
Person1: Lovely.
Person2: She made a play for me after I got back, but her glass eye kept interfering with my concentration. Every time we got into a clinch, I'd start thinking about that hole in her head, that empty socket with the glass eye in it. An eye that couldn't see, an eye that couldn't shed any tears. The minute I started thinking about it, Mr. Johnson would get all soft and small. And I can't see getting married if Mr. Johnson isn't going to be in tiptop shape.
Person1: You don't take anything seriously, do you?

I see that they're nothing, I see they ain't here. The only thing that's here is you. And me. I want you to come upstairs. Now. I tried to take everything last night, like you told me, but I couldn't. I couldn't take everything in a hundred years. It's the way we are. We compound each other.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: I'm freezing to death.
Person2: Come upstairs. I don't care why you come. No, that's not what I mean. Loretta, I love you. Not like they told you love is and I didn't know this either. But love don't make things nice, it ruins everything, it breaks your heart, it makes things a mess. We're not here to make things perfect. Snowflakes are perfect. The stars are perfect. Not us. We are here to ruin ourselves and break our hearts and love the wrong people and die! The storybooks are bullshit. Come upstairs with me, baby! Don't try to live your life out to somebody else's idea of sweet happiness. Don't try to live on milk and cookies when what you want is meat! Red meat just like me! It's wolves run with wolves and nothing else! You're a wolf just like me! Come upstairs with me and get in my bed! Come on! Come on! Come on!

Like the litter of kittens you hadthe only one she wants to keep has six toes and it's cockeyed to boot. Look at him. The bum! And the crush you had on that little Abyssinian... .

And every time I heisted a box or a coffee bag I says to myselfthis is for Edie, so she can be a teacher or somethin' decent. I promised your mother. You better not let her down.

Person1: Okay, Karl, the reason I brought you here was to talk to you about something that is on my mind.  I guess I'll put it right out on the table. Where do I start. Linda and Frank are very important to me. They're like family. My own family was never like family. They're horrible people. As a matter of fact I prayed every night for years that my father would die. I finally realized through a lot of therapy that I was wasting my energy on hating him. Now I just don't care.  You see, you and I are a lot alike, strange as that may seem. I mean not physically or even mentally really, just well, maybe emotionally or actually the hand we've been dealt in life. We're different. People see us as being different anyway. You're -- well you have your affliction or whatever and I, well mine's not as easy to see. I'm just going to say it. I'm gay.  Does that surprise you?  That I'm gay. You know what being gay is, don't you?
Person2: I reckon not.
Person1: Homosexual. I like men. Sexually.
Person2: Not funny, ha, ha, funny queer.
Person1: Well that's a very offensive way to put it. You shouldn't say that. You were taught that, weren't you?
Person2: I've heard it said that way.
Person1: Anyway, it's hard to live gay, that's the right way to say it, in a small town like this. I've wanted to leave many times, but my love for Linda and Frank and another certain person that we won't go into have kept me from it. Anyway, I'm rambling. If you're going to live in the Wheatly garage you need to know that it won't be easy. Doyle is a monster. Not just a closed minded redneck, but a monster. A dangerous person. I've told Linda that one day that man is going to really hurt her or that boy. Maybe even kill one of them. I see it in his eyes. I'm very in tune, maybe even psychic. Doyle will make your life hell. You're a perfect target. When I first saw you I was afraid of you. Not really afraid, I guess, just taken aback. But also, I felt a real sensitive feeling from you. And for some reason, Frank has adopted you. Much like a stray animal. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it like that. In a good way. Anyway, I just want you to know what you're in for. I have a good feeling about you. You're good for Frank. Maybe it's that he can have an adult friend on a child's level. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it in a bad way.  There's one more thing. It's none of my business why you were in the state hospital. Everyone has something in their past, maybe you tried suicide, maybe you did something -- terrible. But what I see before me is a gentle, simple man. All I want you to promise me is that you're capable of being around Linda and Frank. You know. You would never hurt them under any circumstances, would you?
Person2: I wouldn't never hurt them.
Person1: That's what I thought. I hope I haven't offended you in any way. You seem like a thinker. You seem to always be in deep thought. Tell me something. What are you thinking right now?

Person1: Tell me, Vincent.  Do you believe in Santa Claus?
Person2: Can't say that I do.
Person1: Neither do I.  But my children, they're still young.  Do you know who they like even more than jolly old Saint Nicholas?  His helper, Black Peter. An old Russian fairy tale tells of how Santa got so busy looking after all the good kids, he had to hire a helper to punish all the bad kids.  That was Black Peter's job.  He was given the list of all the bad children, and he would visit them in their homes late at night.  And if he caught them not saying their prayers, he would leave a bundle of wooden switches outside their door.  That was a warning.  If they continued to misbehave, he would swoop down and take the children away. And they would never be seen again.

Person1: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart.  Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try.  Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.

Person1: I still ask, why do they want disarmament?
Person2: Well, for the same reasons we do, sir. Don't you see?
Person1: No, Major, I don't.  They have no regard for human life.  They wouldn't care if they lost their whole country as long as they won.
Person2: Gee, sir, that last remark doesn't exactly make all the sense in the world.
Person1: Major, you're talking like one of them!
Person2: Well, I'm not, sir.  Honestly, sir.
Person1: Don't be offended, Major.  Our President holds the same views.
Person2: Don't you think he knows something about this, General Ripper?
Person1: I'll tell you what I do think.  If they say they're for disarmament, I say anyone who says they're for disarmament is either a traitor or a damned fool.
Person2: But, General, we're on our toes.  We haven't agreed to anything for years.  Inffact, a a lot of people say we never will.
Person1: But if they suddenly opened up and gave us the inspection we want, we'd agree, wouldn't we?
Person2: If they gave us what we think we need, yes, I guess we would.
Person1: And you'd like to see that?
Person2: General, what's good enough for the President and all the experts he's got working on the thing, is good enough for me.
Person1: Do you think we'd cheat?
Person2: No, sir.  I'm sure we wouldn't.
Person1: Do you think they would cheat?
Person2: Look, sir.  I'm no expert on the subject, but I've read some pretty sharp ideas the big boys have.  Like, say, both countries agreeing to a million dollar reward and international protection for anyone who gives evidence of cheating to the inspectors. You can't hide those things without a lot of people knowing about it.  And if I were going to try and hide a few, I wouldn't want to depend on the fact that some poor slob isn't going to run and blab for a million bucks.  We're as smart as they are, and if they cheat, or even hold back information, we'd pull right out.

Person1: Well, if the Clock People give you any inside information on the end of the world, drop us a postcard.
Person2: The world isn't going to end, you dummy; I hope you know that much.  But it is going to change. It's going to change drastically, and probably in your lifetime. The Clock People see calamitous earthquakes as the agent of change, and they may be right, since there are a hundred thousand earthquakes a year and major ones are long overdue. But there are far worse catastrophes coming... unless the human race can bring itself to abandon the goals and values of civilization, in other words, unless it can break the consumption habit -- and we are so conditioned to consuming as a way of life that for most of us life would have no meaning without the yearnings and rewards of progressive consumption. It isn't merely that our bad habits will cause global catastrophes, but that our operative political-economic philosophies have us in such a blind crab grip that they prevent us from preparing for the natural disasters that are not our fault. So the apocalyptic shit is going to hit the fan, all right, but there'll be some of us it'll miss. Little pockets of humanity. Like the Clock People. Like you two honeys, if you decide to accept my offer of a lease on Siwash Cave. There's almost no worldwide calamity -- famine, nuclear accident, plague, weather warfare or reduction of the ozone shield -- that you couldn't survive in that cave.

Person1: ... So me and Sounder, ran right by the men that was the prisoners, and crawled under the fence! That's when I cut my hand on the glass. It hurt like mad! But I kept runnin', and then I didn't feel no more hurtin' till I stopped runnin'!  Why was that, Miss Johnson?
Person2: Because all you could think of was getting away from the guard.

Person2: You know, that was a good thing you did for Clarence, in class today. I believed his story, but I was afraid the other children wouldn't...
Person1: He was real scared nobody would believe him -- I could tell, even when he first stood up.
Person2: You could? How?
Person1: I been like that myself, when I thought nobody was gonna believe me...  You wanna hear another story?!
Person2: Not now, David, it's time for bed. You have a long trip ahead of you in the morning...

Person1: Brandon.. Just in case I die, there's something I have to know...
Person2: Yes Commander?

Person2: Well, that's the big question, isn't it?
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: It's been the subject of an extremely heated debate on the internet for years. Many believe that is a matter collapser, a bomb capable of destroying all matter in the universe in a chain reaction lasting 13 seconds.
Person1: But you don't?
Person2: No,  I am of the firm belief that in reality it is not a matter killer, but a matter REARRANGER, converting all molecules to the exact state they existed thirteen seconds previous to activation thus effecting a thirteen second time jump to the past.
Person1: How did you come to that conclusion?
Person2: My cousin's boyfriend's sister went out with the screenwriter. His favorite movie is the Omegaman.  He's seen it 13 times...

Person1: "I know thy works and thy labour and how thou canst not bear them that are evil. And thou hast tried them who say they are apostles and hast found them to be liars". Revelations II.

I'm not gonna sit in Congress and write a law that allows the NSA to point a camera and a microphone at anything they damn well feel like. And the next time you have something to say to me, we do it above-board, in my office, like everyone else. Now get outa my car, I've got a committee meeting on the hill.

Person2: He was trying to get into my apartment and... I know this sounds gross but I was so turned on. I grabbed him and kissed him!
Person1: And then?
Person2: I think I went in and fell asleep. I guess Gregory walked home and got killed! I blacked out.

Person2: And my bra finally fits again.

Person1: There's a lot of water between Vancouver and the U.S.A. This note is a suicide note.  After you're gone where would they look for you?  Why would they look for you? Darkness, and open water, and a fast cabin cruiser.  And I have a pocket full of money.  And if I helped you, I'd be committing a crime, or so they tell me.

Person1: You'll catch cold. It's cold.  What do you suppose he is, a survivalist?

Person2: He looks perfectly fine.
Person1: I think we should go. Please. Before he wakes up and, I don't know, eats us, or whatever feral things do.
Person2: I don't understand you. This is fascinating and you just want to run away. I mean, here we have a human being totally uncontaminated by civilization, totally free, and all you want to do is run back to your...

Person2: What?

Person2: Nathan, what the hell are you talking about?
Person1: Forget mice! Actually forget guinea pigs, cats, monkeys, and chimps also. I'm on to stage five: The human subject.
Person2: Oh no. You can't take him from his home, Nathan.
Person1: Don't you see? He's my Tabula Rasa, my Eliza Dolittle. He's my ticket to the top of the Behaviorist food chain. He's going to make me famous.
Person2: I won't allow you. It's wrong. He's happy here.
Person1: Is he, Lila? Is he happy living filthy and naked alone in this tick infested wilderness? Never to know the love of a good woman, never to revel in the pitter-patter of little feet, never to read Moby Dick, or marvel at a Monet, or just sit back after a day of hard but rewarding work, smoke a pipe, and wonder about the nature of reality.
Person2: You'd be taking away his freedom, Nathan.
Person1: Freedom's just another word for nothing left to lose, Lila, to quote Janet Jackson.

Person1: "The Angel of Flight 104!"  You're telling me you're the A...?

Person1: We have to think this through.  We have to be smart.  Now is not the time to panic.  If we panic now, we're done for.  Nobody saw it. Nobody knows it was us.  We're still okay.  Now all we have to do is just figure out our next move.

Person2: You know General McLelland, he wouldn't attack unless he had everything just right.  Finally Abe Lincoln came to him and said, General, if you're not going to use my army, could I borrow it for a while?  So he gave it to Grant and Grant just said, let's go.
Person1: I'm from Arkansas.  Tell me a story with Robert E. Lee in it and maybe I'll pay attention.
Person2: We're warriors, not desk jockeys.  We've got to be bold.  You always want all your ducks lined up.  But nothing's 100 percent.  It's always 60-40, maybe 51-49. Hell, I'd take 40-60.  Then roll the dice.
Person1: That's why you're a gambling man.
Person2: That's why I'm running foreign and you're not.  That's why you're not married and I am.
Person1: For the third time.
Person2: Take the plunge, admit your mistakes, move on to tomorrow.  That's FedEx, that's women, that's life.

Person1: I'm sorry to do this to ya here in front of a crowd, but I want ya to stand up and make a nice apology to my girl.
Person2: I'm sorry.

Person2: Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...
Person1: Request; life support systems check.
Person2: Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.

Person1: Today, for the first time, I've even wondered whether he might have killed Freddie. He would get so crazy if anybody contradicted him -- well, you know that. Marge. I loved you -- you might as well know -- I loved you, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see? I don't know, maybe it's grotesque to say this now, so just write it on a piece of paper or something, and keep it in your purse for a rainy day. Tom loves me.
Person2: Why do you have Dickie's rings?

Person1: Sorry.

Person2: No you don't understand. That's why I've been fighting to get you better. So you wouldn't be a patient anymore.
Person1: Why didn't you tell me sooner? I would have switched doctors!
Person2: Just get better okay?

Person1: Calm down.
Person2: I vouched for you. I vouched for you and you messed me up.
Person1: This shit's peanuts compared to what we're gonna make with Maxie.
Person2: Ricky. I'm trying to save this money. Understand? I'm trying to make it so my girlfriend doesn't have to grind her ass into other men's erections so her daughter can go to private school.
Person1: I'm sorry...
Person2: This is horseshit. It coulda been so easy.
Person1: It's gonna be fine.
Person2: No more, man.
Person1: Let's get some sleep. That's what we need, man. Sleep.
Person2: How we gonna sleep? We only got a few hours til dinner.
Person1: So what do we do?
Person2: Let's just go now and wait.
Person1: Three and a half hours?
Person2: I don't want to take any more chances.
Person1: Let's just go get guns, I'd feel better.
Person2: Don't mess around. You're gonna get us all killed.
Person1: Think about it. You knocked out that Jewish kid's tooth, cost him eight grand, maybe more. Maybe lost his whole line of clientele? He knows you're fucking up Jess' dancing, and I got a feeling he knows I stole his carpet cleaning van by the way he looks at me. He can't kill us in LA cause that leads to too many questions. So he flies us out here first class for a "drop" that's turned into whatever? He can make us disappear out here real nice...
Person2: Where do you get this shit?
Person1: Scenario B. I think I'm getting under Ruiz's skin. I'm no dummy. He doesn't like how it went down with the Red Drag -- Welshman, whatever. Now I got Fruitpie the Magician telling me I can't call my man Max? And that Welshman's sketchy.  Whatever, I don't know where it's coming, which way it's coming from, I'm telling you one thing right now, I'm not gonna be late for the dance.
Person2: You're not getting a gun.

Person1: Shall we go on?
Person2: He did it to make you stay with him!
Person1: Perhaps. He knew me. He knew I would love her more than the waking world. But there was more to it than that. Perhaps in the end he did it -- to show me that he could. For he lavished affection on her, there was no doubt about that. Life was very different with madame Claudia, as you can imagine...

Person1: He asked me why I thought I was in danger and I said.
Person1: Well if they can kill the President, they can certainly get me.
Person2: That doesn't make sense, Mrs. Hill. We have the man that killed the President.
Person1: No, you don't!
Person1: He kept trying to get me to change my story about the shots.  He was getting hot under the collar, and telling the woman not to write when he wanted.
Person1: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say?
Person2: I want the truth.
Person1: The truth is that I heard between four and six shots.  I'm not going to lie for you.
Person2: ...you heard echoes.
Person1: No.  I had guns all my life.  I used to go turtle shooting.
Person2: I realize you're under a great deal of stress .. it's clouded your judgement.
Person1: So off the record, he starts talking about my family, and even mentioned my marriage was in trouble like I didn't know it or something.  He got angrier and angrier and then
Person2: Look, we can put you in a mental institution.  We can make you look crazier'n Marguerite Oswald, and everybody knows how crazy she is.
Person1: I knew something was crooked as a dog's hind leg, 'cause no one who is just taking a deposition gets that involved and angry... sure enough, when I finally read my testimony as published by the Warren Commission, it was a fabrication from start to finish.

Person1: Rac. R-A-C. Renovate, Automate, Computerize. That, my boy, is the future. One of the monitors shows a little girl bowling. Her ball moves so slowly it barely tips over the first pin. Kastle hits a key and the pins explode in an emphatic strike. The little girl jumps with joy.
Person2: What ever happened to just bowling?
Person1: There's a lot of competition for amusement out there. You gotta adapt to survive.
Person2: I like the sport the way it is.
Person1: A guy like you could breathe some fire into bowling. You got ambition like a...like a...blowtorch. You go for what you want and anything that gets in your way - PSSSHHT! -  shish kebabs.  Maybe lady fate washed you up on my doorstep for your own good.  I think I could help you, Theo.
Person2: How Mr. Kastle?
Person1: You need a sponsor; I have influence. I could sponsor you.
Person2: Why would you help me?
Person1: I like you, Theo. You bowl with soul.

Person1: Good for you. Why shouldnt you protect whats yours.
Person2: I dont think youre hearing me.
Person1: Oh, Im hearing you, Alan. Thats not the problem. The problem is that what you think is yours, is really mine.  And I dont care how low on the totem pole I start, I will get it back...  So do yourself a favor and dont get too attached to that view because sometime soon, maybe very soon, you and your French country antiques, your chintz sofa, and your little play pen are gonna be moving out of that office.

Person1: ...you don't have to make a million dollars -- just get any stupid job so we can at least start looking for an apartment.
Person2: I wonder if I hang around with you because you're like my surrogate mother figure or something. Like I have this subconscious biological need to be nagged and bitched at constantly.
Person1: You hang out with me because nobody else can stand to be around you.
Person2: Or maybe... did you ever think that deep down we really might be lesbos? Maybe that's why we spend so much time together.
Person1: You're gross.  See that guy?
Person2: Which one?
Person1: He gives me a total boner!
Person2: He's like the biggest idiot of all time!

Person1: You gave $383 to the goddamn housekeeper! What the heck is your problem?
Person2: She needed it.

Person2: Her name's Inez. Stop calling her the housekeeper.
Person1: That's what she is!
Person2: I know that. But --
Person1: You're in love with the housekeeper!
Person2: Shut up!
Person1: What are you going to do, get married? Have a bunch of little idiot janitor brats! And go around scrubbing the --

Person1: I'm going to ask you one last time and if I don't get an answer, I don't even want to think about the consequences which would be frightening to say the least. Where's my chest, Jessica?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.

Person1: I never believed you were a murderer.  I knew.  I knew you are a magico.  I have seen it in you.  It's in your spirit.
Person2: I'm tired, Diego.  Go to bed.
Person1: You like to make the boundaries disappear.  It's not only the money, is it, George?  The adventure is part of the victory.  It's the thrill, ah?
Person2: Good night.
Person1: In my country, I am a magico.  A man with a dream.  A man on the rise.  To take nothing and make it something, okay?  I have failed my dream, but I will accomplish.  That is why I am in your country.  Yes, I lose my freedom. But they do not take my dream.  Do you have a dream, George?
Person2: I would if I could get some sleep.
Person1: Yes, you have a dream.  And maybe you accomplish your dream.  But yet you failed.  Why?
Person2: Because I got caught.
Person1: No, my brother.
Person2: Because they caught me?
Person1: You failed because you had the wrong dream.

Person1: So what's with this place? You have a swan fetish? Is this something you'd like to talk about?
Person2: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my painting. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occured to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since. You know what occurred to me?
Person1: No.
Person2: You're just a boy. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Person1: Why thank you.
Person2: You've never been out of Boston.
Person1: No.
Person2: So if I asked you about art you could give me the skinny on every art book ever written...Michelangelo? You know a lot about him I bet. Life's work, criticisms, political aspirations. But you couldn't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling. And if I asked you about women I'm sure you could give me a syllabus of your personal favorites, and maybe you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels to wake up next to a woman and be truly happy. If I asked you about war you could refer me to a bevy of fictional and non-fictional material, but you've never been in one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap and watched him draw his last breath, looking to you for help. And if I asked you about love I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at a woman and been truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief. That God had put an angel on Earth just for you. And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through cancer. You wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in a hospital room for two months holding her hand and not leaving because the doctors could see in your eyes that the term "visiting hours" didn't apply to you. And you wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much. I look at you and I don't see an intelligent confident man, I don't see a peer, and I don't see my equal. I see a boy. Nobody could possibly understand you, right Will? Yet you presume to know so much about me because of a painting you saw. You must know everything about me. You're an orphan, right?

Person1: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.
Person2: I do not think I like the sound of that.
Person1: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.
Person2: I feel hardly nothing.
Person1: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.
Person2: But why be so concerned about me?
Person1: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.
Person2: And you?
Person1: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.
Person2: I am not ready for this.
Person1: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.
Person2: Of course.
Person1: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.
Person2: That is not me.
Person1: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.

Your big opportunity is flying out of here.

Person1: Okay, James, I wish you hadn't shot my girlfriend's dog. Even though Poe and I weren't exactly what you'd call simpatico, that's no reason for him to take two in the chest. Still, the fact remains that I'm the one who took you up into the Chancellor's bedroom. I'm the one who has to take the blame. I don't know what the hell I was thinking.

You were thinking: "I've got to find a way to distract this kid." So you did. It was -- in its way -- a noble act.

I love Jake, but you don't know. He gets crazy sometimes. I'm scared.

Person1: I don't remember his name.  You must understand it was quite crowded, and when you are called in circumstances like that to look at the wound of the President who is dead, you don't look around too much to ask people for their names and who they are.

Person1: To do my work well, I have little time for --
Person2: You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?

Person2: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.
Person1: I did not realize it was obligatory.
Person2: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing --  why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?
Person1: No, sir.
Person2: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.
Person1: Well, I --
Person2: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?
Person1: -- Eduard --
Person2: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.

Person1: Thank you.  It's not important.

Person1: ... No, I went in for more improving pastimes.  Philosophy classes, language courses, European history, all that lark. Did you know that in Paris in the Eighteenth Century there were more rats in people's houses than there were people in people's houses.
Person2: Sounds like Beverly Hills.
Person1: Here, are you always this sarky?
Person2: Sarcastic, moi?  Maybe I'll mellow when my ship comes in.  It's expected any day now.  I'm all packed and ready to go.
Person1: Weren't you on a television series?
Person2: If it played in England somebody owes me money.  Who told you that -- Eddie?

Person2: Three seasons.  They found that's the limit of human tolerance when it comes to following the adventures of a family of Mormons on the Chisum Trail.  I was wife number three -- the ingenue.
Person1: Oh, it just ended, then.
Person2: Now who's being sarcastic?
Person1: When you've lost as many years as I have, love, puts things in perspective, know what I mean.
Person2: I'm sorry.  I guess the rest of us have no excuse for wondering where the time went.  It must've been the bars.

Person1: Forget him. It's not important. I was trying to make a point.

Person1: Wait. Slow down. A film like this, 16mm, cost two three hundred dollars, sold outright, shown in peep machines, maybe theatres, maybe not, is almost impossible to track. 'Nobody' makes it; 'nobody' shows it; 'nobody' sees it. It's like it doesn't even exist.
Person2: What's it called?
Person1: It was called 'Slave of Love' when I bought it. Next time it's sold, it'll be called something else.
Person2: But the police...
Person1: The police? They know less than you do.
Person2: Do you think she's safe?
Person1: Yeah. Probably.
Person2: You like this, don't you. Showing me... this.
Person1: I hate it. But you gotta know, buddy.  A lot of strange things happen in this world. Things you don't know about in Grand Rapids. Things you don't want to know about. Doors that should never be opened. I've known more about this sort of thing than a man should. Don't ask me why.

Person1: She sounds like a prisoner, Taransky.  Are you holding her hostage?  Are you some kind of Svengali?
Person2: Who's the hostage, Sayer, her or you?  You look kind of "captive" yourself.  While you're spending every waking hour obsessing over Simone, guess what, I guarantee she doesn't even know you exist.  Get off my property or I'll call the cops.
Person1: The cops?  The cops read my column to know who to bust.  We're the only watchdog the public has.  None of this is going away.  We'll be here tomorrow and the day after that.  Until you slip up.  And you will.  You are looking at your shadow.  Because all these elaborate precautions with Simone -- every instinct in my body tells me, it's not natural.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you, Sayer. I don't want you to be disappointed.  It gets cold out here at night.
Person1: Nice try.  If we can't get to her through you, maybe your family will be more co-operative.  I can guarantee you, Taransky, one way or another, Miss Simone and I are going to get acquainted.
Person2: I'd like to see that, Sayer. Invite me.

Person1: Good gracious!  What is this?
Person2: You are going to drive to the frontier.
Person1: It is shameful -- infamous!  I insist upon being put down at the Austrian ambassador's house.
Person2: I have orders to gag your honor if you cry out, and to give you this purse containing ten thousand frederics if you do not.
Person1: Ten thousand?  But the scoundrel owes me seventy thousand.
Person2: Your honor must lower his voice.
Person1: All Europe shall hear of this!
Person2: As you please.

Person1: You tell those guys they'll have to do one helluva lot better than that before I'll even say 'hi' to them.
Person2: Well, that's the State's offer. If you plead to possession and tell L.A.P.D. what they want to know, your bond will be set at one-thousand dollars. If you don't, L.A.P.D. will request one at twenty-five thousand based on your prior record and risk of flight. If you don't post it or don't know anyone who can, you'll spend six to eight weeks in County before your arraignment comes up.
Person1: Who's side are you on?
Person2: I beg your pardon?
Person1: What if I plead guilty?
Person2: And cooperate? You might get probation.
Person1: If I don't cooperate?
Person2: With the prior? You could get anywhere from a year to five depending on the judge. You want to think about it? You got two minutes before we're up.

Person1: So, you see if it wasn't for me, me and my friends would be at that KISS concert right now... together.
Person2: That's it?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Well, this is a unique confession to say the least, son. And not exactly the most interesting one I've ever heard either. You sure you don't want to talk about... oh, carnal knowledge with a neighborhood girl or impure thoughts about the new student teacher maybe... or how about finding a box of magazines under your dad's bed?
Person1: No.
Person2: Well then, I suggest you have a seat on the bench behind you and think of something a little juicier to confess than losing KISS tickets. Person1: Now I am the last to say that we have done here is a good thing. It's not. It's not a good thing. But it was, given the circumstances, the smart play. We did what had to be done. And...well...I'm proud of us. I'm proud of each and every one of us. We performed. Under the most complex and nerve shattering of situations, we stood fast and we delivered. I feel proud.

Person1: Wrong. That is flat out wrong. Hell is for cowards, for hypocrites who fear to live by the strenght of their own convictions. This is war. Given the circumstances, and given the fact that we are alive and they are not, we have chosen life over death. Two wrongs don't make a right. So our conviction and execution would only mean more death here, not less.

Person2: The infamous, unfashionable bluntness.  You're here so we can do business. I want to make a deal.

Person2: The powers that be have been quite busy lately, falling over each other to position themselves for the game of the century, if not the millennium.  Perhaps you've noticed.  Perhaps I could help deal you back in.

Person2: I've had a long time to make enemies, Dr. Arroway.  There are many governments, business interests, even religious leaders who would like to see me disappear. And I will grant them their wish soon enough... But before I do, I wish to make a small contribution -- a final gesture of goodwill toward the people of this little planet who've given -- from whom I've taken so much.
Person1: If I knew you any better I'd say that doesn't sound like you.
Person2: That's my girl...  Lights.

Churchill, vit his cigars and his brandy and his rotten paintings. Couldn't even say Nazi.  He would say Narzis, Narzis.  Ve vere not Narzies, ve vere Nazis.  But let me tell this, and you're getting it straight from the horse, Hitler vas better looking than Churchill, he vas a better dresser than Churchill, had more hair, told funnier jokes, and could dance the pants off Churchill!
