Person1: Leon?  Whatsa matter?  They give you a shot down the hospital or what?
Person2: Oh, God, they shot me with like unreal!
Person1: Well, you got to get hold of yourself.  You got to talk to him, tell him to give himself up.
Person2: Oh no!
Person1: He's got eight people in there with him.  He's got this kid with him ... they're gonna shoot the people.
Person2: I can't help it.  I can't stop him from anything.
Person1: If he won't listen to you, who will he listen to?
Person2: He won't listen to anybody.  He's been very crazy all summer.  Since June he's been trying to kill me.
Person1: You try calling the police?
Person2: What good is that?  They couldn't stop him.  And it'd just make him mad.  They don't know him.
Person1: Somebody's got to stop him, Leon.
Person2: He was under great strain. You don't understand, he's a very mixed up person.
Person1: He's makin' threats in there.
Person2: He's scared.  It's crazy.  I never met anyone like him.  His wife, he's a wonderful father to his children.  His mother - you should see her - his mother and father together are like a bad car wreck - he lets it all slide off his back, he sees them, he pays their rent. Unbelievable.  I wanted to get married ... He didn't really want it ... he's married already!  But he did it.  I don't know why.  I thought it would help me, but it didn't.  I was just as confused and unhappy was before; I did terrible things.
Person1: What kind of things, Leon?
Person2: Ten days I spent in Atlantic City - Sonny was frantic - he knew I was drinking; he didn't know where I was ... who I was with.  I couldn't explain why I did the things I did. So I went to this psychiatrist who explained to me I was a woman in a man's body.  So Sonny right away wanted to get me money for a sex change operation. But where was he to get that?  2500 dollars!  My God, he's in hock up to his ears already.
Person1: He needed money?  For the operation for you?
Person2: It made him crazy - so much demand, he'd fly into this rages.  And I got more depressed than ever; I saw I'd never get the operation.  So I tried to take my life - I swallowed about a half pound of pills ... blues, reds, yellows, downers, uppers, screamers ... you name it. But I just threw them up and wound up in the hospital.  Sonny comes there and looks at me and just says: "Wow!"  So when I hear he's in the bank, I almost go crazy because I know he's doin' it for me.
Person1: Well, don't you figure you owe to him to get him out of there?
Person2: I can't talk to him.
Person1: You're in it up to your ass, Leon. You're an accessory.  You talk him out of there and they might be a little more understanding of your case.
Person2: I'm afraid.
Person1: How is he gonna hurt you on the telephone?
Person2: I don't know what to say to him.  I can't.
Person1: You think it over, Leon.

Person1: I hear that! See, I knew she was never going to be a ranchest, but I wanted to try -- I thought maybe she'd give music lessons to the kids in town or at the school, maybe even recitals. My son would grow up here. Maybe have one or two more. I'd teach 'em what I could. They'd play with my brother's kids. All grow up together. And even if they all decided to go out into the world, they'd always know where home was -- cause we'd keep it for 'em...
Person2: That's very important to you, isn't it? Home.
Person1: Yeah, I think it is. And I don't mean everybody's got to be married, have kids -- It's more like, knowing where you're from, where you belong, what feeds you, where you can go no matter what happens... Knowing what you're supposed to be doing while you're here.

Person2: By asking me.
Person1: You still don't get it, do you?  You want to make an omelet, you break a few eggs - I needed to know just how bad the disease was - in the real world, not the lab.  And you never know til you try.  You thought you were genetically splicing together strains of influenza to create a cure for all influenzas.  But I saw you creating a disease so terrible in Chimera that the cure would be priceless.
Person2: You wanted the disease in order to peddle the cure.
Person1: Well, the thought had occurred to me.  I needed Chimera in order to peddle Bellerophon.  For hero to be appreciated, you need a monster. Now that's not so difficult to understand, is it?  Look, time was a shot of penicillin could knock off every bloody bug in the zoo!  Not anymore!..have you any idea the R&D money it takes to float one little pissy boutique antibiotic that's barely effective against one strain of one bacterium?  If I couldn't makes money killing the microscopic little shits that are out there, you'd help me put one out there I can make on!..there it is.  I've confessed.  I, John C. McCloy, am in business to make money.  Lilly's making billions feeding Prozac to depressed dogs.  Pfizer doesn't even know where to put the money they're making on Viagra, and let me tell you that shit didn't do a thing for me even at twice the recommended dose, Jesus, who do I have to screw to get a a break!..now get me out of here, get me treated and let's go back to work!..

Person1: This was my father's old study. When I was a kid, we had to be quiet when we played near here. When I was older, I learned many things from him here.  I was happy that this house never went to strangers; first Clemenza took it over, and then you.  My father taught me, in this room, never to act until you know everything that's behind things.  Never.  If Hyman Roth sees that I interceded with you in the Rosato Brothers' favor, he'll think his relationship with me is still sound.  I'm going somewhere to meet him tomorrow.  We have friends in some very important business that we're making.  Do this for me; you make the peace with the Rosato Brothers on their terms.  Let the word out that I forced you; you're not happy wit hit, but acquiesced, just because of me.  It will get back to Hyman Roth.  Do this, Frankie.  You can trust me.
Person2: Sure, Mike.  I'll go along.
Person1: Good.

Person1: You see, Karl, growing up, only knew that sex was wrong and that people who did it should be killed for it. He couldn't really read but, well, neither could his mother. But, his father made sure that his mother knew what the Bible said. And she made sure Karl knew. You know he slept in a hole in the ground under a toolshed, right?

Person1: His mother told him that he was their punishment. Hers and his father's; from God, for having sex--
Person2: Before they were married?
Person1: I don't think so. Just period, I think. She told him... God gave them the ugliest creation he could think of. Karl has an entire book -- a notebook. On every page it says "Franklin Chapter 1 Verse number 1." He wrote that a few years ago after he'd learned to write. His father's name was Franklin.
Person2: That's really strange. What does it mean?
Person1: One of his Daddy's Bible lessons I imagine. Y'all pull up a chair. I'll go out and talk to him.

Person1: Well, I got up one morning and went to work... just like any other day, except it was my first since hearing about the baby. And, I... I felt this fear and anxiety washing over me.  I looked around, and I thought, how can we raise a child surrounded by all this?  How can a child grow up here?  So, that night, I told her I didn't want us to have it, and over the next few weeks, I convinced her it was wrong.  I mean... I wore her down, slowly.
Person2: I want to have children.  It's just...
Person1: I can tell you now, I know... I'm positive I made the right decision.  I'm positive. But, there's never a day that passes that I don't wish I had decided differently.

Person1: Come on--we're taking off.

Person2: How could they recognize you? I don't recognize you. Anyway, you don't have a choice. You run, you might as well admit guilt, turn us both in right now. No, we stick this out-- find out what we can but change nothing. This is a minor inconvenience, that's all it is. We've faced worse than this. If I'd known you were going to panic at the last moment, I wouldn't have bothered. You can't quit on me now. I've invested too much in this. Besides, this plan is mine. I had other options, you know. I could have teamed up with someone braver. You want me to go in there and finish the job myself? We'll take off all right, from pad 18 just like we planned.

Person1: Would you mind repeating the question?

Turned out he was running a bookie joint right in the Actuarial Department tying up the switchboard, figuring the odds on our I.B.M. machines -- so the day before the Kentucky Derby, I called in the Vice Squad and we raided the thirteenth floor.

Person1: No, sir. I'm not going to deny it. But if you'd just let me explain --
Person2: You better.
Person1: Well, about six months ago -- I was going to night school, taking this course in Advanced Accounting -- and one of the guys in our department -- he lives in Jersey -- he was going to a banquet at the Biltmore -- his wife was meeting him in town, and he needed someplace to change into a tuxedo -- so I gave him the key    and word must have gotten around -- because the next thing I knew, all sorts of guys were suddenly going to banquets -- and when you give the key to one guy, you can't say no to another and the whole thing got out of hand -- pardon me.

Person1: I've got some good news.  The doctor says you're all better.  You can come home.

Person1: We're recruiting.
Person2: Who's recruiting?
Person1: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...

Person1: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.
Person2: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...
Person1: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?
Person2: Yes, please.
Person1: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

Person1: Please... no?  You mean "not here" -- that's it? You're a private Available but particular.  Don't worry. There's no one here but me. And you.
Person2: No.  Just no.
Person1: You prefer women?

Person2: A friend of mine went on Carousel tonight. Now he's gone.
Person1: Yes... probably he was renewed?
Person2: He was killed.
Person1: Killed? Why do you use that word?
Person2: Isn't it right? Isn't that what you do? Kill.
Person1: I never 'killed' anybody in my life. Sandmen terminate Runners.  Who brought you?
Person2: Nobody. I felt sad... I put myself on the circuit.
Person1: You felt sad. What's your name?
Person2: Jessica.
Person1: You're beautiful. Let's have sex.
Person2: No.
Person1: Later.
Person2: No.
Person1: But you put yourself on the circuit!
Person2: I thought I had to do something.
Person1: And?
Person2: I changed my mind.
Person1: And now?
Person2: Curious.
Person1: About what?
Person2: How a Sandman lives.

Person1: I knew you two pricks would give me problems. Give me shit cause I'm a woman. I'm not gonna take your male dominance bullshit!

Person1: By the way, Jeffrey, this story isn't going to the press and I'm going to ask you to consider all you've heard strictly confidential. Do not discuss this business with anyone, but me, or other police personnel. Got it?

Person1: I didn't mean to hurt you.
Person2: Shhhhhh. Now I have your disease.
Person1: You what?
Person2: You put your disease in me. Your semen. It's hot and full of disease.
Person1: There's no disease, I can tell you.
Person2: Men are crazy. Then they put their craziness into me. Then it makes me crazy. Then they aren't so crazy for awhile. Then they put their craziness in me again.  It's burning me, but I love you. I do, I do. Did you know that? Did you know that I love you?
Person1: I'm glad you do.
Person2: There's so much I want to tell you. I'm in so much darkness though with things moving. There is darkness sucking me. It's kissing me and darkness is entering me. In every hole. It's opening me to a death.
Person1: Dorothy. No!
Person2: If I die, then they'll be free. It's getting late, isn't it? I can tell, it's a cold feeling when it's late. It's warm then it gets cold. Jeffrey. I feel it getting cold.
Person1: You called me Jeffrey.
Person2: I did. Are you?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Why are you here?  HMMMMMMMM!!!! OK.
Person1: No. Not really.  But also because I really want you to be alright.

Person1: You idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.

Person1: Shut up, Plissken.

Person1: That's the deal.

Person1: Where do you think you're going?
Person2: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Person1: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!
Person2: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!
Person1: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
Person2: I know, but --
Person1: You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
Person2: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?
Person1: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
Person2: I'd like to think.
Person1: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
Person2: I get it!
Person1: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
Person2: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!
Person1: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
Person2: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --
Person1: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?
Person2: That one -- how you gonna take him? They'll see him.

Person1: I'm pretty sure I can get you a part on the show... But tonight? Pretend it's an acting job, kid. Showbiz.

Person1: Magua would use the ways of Les Francais and the Yengeese...
Person2: The red man put down the bow, picked up the fire stick and became the best warrior in the forest. Yes. It is the only way.
Person1: Would the Huron make his Algonquin brothers foolish with brandy and steal his lands to sell them for gold to the white man?  Would the Huron have greed for more land than a man can use? Like Francais Black Robes do?  Would Huron kill tribes with disease? Would the Huron fool Seneca into taking all the animals in the forest for beads & brandy? But sell the fur to the white man for gold?...  Those are the ways of Yengeese and Les Francais masters. Are they the ways of Huron men who hunt & work the land? Or of dogs?  ...Magua's heart is twisted. He would make himself into what twisted him. A Dog, become Master of Dogs. But are Hurons dogs?  ...Magua's way is false. It is like the white sickness. Magua's way will bring only sadness and shame. Is there another way? I don't know.  I am Nathaniel of the Yengeese; Hawkeye, adopted son of Chingachgook, of the Mohican people... Let the children of the dead Munro go free... I speak the truth.

Person1: I thought I told everybody to get out of my house. That includes cocksuckers and retards. Get off your asses and go.

Person1: Poor Mac.  It's been a bit of a struggle. I'm sure Sally's told you.
Person2: No, what?
Person1: The movie.
Person2: Oh, she's really enjoying it.  I think. Is Mac okay?
Person1: I don't know what's going on.  I don't care to guess.  Mac's really unhappy. She isn't there, that's all.  She's no idea what she's playing, not a clue.
Person2: Who, Sally?
Person1: And, you know it isn't rocket science, this script.  She can barely get the lines out.  There was a scene last week - she sobbed, through every take.  I know crying's easy for her but it's a comedy, Joe.  Something's gone.  You know, that thing that was Sally - that always surprised you.  It's gone.  I think she's scared.  And that's death.
Person2: I still think she sails above the rest. I mean not like her early films.  But those were all such great directors.
Person1: Mac's a pretty great director, Joe.  He's a woman's director.  And nothing's happening.  Course he won't fire her, because of the friendship... But it was discussed.  He had to battle his studio to get her in the first place.
Person2: What?
Person1: Hey, listen, I love her.  She's Sophia's best friend.  I never said any of this, alright.  I'll deny it on the stand...  You guys are gonna have kids.  That is so great.  Maybe that's what this is all about.  Maybe she doesn't want to do this anymore.  You know adults don't do this for a living.  You guys are gonna have your kids, you'll be directing -- one asshole in the family is enough.  Sophia knew that intuitively.  Look at Clair. Clair's a mess.  Make sure she gets the epidural.  Forget that natural childbirth shit. Everything's going to be what it's supposed to be.  "Life is but a walking shadow.  A poor player who struts and frets his hour upon the stage and then is heard no more..." And speaking of me, the role of Leo in your film?
Person2: Leo?
Person1: Any thoughts on casting yet?
Person2: Leo?  It was out to Jude Law.  Jude passed.
Person1: Well, I can't make any promises, and of course I haven't read the script but I loved the novel...when are you shooting?
Person2: October-ish.
Person1: I have a small window of time.
Person2: Leo.  Leo's twenty-eight, Cal.
Person1: Scratch the two, write in a four.
Person2: Scratch the two, write in a four.
Person1: You've got a lot of gall.  Thirty nine.
Person2: Five years ago, I was at the party, remember?

Person1: Her name is Alice. You know I love that girl to death. If I ever found out somebody was makin' out with her, I'd take this...  ...and shove it so far up his ass it would come out his mouth... Then you know what?...
Person2: What?
Person1: I'd pull the trigger and shoot him right between the eyes.

Person1: You like the ponies?
Person2: Sure. Yeah.
Person1: You bet the ponies?
Person2: Me? No. Not really.
Person1: Smart. Hard as hell to handicap. You know what I like? Hai Alai. Fast game. You know why I like it?
Person2: Why?
Person1: It's fixed. That's the only way to win. A sure thing. See that horse. The blaze.
Person2: This one?
Person1: Yeah. The blaze. I bought her in '66. Hired a trainer, stall, whatever it was. That horse made me over a hundred grand. In 'sixties' dollars. You know what that is today?
Person2: Pshhh...
Person1: A million. Easy.
Person2: She was fast, huh?
Person1: Never won a race. But it got me in with the trainer. We'd have a thing, I don't remember, some thing. The jockey would raise his whip, it meant the fix was in, we'd all go running. People get greedy. First they bet small, they keep their mouth shut. Within a month's time, everyone and their brother was in on it. The odds would drop, I mean you could watch the board. It looked like a stopwatch, the odds would drop so fast.
Person2: That's why they call it the smart money.

Person1: My fault!  My fault!  This nut case goes out on a ledge and it's my fault?
Person2: If anything happens to John BUbber, Mister LaPlante I'm going to see you prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
Person1: What, is everybody in love with this, bozo?  I don't get this.  What about...?
Person2: Yes, everybody is in love with John Bubber.  The whole country, in fact. And they're not going to be happy if he jumps to his death because he was harassed by a lousy little money-grubbing low-life fence...
Person1: "Harassed."  Cause I yelled at him when he's riding in his limo?  The guy's a thief, he took my...
Person2: He had one tiny, uncharacteristic moment of weakness.  That's not the same thing as a lifetime of petty crime...
Person1: Hey, lady, I got faults, I know I'm not perfect but I don't get this at all, your attitude.  I saved your...
Person2: A lifetime of petty crime climaxed by your sleaziest accomplishment yet...  blackmailing a national hero...
Person1: -- saved your...  whaaaaaaat?  What? Blackmailing...?
Person2: You think I haven't figured it out? Just because the cops aren't on to you yet doesn't mean you're home free.  I'm a veteran reporter.  I've seen your kind before, the underbelly of crime.
Person1: Underbelly!
Person2: In all that smoke and fire, John had a moment of weakness.  He'd been down and out, destitute, living in his car.  It was just an impulse, stealing my purse.

Person1: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, 'cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?
Person2: Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?
Person1: Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?
Person2: Is she?
Person1: Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ...  Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it ... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!
Person2: And you honestly think that's what she meant?
Person1: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh.

Person1: 'Scuse me.
Person2: I know it can't be easy. Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny. At least they can go out in public. But for you? People staring. Whispering behind your back...
Person1: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --
Person2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

Person1: How would you like to go back to teasing hair, big mouth?
Person2: Roger, do you mind if we talk a little business?
Person1: Please, please, that's what we're here for.  Be careful, that hurt.
Person2: I think this would be a marvelous opportunity for you, Roger.  Up to now, you've always been associated with musicals, and...
Person1: Yes.  Dopey show-girls in gooey gowns.  Two-three-kick-turn!  Turn- turn-kick-turn!  It's enough to make you throw up!  At last a chance to do straight drama!  To deal with conflict, with inner truth.  Roger De Bris presents history.  Of course, I think we should add a little music.  That whole third act has got to go. They're losing the war.  It's too depressing.  We'll have to put something in there.  Aaahghhh!  I see it!  A line of beautiful girls, dressed as Storm Troopers, black patent leather boots, all marching together... Two-three-kick-turn!  Turn-turn- kick-turn!
Person2: That's genius.  That's genius. Roger, I think I speak for Mr. Bloom and myself when I say that you're the only man in the world who can do justice to SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER.

Person1: Why do you want the white horse to bid you "good-day"?

Person2: I'd love to.  But he keeps showing up.  And you keep talking to him.  I can't have that--

Person1: We're damaged goods.
Person2: No, we're not!
Person1: We are, Miles. You know I'm right. There's something "off" about you and me Miles. And maybe it isn't because of these women -- maybe they were just extremely insightful and recognized our "deficiencies" very early on. Maybe...
Person2: That is bullshit! Mine is a bitch and yours is a psycho. I can't believe you're saying this, Marylin! There's nothing wrong with us. We're attractive and charismatic and successful and... I like us.
Person1: I'm sorry Miles. You shouldn't listen to me. I'm sure you have a very fulfilling life. I'd better go. I'm depressing.
Person2: No.
Person1: Thank you for the coffee. It's very robust.

Person1: You killed them.
Person2: It was only a matter of time before somebody killed somebody.  You saw it coming as well as I did. Dodge had his plans, starting with scuttling the boat. And Greer too, except he went nuts. Couldn't take it, I guess. Could've happened in the middle of downtown Anchorage. But did it make him any less dangerous? I don't think so.
Person1: So you killed them?
Person2: The way I figure it, it was them or me. I thought putting Dodge up on that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a little time. Made it look like whoever killed those Greeks was still around. But it's just us on this ship. Us and your... spirit friends.
Person1: And now you're gonna kill me, is that it?
Person2: I didn't want it to turn out this way.
Person1: Murphy, don't you see what's happening?
Person2: I think I see it pretty well.
Person1: It's the ship. The ship's making you think this way.
Person2: I know a little bit about human nature and what I've seen only confirms that.
Person1: It's a trap. There was no way we were gonna get away with that gold. Nobody ever does. It's just the bait. This ship sucks people in and it never lets them out.
Person2: I think maybe you been on this boat a little too long, with all that supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's nothing supernatural about greed. And that's what it comes down to, pure and simple.
Person1: I don't give a damn about the gold.
Person2: I wish I could believe that. Either way, you know what I've done. I've got no choice.

Person1: You'll never have another chance to hit me again.  I never knew till this minute -
Person2: Susan, it seems to me -
Person1: Don't tell me you're sorry.
Person2: I'm not sorry.

Person2: No, you're not.
Person1: Yes.

Person1: He might be interested... but it would mean another five thousand.

Person1: Okay.   Okay.    I believe you.
Person2: You killed her!

Person2: Okay.  You're not a team player. You gotta do things your own way. Fine.  Nail this guy and make us all look good.  But you better watch your ass.  If you screw up, I can promise you, you're goin' down.

Person1: Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.
Person2: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.
Person1: Unfortunately.
Person2: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.
Person1: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.
Person2: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...
Person1: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.
Person2: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.
Person1: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.
Person2: Go on.
Person1: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.
Person2: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.
Person1: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

Person1: Now I'm the one who's nauseous. So what's the deal? What do you need me for?
Person2: There's some folks I want to keep tabs on. Dirty, tattooed, uncivilized. Your kind of people.
Person1: What do I get out of it?
Person2: If you find out what I want to know, and if I'm able to successfully use that information, you get to go back to your degenerate little life. If not, you take a bath.
Person1: You're one sick bastard. A sadist with a badge looking to rope me in to a suicide mission. I think no matter which way I go I'm likely to wind up face down on a sheet of plastic. So here's my answer

Person2: You know.
Person1: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!
Person2: I'm not the Devil.
Person1: Then what, what are you? Tell me...
Person2: Better if I just show you.

Person1: They've taken my mind, my memories...
Person2: What?  Who has?
Person1: Is that your idea of a joke?  I don't remember...  Take my advice, Bumstead.  Get off this case.  Now.
Person2: What is going on?

Person1: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.
Person2: I did.
Person1: No, you didn't!
Person2: I poisoned his life.
Person1: But not his body.
Person2: What difference does that make?
Person1: My son, why should you want all Vienna to believe you a murderer? Is that your penance? Is it?
Person2: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!
Person1: Oh my son, my poor son!
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

Person1: What are you crazy kids doing in my tool shed?
Person2: We're not crazy. We're "special". PRINCIPAL COLLINS wants us to have our own classroom!
Person1: My boy's special, well how about that. I knew you were different.
Person2: So I guess you'll need a new spot for your moonshine.
Person1: I reckon so.

Person1: What about him?
Person2: I need to ask you questions of a psychological nature.
Person1: Remember when you asked for a study on him, I refused. Same goes for now.
Person2: That was Peterson upstairs.
Person1: It was you who did the asking.
Person2: He doesn't think you run mind games on him.
Person1: I wouldn't presume to try.
Person2: You're never alone in a room with Graham, are you? You're smooth about it, but you're never one-on-one with him. Why's that? Do you think he's psychic?
Person1: He's an eideteker. He has almost total recall.  But I don't think he's psychic.  What he has it empathy and projection.  He can assume your point of view and mine.., and some other points of view that scare and sicken him.
Person2: Why aren't you ever alone with him?
Person1: Because I'm professionally concerned about him. And he'd pick up on that. He's fast. He hates being prodded and poked.  So do I.  What do you want?
Person2: His nervous breakdown followed Hobbs. Could he kill again if he had to save his life? Or would he hesitate?
Person1: I'll tell you the events. The psychology's none of your business. Hobbs was trying to cut his eleven- year-old daughter's throat. Graham shot him with his .38 six times. Hobbs still didn't go down. He had to wade in...
Person2: That's when it happened?
Person1: No. It happened when Graham went to see Hobbs' daughter four months later in the hospital. She saved her carotid artery.., but lost three fingers and her larynx. She was connected up to a voice box.  When Graham went to see her, she asked him -- through the speaker: "Why did you have to kill my daddy?"  That's when Graham had his nervous breakdown.
Person2: What's the bottom line?
Person1: If he pushes too deep into our boy's mind-set, he may destroy himself.  What are you planning, Jack?
Person2: Could he handle a direct contact?
Person1: I don't recommend it.

Person1: I say none of us leave this room until our young Mary here stops jerking us around and decides once and for all who she wants. Now Mary, I know this is difficult but you really will be doing them all a favor to tell them the truth about us.

Person1: "Big and older"?
Person2: You can shut up now.

Person2: I swear I'll shoot you in your sleep.

Person1: Let me explain about time- you've been here three months and already two months behind. And the Germans and the French are gearing up. And I don't care about you and I don't care about the thirty dead- I care about my knighthood and if this railroad finishes on schedule, I'll get my knighthood and I want it.  Professional hunters may be the answer.
Person2: All they'll bring is more chaos and we've plenty of that already- and if they come in, word will get out- and what happens to your knighthood then?
Person1: I'm going to try and locate Redbeard- I assume you've heard of him.
Person2: Every man who's ever fired a rifle has heard of him- by the time you find him, the lions will be dead.
Person1: Very well, the job's still yours, I'll go. But if I have to return, you're finished. And I will then do everything I can to destroy your reputation. Am I not fair?  Told you you'd hate me.

Person1: Yeah - where were you?
Person2: With you.
Person1: With me?

Person1: It did?  Boy, did it ever!
Person2: So I had to rush him to the hospital and give him a transfusion...  Right?
Person1: Right.  We have the same blood type...
Person2: - Type O.

Person1: Go on back to the hotel.
Person2: Please, Eddie, don't beg him.
Person1: Would you go on back to the hotel? Take a cab, go on back to the hotel.
Person2: Doesn't all of this come through to you, Eddie? Doesn't any of this mean anything to you? That man, this place, the people. They wear masks, Eddie. And underneath the masks they're perverted, twisted, crippled.

Person1: What makes you so sure this will work?

Person2: Listen, either he wastes away as a pathetic vegetable or he can give what's left of his life to save hundreds of potential victims. He's a McDermott. I know what his choice would be.
Person1: I suppose you're right. But I still don't like it.

Person1: Okay, Pat, take it easy -- don't do anything reckless.

Person1: Say it.

Person2: But I speak English.
Person1: Will you please do it my way? You'll get into trouble if you don't. If anybody talks to you, tell them... I do not speak English.
Person2: I do not speak English.

Person2: 'Las Vegas, please. I do not speak English.' What is hitchhike?

Person2: Yes.

Person1: Kevin?  Do you not love me?
Person2: No, I don't not love you.  I like, I know that we've definitely got something between us.  Something good. Something special.

Person1: This isn't a courtroom.  Don't try to turn this around on me.

Person1: Oh my God! I almost forgot--I got you a meeting with the admissions guy from Dartmouth!
Person2: What! But--I wasn't even going to go to college--
Person1: No, I know, but I pulled some strings, got him to look at your writing, and he agreed to meet you.

Person1: told him  --if I'm wrong about this girl, you can take away my teaching certificate!

Person1: Now that is a happy sound! Tomorrow, I want the citizens -- my people -- back in the arena.  The Gods know, I'm tired.  Come to bed, now; tonight we're celebrating.
Person2: What are you talking about?

Person2: If I ever loved Narcissus it wasn't like you want.

Person1: Or rather, bad news and good news, because he likes this person playing tonight.  I mean, he liked Laura too, I didn't mean that.  And he likes you.  It's just that --
Person2: I understand, Dick.
Person1: Sure.  'Course.  Rob, look.  Do you want to... talk about it, that kind of thing?

Person1: Mummy and I, we were more like lovers, really, or sisters.  Then a couple of years after Daddy died, and not long after I left Oxford, she started seeing various men and I was furious.  I really was upset. I stopped going home.  I never phoned.  I went round telling everyone how awful her books were. And she hardly seemed to notice, and that made me angrier.  Then I got a job I was interested in, and I started to see lots of men, and I suppose I grew up a little and began to understand.  So I wrote her a long letter, almost seven pages, saying how sorry I was, and how I was worried that we were drifting apart.  And do you know, she wrote me a poem, a really beautiful poem about mothers and daughters.
Person2: How nice.
Person1: It makes me weepy just to remember it.  So we were fine again, and then she got married to Matthew who's a womaniser and a bit of a yob, but quite nice really, makes TV commercials.  What about yours.
Person2: Both dead.
Person1: That must be rather nice, in a way.  I mean, you don't have any--

Person1: Good afternoon.
Person2: I came to make a clean breast of everything... the whole business.
Person1: Yes.  Of course.  Very wise.
Person2: Remember when I went to Italy and canceled the policy on the new stadium.  Well, we weren't being cheated by the Mafia or anybody except maybe by me...  ... Do they come for lunch everyday? I really went on my own business, to see a man that I happen to be in love with... and I'm glad I did it, but I'm sorry about the policy and I'll be happy to make up the money the company didn't get... of course just now I don't have...  One million, four hundred and ten thousand dollars.  But if you were to dock my salary, say, twenty dollars a week, in a few hundred years we'd be even... and I think this is where you fire me?
Person1: You're right.  You're fired.
Person2: Will that interfere with my getting maternity leave?  I'm pregnant.
Person1: The Italian, I presume?
Person2: No.  He's French, he was just in Italy for the competition.
Person1: He seems to have won it.
Person2: Yes, isn't it wonderful?  I'm so happy.  I'll bet I'm the happiest pregnant fired person in the world!

Person1: The families... want your ticket. Turn it in, we forget the whole thing.  Everybody goes home.
Person2: ... Absolutely not.

Person2: I am accountable.

Person1: You actually listen to all those tapes?
Person2: No, I just like the effect a tape recorder has on you.  How you feeling today?
Person1: A little less than yesterday.

Person1: You're not my therapist. You're hear to study me. Face it  I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
Person2: That's not true, Parker.
Person1: If I had died yesterday, you'd have already dissected my brain and analyzed it to see if I carry any genetic predisposition toward violence.
Person2: What was going through your mind when you killed the busboy?
Person1: Not much. He was just a computer program. Nothing more.
Person2: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did.  You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...
Person1: Go to hell.
Person2: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it?  But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.
Person1: Enough!

Person2: Take it easy, Ruby...
Person1: Did you find a scalpel? Did you find a murder weapon?

Person2: Mm-hm.

Person2: What secret shall I tell?

Person2: A man would be more considerate. He wouldn't come home to his wife a nervous wreck.

Person2: It could be a purely impersonal thing. What matters is the therapeutic value of relieving your tensions.

Person2: What room have you got?

Person1: It's okay, Enzo.  I'll go somewhere else.
Person2: Not only is Jacques Mayol a very special friend, but he happens to be one of the best divers in the world!  And you're throwing him out!  Are you crazy, or what? Stupido!

Person1: To our assignment.

Person2: I don't know.  I have to think...
Person1: Here.  Sit down.  Be comfortable.

Person2: People love you but I know you. Jennifer Forbes told me the petition she signed was to put a jacuzzi in the cafeteria. And Doug Hylton...

Person2: Don't talk to me like that.

Person2: No.

Person1: You're out of your mind, you know that!? You're messed up!?

Person1: That's how it is.  You see her approaching you toss out installment one.
Person2: I'm tying it up in a bundle now. Where is she?

Person1: Well?

Person2: At your discretion...But first, I desire more entertainment.

Person2: Ahh, there is yet time.
Person1: At the first sight of the morning's rays' light...
Person2: I know the laws of the night. I state there is still time for yet another.
Person1: I would have time for my own pleasures!
Person2: Your own pleasure comes only after mine, when I desire it. I am the Sole Ruler of the Dark World.  There is no one to challenge my authority here. My word is the law--all powerful. No one is to challenge that authority, no one!.  Is that understood?  It is my command.
Person1: I understand, Master
Person2: Then see that it does not happen again, in the penalty of Everlasting Despair.  Now are there others?
Person1: There are others.
Person2: Well then let us proceed.

Person1: Sorry but I have to get at least one fight out of you otherwise I won't even get back the cost of the bribe I had to pay the arena slaves to get you here.  I know what you're trying to do.
Person2: I refuse to be your slave.  I refuse --
Person1: -- to fight?  We'll see...

Person1: Merde... Wait here. When I return you tell me about last night, huh?
Person2: But... I don't remember anything, I swear...
Person1: I leave these open. Maybe something comes back to you.

Person1: I tell you he hasn't and he wouldn't dare use it if he had.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Because he drove Jessica insane -- deliberately -- coldly!

Person1: I don't, I don't remember. What do I owe you?
Person2: Uh, eleven twenty-five.

Person1: What do you mean, thank God?
Person2: Well, are you sure about this baby thing? It's not the ticking clock shit, is it?
Person1: No, no, not at all... I mean I've still got plenty of time.  Don't I?  I mean I still have a good six years, whatever. We could have three kids yet, if we wanted.  And I know I've always said I never wanted kids, and I didn't... but this year, I really, truly, feel ready...
Person2: Honey, I'm not worried about you.  You are going to be a fantastic mom.  Not an issue.  I pressed you, remember?  Joe, on the other hand, is a different story.
Person1: Oh Soph, Joe loves kids.  Joe wants kids. Joe thinks he needs kids.
Person2: He wants playmates.  Oh he's a sweetheart, Sal, you know I love him. But he's not going to be a good father. He's just not parenting material.
Person1: Hey, let's sit down.  I bet the rug feels really nice against your skin.

Person1: You told us about the appearance of this... voice.  What exactly did you see?  Part of it... or all of it?
Person2: His face.
Person1: Does he have hair?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Is it long and hanging down?
Person2: I'm more interested in what he says, not what he looks like.
Person1: But if the devil were to take on the physical appearance of a saint or an angel... or a man... how would you recognize him?  By what he said?
Person2: Go on to the next question.
Person1: That's enough!  You will answer the question... or face the consequences!

Person1: It's a generous offer, Mr. Galvin... ...nothing can make the woman well...but we try to compensate...to make a gesture...

Person1: We thought it was just.
Person2: You thought it was just.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Because it struck me how neatly 'three' went into the amount.  Two Hundred Ten Thousand.  That would mean I keep seventy.

Person2: Yes.  It would be.

Person1: Don't you realize that everybody here is going to know about this? That you've packed your bags and ordered the car and -
Person2: - And left?  Of course they'll hear.  I'm not saying goodbye - except to you - but I never imagined that people wouldn't know.

Person1: ... looks like you grown another inch... but you don't look so hot, getting bags under your eyes, starting to look old like me.
Person2: Ah, I had a tough day. Some jerk D.K'd me and I gotta cover his loss.
Person1: Speak English will ya.
Person2: D.K. -- didn't know -- who I was when the options he bought took a bath. He reneged on me.
Person1: I told you not to go into that racket. You could've been a doctor or a lawyer,
Person2: Coulda been a contender.
Person1: you coulda stayed at Bluestar and been a supervisor in instead of going customer relations by now, 'stead of going off and bein' a salesman.
Person2: Look Dad, I'm not a salesman. How many times I gotta tell you I'm an account executive, and pretty soon I'm going to the investment banking side of the firm.
Person1: You get on the phone and ask strangers for their money, right? You're a salesman.
Person2: Dad, it takes time. You gotta build a customer list. I'm doing it. I could make more money in one year as a broker than five years at the airline.
Person1: I don't get it, you get a scholarship to NYU, you get 35,000 the first year, and 50 last year, where the hell is it?
Person2: 50 K don't get you to first base in the Big Apple, Dad, not any more. I pay 40% in taxes, I got a rent of 15,000, I got school loans, car loans, food, park my car costs me 3 bills a month, I need good suits, that's $500 a pop, shoes...
Person1: So come home and live rent free, 'stead of that cockroach palace you live in. $50,000 Jesus Christ, the world is off its rocker. I made $37,000 last year and you...
Person2: It's Queens, Dad and a 5% mortgage and you rent the top room--I gotta live in Manhattan to be a player, Dad. There's no nobility in poverty anymore, y'know. One day you're going to be proud of me, you'll see...
Person1: It's yourself you've got to be proud of, Huckleberry, how much ya need?
Person2: Can you spare three hundred? Pay you back next month, promise.

Person1: And?
Person2: Your Grandfather pointed out Shake was always being taller than me just to spite me.
Person1: I knew it, he started it, I should have known.
Person2: Y'what?
Person1: You two have never had a quarrel in your life and in two minutes flat he's got you at it. He's a king mixer. Adam and Eve, meet the serpent. Anthony and Cleopatra, there's your asp. Divide and Conquer, that's this one's motto. He hates group unity so he gets everyone at it.

Person1: I want to fly, sir!
Person2: That's no reason. Everybody wants to fly. My grandmother wants to fly. You going after a job with one of the airlines?
Person1: I want to fly jets, sir!
Person2: Why? Because you can do it alone?
Person1: No, sir!
Person2: What is it, the kicks? Is that it?
Person1: I don't want to do something anybody can do.
Person2: Pity you don't have the character.
Person1: That's not true, sir! I've changed a lot since I've been here! And I'm gonna make it, sir!
Person2: Not a chance, asshole!

Person1: But you can't let her get involved now, Ben. Vader will destroy her.
Person2: She hasn't been trained in the ways of the Jedi the way you have, Luke... but the Force is strong with her, as it is with all of your family. There is no avoiding the battle. You must face and destroy Vader!

Person1: Go, go, go, jump!
Person2: You're crazy!  I'm not gonna jump!
Person1: Tim, you're going to have to let go of the fence.  Tim! Get down right now.  Get off the fence!  Now!

Person1: Well ?

Person1: We will start work on it now sir.

Person1: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person2: Sweet Dick, I didn't mean it like that.
Person1: Yes you did.

Person1: He makes you feel pretty unhappy?
Person2: He calls me a dirty tramp--my own father!
Person1: Do you think your father means that?
Person2: Yes!  I don't know!  I mean maybe he doesn't mean it but he acts like he does.  We're altogether and we're going to celebrate Easter and catch a double bill.  Big deal.  So I put on my new dress and I came out and he--
Person1: That one?
Person2: Yes--he started yelling for a handkerchief--screaming.  He grabbed my face and he rubbed all my lipstick off--he rubbed till I thought I wouldn't have any lips left.  And all the time yelling at me--that thing--the thing I told you he called me.  Then I ran out of the house.
Person1: Is that why you were wandering around at one o'clock in the morning?
Person2: I was just talking a walk.  I tried to call the kids but everybody was out and I couldn't find them.  I hate my life.  I just hate it.
Person1: You weren't looking for company, were you?
Person2: No.
Person1: Did you stop to talk to anyone, Judy?  Do you enjoy that?
Person2: No.  I don't even know why I do it.
Person1: Do you think you can get back at your Dad that way?  I mean sometimes if we can't get as close to somebody as we'd like we have to try making them jealous--so they'll have to pay attention.  Did you ever think of that?
Person2: I'll never get close to anybody.
Person1: Some kids stomped a man on Twelfth Street, Judy.
Person2: You know where they picked me up! Twelfth Street!  I wasn't even near there!
Person1: Would you like to go home if we can arrange it?  Did you notify the parents?

Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Meet me at three.
Person1: What - what, Caesar's?
Person2: No, a...
Person2: ...hundred yards further down the road.

Person2: Don't ask questions. Just be there.

Person1: What are you crazy?

Person1: I can't... they don't work that way...
Person2: Forget how they work. Just do it. Like your man says, "By any means necessary."

Person1: Okay? With this pad, the killer wheels? Looks like you really cleaned up your act.

Person2: Who, here, could possibly care what you want?  At best, you're Employee of the Month for the highest bidder in the Solaris auction.  They have no idea what's going on up here. They've never even been in space. And I'm supposed to listen to you?
Person1: I am here to recover this mission, report my findings, and make a recommendation.  Now, what happened to him?

Person2: In the lab.  With her, probably.

Person1: Stop it. You are blowing a great opportunity here, Miles. Maya, man. She's great. She's cool. She's funny. She knows wine. What is this gloomy come-down nonsense? These girls want to party. And what was that ten-minute lecture on, what was it, Vouvrays? I mean, come on!
Person2: Let's just say I'm uncomfortable with the whole scenario.

Person2: I recall you.

Person2: Yeah.

Person2: We didn't hit it off.

Person2: How are you?
Person1: Good.  How are you?
Person2: I'm fine.

Person2: Oh, no.
Person1: Yeah, really.  You do.  You do.
Person2: Yeah?

Person2: Yeah, it was.
Person1: Remember slamming the cab door in my face and..  you know, it came very dangerously close to emasculating my nose in a...

Person2: Bobby laid his own tracks.  He could have gone quietly but he played the hard-ass con till the end. And as far as I'm concerned, he wife and kid are a hell of a lot better off without him.  Now take the money.

Person1: They found another note?
Person2: Uh-huh. Another News clipping. Another one about Sid's mom. Dewey, whether we like it  or not it looks like we're going to have to  go back into our past.
Person1: You mean OUR past as in Me and Sid. This has nothing to do with you Gale.
Person2: This has everything to do with me Dewey. I was the one who brought the nation's attention to this shit anyway. I'll be damned if I'm gonna sit around and pass on the buck again.
Person1: Do you really mean it this time Gale?
Person2: Yes. Look, let's get something straight Dewey, I got into this shit cause the police came looking for ME. Not cause I'm out to make the SUNRISE STUDIOS SLASHINGS.
Person1: Why would the police come to you?
Person2: Again, I am the author of the definitive book on the Woodsboro murders.!  What about you?
Person1: What about me?
Person2: You said you'd never leave Woodsboro, 'The only place that's real!'  But now you're here. Not with me.  Dewey, I took care of you.  I waited until you were well.  I couldn't stay there, I mean, it's like dog years, one year in Woodsboro is like seven everywhere else.
Person1: So it's off to London for a week?  New York for a month? L.A Forever?
Person2: It was '60 Minutes II'!  I couldn't say no!  I could've been the next Diane Sawyer!
Person1: What's wrong with just being Gale Weathers? I liked her!
Person2: It didn't work Dewey.  We tried,  we're different.
Person1: You used to say that was our strength.
Person2: Dewey, you're not just here because of that second rate K-Mart, straight-to-video version of me, are you?
Person1: Brace yourself, Gale, all of this is actually not About you.
Person2: All of what Dewey?  You do know something, don't you?
Person1: Off the record.
Person2: Always.
Person1: Two months ago, the Woodsboro police got a call from a woman who said she was with 'Stab 3'.  She wanted to see the file on Sid, for research.
Person2: And?
Person1: The boys said no.  She wouldn't give her name. A month later, the station gets broken into, the file room ransacked.
Person2: Someone stole Sid's file?
Person1: I already removed it.  I think someone on the film was trying to find Sid, and that's the only reason I came here. To make do a little private investigating of my own and make sure no one here was planning anything.
Person2: I'm sorry, this is too good!
Person1: What part of 'Off the record' don't you understand?
Person2: Right. Sorry.  Do you think he did it?
Person1: I've got my suspicions but still, nothing  you say can ever make me take my eyes off one person.
Person2: And who is that?

Person1: You haven't said a word since we left the club -- what happened back there?
Person2: I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to tell you or not.
Person1: I don't think I follow you.
Person2: He said if I told anybody it could prove fatal for them as well as me.
Person1: Who said?
Person2: That's what I'm not supposed to say.
Person1: Stop this nonsense! If you're in some sort of trouble I want to know about it.
Person2: Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying me.
Person1: I wasn't --
Person2: Yes, you were -- you called it nonsense. Being murdered in cold blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it happens to you sometime.

Person1: He likes it.

Person1: ...I've never tried it.

Person1: Oh, you mean Fred.

Person2: He never told me anything about... that's unbelievable!

Person1: I ain't never used no hatchet that I remember.

You're just a bit odd it looks like to me. Not really, I'm just jokin' with you. Welcome to our humble home, buddy. Frank needs all the friends he can get. Frank's a real weak little kid. His daddy taught him how to be a timid person.

Person1: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport.  ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world...  Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...
Person2: I don't understand.
Person1: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...
Person2: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I...  It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?
Person1: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that?  I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...

When I wouldn't see ya for six months to a year at a time, did you ever get your shit about it? No, it was always "OK", "No problem", "You're a busy guy, I understand". The whole time you were a drunk, did I ever point my finger at you and talk shit? No! Everybody else did. I never did. You see, I know that you're just a bad parent. You're not really very good at it. But I know you love me. I'm basically a pretty resourceful guy. If I didn't really need it I wouldn't ask. And if you say no, don't worry about it. I'm gone. No problems.

Person1: Let me worry about that, Major. I've still got my red line to the Air Command.
Person2: That's right, sir.
Person1: We don't want to be vulnerable to saboteurs calling up and pretending to be different people from the President down, do we?
Person2: You're right, sir.
Person1: No calls from inside out.  No calls from outside in are even answered.  No calls.
Person2: I understand, sir.  Nothing comes or goes without your personal say-so.
Person1: No calls at all.  With or without my say-so. My voice can be imitated too, Major.
Person2: Yes, sir.  I just thought of something, sir.  How do I know I'm talking to you now?
Person1: Who do you think you're talking to?
Person2: To you, sir.  But how do I know?
Person1: Are you trying to be insubordinate?
Person2: No, sir.
Person1: I hope not.  Now, as soon as you do what I told you, have Plan-R radioed to the Wing.
Person2: Plan-R????
Person1: Are you hard of hearing, Major?
Person2: No, sir.  Plan-R to be radioed to the Wing.
Person1: As soon as you've done that, shut down the communications center.  Lock it up and assign the personnel to base security details.
Person2: General Ripper, if I shut down the communi- cations center, there'll be no radio or teleprinter contact with Air Command head- quarters or anyone, for that matter.
Person1: Are you questioning my orders, Major?
Person2: No, sir.  I'm just bringing the facts to your attention, sir.
Person1: You're a good officer, Major, and you're perfectly right to bring these facts to my attention.
Person2: Thank you, sir.
Person1: Now, as soon as you've done that, double- up on all base security teams.  Our enemies are plenty smart, and there might even be an attack on the base by saboteurs.
Person2: Yes, sir.
Person1: And lastly, all privately owned radios are to be immediately impounded.  They can be used to issue instructions to saboteurs. Air Police will have lists of all owners.

Person1: You've always been so good to Li Mu Bai and me.  Please accept our thanks.

Person2: When it comes to emotions, even great heroes can be idiots.  Tell me if Li Mu Bai is not more open the next time you see him.  I'll give him an earful!

Person1: Yes there is.  I felt it this morning when I brought you the coffee.

Person1: How stale last night's gaiety looks! It has the taste of a dead cigarette.
Person2: If you were encouraged to come here by our meeting last night I am afraid you misunderstood my attitude.
Person1: Don't worry, you were quite rude enough.  Do you mind if I let in a little fresh air and sunshine? I'm sure it will make you feel better and I want you to be at your very best. In full possession of your faculties, at least.

Person2: Well, whatta you mean? I mean, it's perfectly fine out here. I mean, Tony's very nice and, uh, well, I meet people and I go to parties and- and we play tennis. I mean, that's... that's a very big step for me, you know?  I mean...  I'm able to enjoy people more.

Person2: What's so great about New York? I mean, it's a dying city. You read "Death in Venice."

Person2: That's right, that's right.  You only gave me books with the word "death" in the titles.

Person2: Alvy, you're incapable of enjoying life, you know that? I mean, your life is New York City. You're just this person. You're like this island unto yourself.
Person1: I can't enjoy anything unless I... unless everybody is. I-you know, if one guy is starving someplace, that's... you know, I-I... it puts a crimp in my evening.  So wanna get married or what?
Person2: No. We're friends. I wanna remain friends.
Person1: Okay.  Check, please. Can I -can I... Can I... Can I...
Person2: You're mad, aren't you?
Person1: No.  Yes, of course I'm mad, because you love me, I know that.
Person2: Alvy, I can't say that that's true at this point in my life. I really just can't say that that's true. I mean, you know how wonderful you are. I mean, you know... you're the reason that I got outta my room and that I was able to sing, and-and- and, you know, get more in touch with my feelings and all that crap. Anyway, look, I don't wanna- Listen, listen, listen, uh  h'h, so whatta you up to anyway, huh?
Person1: The usual, you know. Uh, tryin' t' write. I'm workin' on a play.  Jesus. So whatta yuh saying? That you're not comin' back to New York with me?

It's a natural inclination.  But for I, this isn't a fantasy, it is reality! You are on my planet!  You walk around the corner for coffee, out of my sight, you do not exist!  The lives of shmoes like you have meaning only in relation to the rich, to the powerful, to ME!

Person1: How were things between you and Frank?

Person1: But he was just another feller, wasn't he?

Person1: Though nicer than most?
Person2: Yes. I can't help the way I am.
Person1: Why'd you see him so regular?
Person2: Once a week?
Person1: I call that regular.
Person2: He was gentlemanly. I like that.
Person1: Once a week you like a gentleman?
Person2: Look, I'm me, right. You're not. We are what we are, like it or not.  Why all the bloody needle?
Person1: What was bugging Frank?
Person2: He wanted me to leave Dave and marry him. Last Friday I told him it wouldn't work. Dave would have killed us both!  He followed me home and kicked up a stink in the street,  I had to tell Frank I couldn't see him any more. It was getting too dodgy. That was on Sunday.  He said he'd kill himself. I was frightened what you might do.

Person1: How you doing, baby?  My name is Prince Mubutu from Nigeria.

Person1: San Juan!  You must know my good friend Pedro Martinez Hernandez Hector Elizondo.
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: I'm sorry, you looked like you traveled in the best circles.  But hey, I understand.  Make yourself at home, Isabella.  Champagne, caviar, whatever you want.  My ship is your ship.
Person2: This is your ship?

Person2: El Capitan?
Person1: I don't want to play games with you, Isabella.  I like you.  I can see myself with you -- in one of those bathrooms over there in about five minutes.
Person2: Well, I'm very tempted.  It's such a beautiful yacht.  What's it called?
Person1: Called?  What's my ship called?  Well...it's called the S.S. Minnow Johnson.
Person2: The S.S. Minow Johnson.  Funny, the name on the back was "Red Dragon."
Person1: Red Dragon?  You sure about that?
Person2: I'm sure, because this is my friend's yacht.  And it's his party.
Person1: Your friend's ship?  Oh, man.  I must've walked onto the wrong yacht.  I knew there was a reason my keys didn't work.

Person1: No. No. No. It's what my father said to me. He said it and he meant it... He said to me...He said, Adam, he said...He told me and I heard him... he said...  Hell he said so many Goddamn things I can't remember everything he said for Christsake.

Person1: It's a job.  I keep banker's hours.  I set dinner on the dining room sideboard at six.  You can serve yourselves.  Breakfast is ready at nine.  I don't wait on people.  I don't stay after dinner.  Not after it begins to get dark.  I leave before dark comes.  We live in town.  Nine miles.  So there won't be anyone around if you need help.  We couldn't even hear you, in the night.
Person2: Why would we --
Person1: -- no one could.  No one lives any nearer than town.  No one will come any nearer than that.  In the night.  In the dark.

Person1: Within no time, everything was set in place. We got rid of the freelance scamsters. The per was way up.  The gods were happy, or as happy as the gods can ever be.  And I, I decided to complicate my life. For a guy who likes sure things, I was about to bet the rest of my life on a real longshot.
Person1: We're not getting any younger. Don't you think it's time? Aren't you gettin' tired of all this shit? Bangin' around, hustlin' around?
Person2: What, are you trying to handicap me?
Person1: I'm gonna do you one better. I'm trying to marry you. You want to marry me?  I'm serious. I mean, I - I want to settle down. I want a family.
Person2: You got the wrong girl, Sam.
Person1: I know I'd be a good father. I know you'd be a good mother.
Person2: You don't know me. What, you've known me, two, three months. What do you know?
Person1: I'm forty-three years old. I don't want to wait. I know you well enough to know that I really love you very much.  And I can't think of anybody better to be with. And I don't feel like waiting anymore.
Person2: You know a lot of happily married people, Sam? 'Cause I don't.
Person1: Yeah, I know all that.
Person2: I care about you, a - But I just don't have those kind of feelings for you. I'm sorry. I'm not in love with you.
Person1: I - I - I...
Person2: Understand?  I'm sorry.
Person1: No, I - I... mean...  that can grow as I - as long as there's a mutual respect... that kind of thing can grow. I'm realistic. I can accept that. But, you know, what is... What is love anyway?  It's a... it's a mutual respect. It's - it's a devotion. It's a... it's a caring from one person to another. And if we could set up some kind of foundation...  based on that mutual respect...  I feel that eventually you would care enough about me... that I could live with that.
Person2: If it doesn't work out. You know, if it doesn't play out, then what happens to me?
Person1: You know I'm doin' well now. And I'm gonna do even better. And so, whatever happens, if it doesn't work out between us, I'm gonna make sure you're okay for the rest of your life. And if there are kids, especially, you know, I'll take care of you better than you'd ever imagine.
Person2: What're you... what're you pitching me, here?
Person1: Just what I said. You'll be set up for the rest of your life. That I can promise you.  Want to take a chance?

Person1: Oh please, who do you think you're kidding? And where did she spy on the Russians from, here in Pennsylvania??

Person1: He was curious from birth - premature by two weeks, as if he couldn't wait to get started.

Person2: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?

Person1: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave...  Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria.

Person2: Leave me alone.

Person1: Well, Miss Henried, what a coincidence. You're just in time fer a case that seems ta concern you. Guess you didn't care about the other proceedin's we been dealin' with here this mornin'.

Person1: Well, you managed ta make it here jus' in time fer this case, didn't ya?

Person1: Alright, now tell me. What is it?
Person2: There are opportunities in life for gaining knowledge and experience. Sometimes, in some cases, it's necessary to take a risk. I got to thinking. I'll bet a person could learn a lot by getting into that woman's apartment, you know, sneak in and hide and observe.
Person1: You said it was a strange world. And you're the strangest part of it. Are you crazy? She is possibly involved in murder. This gives me the creeps.
Person2: Settle down. I have a plan which I think will work. There is very little for you to do, but I do need your help. Aren't you curious about my plan?
Person1: It wouldn't hurt to hear the plan, I guess.
Person2: Alright. the first thing is to get into her apartment and open a window that I could crawl into later.
Person1: Now, how are you going to do that?
Person2: Right out in the car I happen to have some old overalls and a bug spraying rig. I will go to her apartment and be the pest control man. I will spray her apartment. After a few minutes you will knock on her door, drawing her attention away from me and I will then jimmy a window.
Person1: What will I say when she comes to the door?
Person2: You will be a Jehovah's Witness. I have a few "Awake" magazines for you. You don't have to keep her very long. A few seconds is all I'll need. Whatiya think?
Person1: I don't know, it sounds like a good daydream, but actually doing it is too weird. Too dangerous.
Person2: Let's just try the first part. If that goes well, we'll see about the rest. No one will suspect us, because no one would believe two people like us would be crazy enough to do something like this.
Person1: You've got a point there.

Person1: It's a miracle she's not dead!
Person2: We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape...
Person1: Jean, it's... it's not so easy...
Person2: But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her...
Person1: Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?
Person2: No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

Person1: I'm sorry I'm late, but something happened.

Person1: When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.

Person2: Just myself.

You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!

Person2: I'm not sure yet. I've had a shock recently, and I'm only beginning to get over it. Perhaps I'll go back to the convent one day.

Person1: Tell them I'm keeping what's left. I earned it.  I probably killed some poor bastard for it.

Person2: You won't shoot me.  That's not your style.

Person2: Do you have to point that?

Person2: He seems to be headed for Topanga.
Person1: I'm not trying to lose them.  Nor am I exceeding any speed limits.
Person2: The one thing you don't want is to attract the police.
Person1: Granted, the cops are not an alternative.  Certainly not with one of their own still locked in my trunk.
Person2: I don't hear him moving around anymore.
Person1: Those shots your associates got off may not have done him too much good.  That's on their head.  All I did I was put him there.
Person2: A typical mess-up.

Person2: Oh no, you were too busy trying to keep some Croatian from slapping the shit out of his girlfriend. She showed her gratitude by almost taking your eye out with her spiked heel.

Person2: Naturally you didn't learn your lesson.
Person1: I guess I ought to stop seeing woman as victims.

Person2: Aren't you?

Person2: Can't we really go home?  I can't breathe. Aren't you dying for green, anything green, or rain, wouldn't you die to feel rain on your face? It's Christmas and it's all - I don't know - if you asked me I'd go home tomorrow.  If you wanted.
Person1: Sweetheart, you know we can't go home, there might be a war.
Person2: Geoffrey, you do so love putting on a disguise.
Person1: I do so love you.  What do you smell of?
Person2: What?

Person1: I'm supposed to be leaving on a fellowship that I worked for my entire life.  I don't even care.  I met this boy over the summer, and I, I can't see him because of this, I can't talk to him, I can't talk to my father about... I wore these clothes, I thought, I thought that if I looked right and if I acted right then someone would talk to me.  But I look awful and I feel awful, could you, could you please talk to me?  Be a little decent.
Person2: We believe that your father operates in a large pool of cash that comes from phoney billings, phoney patients.  We've been investigating him for five years.  We believe that when they die, he takes their money.
Person1: Pardon me?
Person2: Look, why don't you check it out for yourself?  See if your father fits the profile.
Person1: What's the profile?
Person2: Well, take a look around the house.  Is everything nice, but not too nice?  Are there lots of, uh, rugs, pieces of art, stereo equipment, uh, furniture, a lot of things bought with cash?  Does he give a lot of gifts?  Do the major items in your house cover around the nine thousand-dollar range?
Person1: You're trying to get me to say something, that's why you're telling me all of this.

Person2: Because he's guilty.
Person1: No, no he's not.
Person2: We have records.  We have proof.  I'm sorry to be the one to have to tell you this, but it's going to get worse.  Now, if I were you, I would take that fellowship.

Person1: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us 'that writers make choices -- at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great -- I mean, really great -- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and all the dental records and so on -- and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always... under the influence.
Person2: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence,' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence.'

Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?

Person1: Of course, I've had to make some additions for the new models, but not as many as you might think. Once you have your basic set it's then only a question of variation.

Person2: Still, I think you'd upset people and I'm not sure that's right.

The doctors said it was Pneumonia, because it happened some months later during the 'flu epidemic. The doctors told me it was Pneumonia, but I knew what it was. A victim of the modern age, poor, poor girl. Suddenly his mood changes. He wheels right up to Alex.

Person1: Peter, if you want me to run your little camping trip, there are two conditions.  First -- I'm in charge, and when I'm not around, Dieter is.  Your job is to sign the checks, tell us we're doing a good job, and open your case of scotch when we have a good day.  Second condition -- my fee.  You can keep it.  All I want in exchange for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs.  A male.  Buck only.  Why and how are my business. If you don't  like either of those conditions, you're on your own.  Go ahead and set up your camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a rex nest, for all I care.  But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas.  Okay?

Person1: You know what? I've been here since I was fourteen and I remember like yesterday when Baby Suggs, holy, came here and sat right where you are. Whiteman name of Garner brought her. He and Mr. Bodwin were good friends. That's how she got that house you all live in. Other things too.

Now, I don't want to quit these people but they can't have all my days and nights too. I got my own family needs me. It'll take some convincing but maybe you could come after supper - take care of your mama during the day, then earn a little something at night, how's that?

Person2: Weren't you afraid?
Person1: Afraid she might commit suicide?  People who commit suicide don't talk about it. That room made her happy in some strange way I couldn't understand. She lived in a world of her own fancy. She didn't always tell the truth. In fact - I'm afraid she didn't know what the truth was.  There were many things about Jacqueline I didn't understand, and yet, without understanding, I had to be with her  to see her  to touch her  in order to be happy. It's hard to explain to a youngster.
