Person1: OK. OK. Let's not fence around ... This is the situation. Some idiot somewhere in the building, some insect, confused two of our clients, B58/732 and T47/215.
Person2: B58/732, that's A. Buttle isn't it?
Person1: Christ! You do know it all!
Person2: No, no, I don't. I'm just beginning Honestly. Sorry, carry on.
Person1: Well, your A. Buttle has been confused with T47/215, an A. Tuttle. I mean, it's a joke! Somebody should be shot for that. So B58/732 was pulled in by mistake.
Person2: You got the wrong man.
Person1: I did not get the wrong man. I got the right man. The wrong man was delivered to me as the right man! I accepted him, on trust, as the right man. Was I wrong? Anyway, to add to the confusion, he died on us. Which, had he been the right man, he wouldn't have done.
Person2: You killed him?
Person1: Sam, there are very rigid parameters laid down to avoid that event but Buttle's heart condition did not appear on Tuttle's file. Don't think I'm dismissing this business, Sam. I've lost a week's sleep over it already.
Person2: I'm sure you have
Person1: There are some real bastards in this department who don't mind breaking a few eggs to make an omelette, but thank God there are the new boys like me who want to maintain decent civilized standards of terrorist eradication. We've got the upper hand for the moment, but they're waiting for us to slip up, and a little slip- up like this is just the chance they're looking for.
Person2: So how ...?
Person1: What I've got to do now is pick up Tuttle, interrogate him at the same voltage as Buttle, to the same meter reading to the last penny, and juggle the books in electrical banking.
Person2: What has Tuttle done?
Person1: We suspect him of freelance subversion.
Person2: He's a freelance subversive?
Person1: He's a compulsive heating engineer. A maverick ex-Central Service repair man with a grudge against society. Now, fortunately, we're nearly out of the wood, I think. At least we will be when I get this Layton woman under arrest.

Person1: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
Person2: This is absolute nonsense!
Person1: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
Person2: Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

Person1: Are they?  Why would they?
Person2: That's exactly my question, Jerry. Maybe I'd better show you some pictures so you can begin to understand what I am talking about.

Person1: You taught my child that I am some unsuccessful loser.  Who didn't care about her pain.
Person2: That's not wh...
Person1: You think I didn't have some harsh words for that little troublemaker? You think I couldn't figure out some sharp criticisms?
Person2: You weren't passing 'em out.
Person1: Well, maybe your version of growing up is 'Just win, baby'.

Person1: What's the matter with you?
Person2: What right do you have to take me for granted?
Person1: What right? Do you want me to tell you?
Person2: Has it ever occurred that I may have a life of my own? That there may be some girl I'm crazy about?
Person1: Who? Some car hop, or a dress extra?
Person2: Why not? What I'm trying to say is that I'm all wrong for you. You want a Valentino -- somebody with polo ponies -- a big shot --
Person1: What you're trying to say is that you don't want me to love you.  Is that it?

Person1: You're grounded 'till you're fifty!
Person2: You're over reacting!
Person1: Make that sixty and I'm docking your allowance for two weeks.
Person2: MOM!
Person1: You think this is easy for me? You go out on the town and I get to be the bad guy. Look I don't want you to be some punk hoodlum delinquent but I can't do my job as a parent if you don't do your job as a kid.

Person1: You're strapped into an implant chair, and I'm monitoring you at a psycho-probe console.
Person2: Oh, I get it; I'm dreaming!  And this is all part of that delightful vacation your company sold me.
Person1: Not exactly.  What you're experiencing is a free-form delusion based on our memory tapes.  But you're inventing it yourself as you go along.
Person2: Well, if this is my delusion, who invited you?
Person1: I've been artificially implanted as an emergency measure.  I'm sorry to tell you this, Mr. Quaid, but you've suffered a schizoid embolism. We can't snap you out of your fantasy. I've been sent in to try to talk you down.
Person2: How much is Cohaagen paying you for this?
Person1: Think about it.  Your dream started in the middle of the implant procedure. Everything after that--the chases, the trip to Mars, your suite here at the Hilton--these are all elements of your Rekall Holiday.  And Ego Trip. You paid to be a secret agent.
Person2: Bullshit.  It's all coincidence.
Person1: What about the girl?  Brunette, athletic, sleazy and demure; just like you specified.  Is that a coincidence?
Person2: She's real.  I dreamed about her before I even went to Rekall.
Person1: Mr. Quaid, can you hear yourself? "She's real because you dreamed her?"
Person2: That's right.

Person1: Mr. President, Hunt wants more money. Another hundred-and-thirty thousand.
Person2: Son of a bitch.
Person1: He says if he doesn't get it right away, he's going to blow us out of the water.  And he means it.  Ever since his wife died in the plane crash, he's been over the edge.
Person2: Pay him.  Pay him what he wants.

Person1: You promised you'd meet projections, Alan.  A dollar sixty per share you said.  So, I don't think this is so surprising a visit.
Person2: Projections were far too optimistic.
Person1: Admittedly...
Person2: Our E.P.S. was one fifty last quarter.  We're up eight cents per share.
Person1: But, the expectation was ten.  And, in this case, expectation is everything.
Person2: Will you really hold me to it over pennies?
Person1: My stock's falling.  Isn't yours? Those pennies are costing me millions.
Person2: The stock will turn.
Person1: It probably will.  In fact, I'd go so far as to say it almost certainly will, in time.  Why should I settle for that?
Person2: Because it's fair.  Give me next quarter.  If you still feel this way, vote your shares...
Person1: You're talking tomorrow.  Today is what counts.
Person2: You intractable son-of-a-bitch.  If your father could see you now...
Person1: What?
Person2: Your father was a friend.  Goddamn it... I watched you grow up.  How do you end up treating me like this?

Person1: Break my neck.  Or strangle me.  It would be oh so easy to wrap your hands around my neck and choke the life out of me.  Please, Clayton. We've come this far.
Person2: You're crazy.

Person1: Come on, Ma.
Person2: Let's remember how I got into this. "Please, Eddie, do this for me. I can't get a break."
Person1: You know what your problem is?
Person2: Yeah. My problem is I've got a brother who writes a sentence like "We grew up in a small, little bedroom." As opposed to a big, little bedroom?
Person1: I got paid by the word! No! Your problem is you don't ever want anything to be your fault.
Person2: Me?! That's you!
Person1: I commit. I take a chance. You wanted to be the guy on TV, but you didn't want to say you wanted to. So you have me talk you into it so you get what you want, but if it goes bad it's not your fault.

Person1: I cannot ignore the verdict of my council.
Person2: Surely you can do anything you want.

Person1: I hope you're still alive, Jean Luc.
Person2: I am.
Person1: Don't you think it's time to surrender? I'll have my cloak back in a matter of minutes and your poor ship is shot to pieces. Why should the rest of your crew have to die?

Person1: Christ, Michael - what the hell are we doing...?  We don't even know -
Person2: Is this the part where you try and talk yourself out of how good this is...?
Person1: I'm serious.  You don't -
Person2: Let's see...  Next you tell me all the terrible things about you - and prove that we're doomed to fail - right...?   you hate kittens and puppies, you've drivin all your lovers to suicide --and those mysterious deaths at the hospital were really -
Person1: Stop it.
Person2: You stop it.  you're loving, and gentel..  You're the most remarkable woman I've ever met --- so stop telling me I don't know what I feel just cause you're scared.  Cause it won't work.

Person1: Little miss, don't you never come here alone. You gave me a fright, you did.
Person2: But she's such a nice lady.
Person1: But I don't want you coming here alone. You get me to go with you when you want to come here. You promise?

Person1: You see, when you travel, everything is small, self-contained--
Person2: The spork.  I get it.  You're very clever.
Person1: Thank you.
Person2: How's that working out for you?
Person1: What?
Person2: Being clever.
Person1: Well, uh... great.
Person2: Keep it up, then.  Keep it right up.

Person1: I was a great dancer...
Person2: A strange collection. You're like the false god you worship... fallen angels, all of you.
Person1: Life has betrayed us. We've found there is no heaven on earth, so we must worship evil for evil's own sake. We're not wicked. We commit no violence, unless...
Person2: Unless what?
Person1: No, you draw no secrets from me, as you drew them from Jacqueline. You are not one of us yet. You're clever, Louis, but I recognize your interest in me for what it is worth. You are only curious. You have never loved a woman who had but one arm.
Person2: It would be a charming experience. She might only protest half as much.
Person1: You're very flippant and perhaps wise, but not wise enough to see the truth, Louis.

Person1: Now could you leave me alone?
Person2: Yeah.  Oh, one more thing. Tammy. You know, all this election stuff. 'Cause, you know, everyone is saying it's so weird that you're running against me, and, well, it is kind of weird, and you haven't really told me why you're doing it and didn't tell me in advance or anything.  But that's okay, you know.  l respect your privacy.  I just want you to know that no matter who wins, if it's you or me, there's no hard feelings. We're still brother and sister.  Okay? Cause... and I hope you feel the same.
Person1: Sure, Paul.  No hard feelings.
Person2: Okay.  Great.  I feel good.

Person1: You're a son of a bitch.
Person2: Yes--well--uh--that's another one of those statements which more or less automatically requires an apology.  Whenever you feel like it. It's sort of like turning off an alarm clock that's ringing loudly. Your apology turns off the alarm.

Person1: You said Merry Christmas, Rudy.
Person2: I... you told me your name was Rudy. You told me a million times, back in the truck, telling me you weren't Nick --
Person1: No --
Person2: You were screaming you weren't Nick! And we just didn't believe you!
Person1: But I never said Rudy.
Person2: You said it a million times!
Person1: I never told you my name.

Person1: I've been thinking about when we look for our apartment how we have to try and convince people that we're like these totally rich yuppies...
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: That's who people want to rent to. It's a known fact that it's way easier to get a job and everything if you're rich... All we have to do is buy a few semi-expensive outfits and act like it's no big deal... it'll be fun.
Person2: You just want an excuse to dress like some stupid fashion model without me making fun of you.
Person1: Just promise you'll do it.
Person2: Okay, okay, I promise... Jesus, you're out of your mind.

Person1: I overheard you telling Mark that I wasn't qualified for the promotion.
Person2: That's not what I said. I mentioned that you were newer to the team.
Person1: So you're implying I don't have the experience.
Person2: You are making that up. I never said you weren't qualified. I was just discussing team dynamics.

Person1: It's all your fault. Both you little bastards. I was a fool to believe you would bring me any peace. The day your Da left us when you were almost too young to remember, he said the two of you would do me right and make me proud, but he was wrong and I got nothin' ta live for.
Person2: Mother, what are you sayin'? You're talkin' crazy here.

Person1: Get a dance yet?
Person2: Nope.
Person1: Me neither.
Person2: Who'd you ask?
Person1: Tina Wilcox.
Person2: You're crazy.  She's Ed's girl friend.
Person1: Doesn't hurt to ask.  Sometimes the most beautiful girls are the loneliest.
Person2: That's a crock of shit.
Person1: I know.

Person1: Eddie, you've got to get me out of here.
Person2: Not again.  You can't keep calling. Somebody's going to catch on to where you are.
Person1: But I'm going insane!  All these people do is pray and work, work and pray!  I don't get it -- when's the weekend? They have gruel, Eddie, that's what they call food!  Gruel -- it's like Alpo for nuns! I sleep in a cell, on a board, and I pray five times a days  Do you know what I pray for, Eddie, do you have any idea? Check your crotch, Eddie --anything fall off yet?  Get me outta her!
Person2: Calm down.  Look, I didn't want to tell you this, but we've had some problems with our protection program lately.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Keeping our witnesses alive.  We hide them, but there's a leak in the department, and they end up dead.
Person1: You son-of-a-bitch!

Person1: I asked him what was so important for him. "True love," he replied. And then he spoke of a girl of surpassing beauty and faithfulness. I can only assume he meant you. You should bless me for destroying him before he found out what you really are.
Person2: And what am I?
Person1: Faithfulness he talked of, madam. Your enduring faithfulness. Now, tell me truly. When you found out he was gone, did you get engaged to your prince that same hour, or did you wait a whole week out of respect for the dead?
Person2: You mocked me once, never do it again -- I died that day!

Person1: Can I come out?  No.
Person2: I have to talk to you, alone, J.J., that's why.
Person1: You had something to do for me - you didn't do it.
Person2: Can I come in for a minute?
Person1: No.  You're dead, son - get yourself buried!

Person1: You don't think she'd be raped if she were captured?  You don't think the threat of rape would be used to leverage the men?
Person2: You broke a dozen training rules back there -- before I lost count.
Person1: I've had it.  Just because they pay me like a baby-sitter doesn't mean I'm gonna be one.
Person2: She's a trainee, just like the others.  Why are you coming down so hard?
Person1: She's an officer.  There's a higher standard.
Person2: She's a women, and that's why you're ridin' her bareback.
Person1: Of course it is.  And I'm gonna stay on her until everyone realizes this is not some bullshit equal-rights thing, that real lives are gonna be lost.  Maybe mine, maybe yours.
Person2: I oughtta report you.
Person1: I think you probably would -- if you didn't know I was right.

Person1: Well, get me and Chris a drink then.
Person2: I'll get the drinks, but not here. Let's split. I can't stand this any more, it's murdering my respect for literature.
Person1: But I don't want to go, I am enjoying it.
Person2: How about you Brutus?

Person1: There's a guard outside my door! I'm a prisoner, Nigel!  Do you understand that?
Person2: Dr. Argon would say we are all prisoners.
Person1: Argon is a lunatic!  I can't believe I was stupid enough to believe I could control him.  You heard what he said, Nigel.  He doesn't care if all of Calumet City is turned to Jell-O.  How can that not affect you?
Person2: Because I am a new man, Susan.  I am a man of vision.  Your problem, Susan, is that you're always looking down.  If you'd just look up you'd see the big picture and in the big picture men of vision do not dwell on what might be lost.  They focus on what can be gained.
Person1: Is that what Argon told you?
Person2: No!  Well, not those exact words.
Person1: Nigel, can't you see he's using you?
Person2: Of course he is, but at least there isn't a security guard outside my door.
Person1: You're afraid of him.
Person2: Who isn't?

Person1: Yes, well, I awoke to discover I'd turned into a cat. If you don't do as I say, I'll sink my little fangs into your drumsticks, and suck the marrow straight out of your bones.
Person2: At your service, Count.
Person1: Now give the signal.

Person1: Yes, and I've read it.  You wake up every night, sheets soaking, the same nightmare over and over...
Person2: No!  The answer is no.  Now please go.  I'm sorry.  Just go, would you.

Person1: You killed Domini, didn't you, witch??
Person2: I'm not a witch, you're all crazy!

Person1: You really like that bitch don't you? I gotta tell you, I was pretty convinced that the whole thing before was blowing her off for her cut. You know how it is, get her to do some shit for you, throw her a bang to keep her happy. But, if you're into her... That's cool.
Person2: That's what I like about you, Lupus. You're a free thinker. Don't let the King tell you different.

Person1: YOU still want to go to Asgaard?
Person2: Of course.
Person1: Do you believe I love you?
Person2: I... but I...
Person1: You don't have to love me. Just, do you believe I love YOU?
Person2: Yes -- I believe you do.
Person1: Then let go!

Person1: What is the first and principal thing he does, what need does he serve by killing?
Person2: Anger, social resentment, sexual frus-
Person1: No, he covets. That's his nature. And how do we begin to covet, Clarice? Do we seek out things to covet? Make an effort to answer.
Person2: No. We just -
Person1: No. Precisely. We begin by coveting what we see every day. Don't you feel eyes moving over your body, Clarice? I hardly see how you couldn't. And don't your eyes move over the things you want?
Person2: All right, then tell me how -
Person1: No. It's your turn to tell me, Clarice. You don't have any more vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island. Why did you run away from that ranch?
Person2: Dr. Lecter, when there's time I'll -
Person1: We don't reckon time the same way, Clarice. This is all the time you'll ever have.
Person2: Later, listen, I'll -
Person1: I'll listen now. After your father's murder, you were orphaned. You were ten years old. You went to live with cousins, on a sheep and horse ranch in Montana. And - ?
Person2: And - one morning I just - ran away...

Person1: Talking to me, dad?
Person2: Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!
Person1: Well, then forget all this stern dad stuff.
Person2: I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home.

Person1: Well, keep going! We want an extra out on the streets before it's too late!
Person2: Where's Bruce?
Person1: Bruce? Oh -- er -- he went out to get the tickets.
Person2: What tickets?
Person1: Railroad tickets.
Person2: Is he coming back here?
Person1: Didn't you hear him? Of course he's coming back here. Keep going, will you?

Person1: Mrs. Mulwray, do you love your husband?
Person2: ...Yes of course.
Person1: Then go home and forget about it.
Person2: But...
Person1: I'm sure he loves you, too. You know the expression, let sleeping dogs lie? You're better off not knowing.
Person2: But I have to know.

Person1: That only leaves the rest.
Person2: You don't have any baggy shorts? Pajama bottoms?
Person1: Sorry.  My pajamas are tailored. Would it be too distressing to continue with the towel?  No more immodest than a kilt, you know.
Person2: Do I have any other choice?
Person1: Very sporting of you, Clayton.

Person1: He has to look here or I won't get a clear shot.  Call him, Margo.
Person2: I can't!
Person1: You have to.  Do it now!

Person1: Inflamed joints -- Walkin' in an' out of a freezer carryin' meat plays hell on the joints.
Person2: Maybe ya should see a doctor.
Person1: I don't need a doctor, I need a different job.
Person2: Maybe another job is the best thing.
Person1: Do me a favor -- Talk to Gazzo. Tell him I'm a friend an' would do a good job... Tell him I ain't bothered by nothin' an' would be a great collector... Bustin' bones don't bother me -- Tell him I'm a good worker.
Person2: Gazzo's gotta come to you.
Person1: I'm askin' ya to go to him -- As a favor.
Person2: Gazzo's gotta come to you -- Hey, Paulie, it's a bad job -- Do what you do now.

Person1: Gone--  --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got his notice to get off.
Person2: But what's happened?  How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.
Person1: Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks.  Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.
Person2: But who done it?
Person1: Listen!  That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.
Person2: Are you crazy?
Person1: Some say I am.  You want to hear what happened?
Person2: That's what I asked you, ain't it?

Person1: What do you mean get back?
Person2: Well, obviously, we got to go back.
Person1: Bob, that makes no sense.
Person2: Dignan, he's my brother. I can't just leave him there.
Person1: This could be a trap.
Person2: Come on, Dignan.
Person1: Don't "Come on, Dignan" me.
Person2: I'm going back.
Person1: Not in that car you're not.
Person2: Watch me.
Person1: Good luck, since I got the keys.

Person1: Everything's going exactly as we planned.
Person2: Not quite. You haven't announced our engagement yet.
Person1: It must have slipped my mind.
Person2: Your mind is so slippery.
Person1: Don't worry, Pootchkie. My womanizing days are over. You're my Lady Macbeth, my Imelda... my Nicole.  We're such an incredible team. Who could possibly stop us?

Person1: Listen, is this your idea of a joke?
Person2: More of a game really.
Person1: What kind of a game?
Person2: You seem to be familiar with the STAB movies. Here's how we play. I ask you a question. You get it right, your girlfriend lives. You answer wrong, she dies.
Person1: I swear to God if you lay a finger on her I'll kill you!
Person2: Maybe so, but right now, we play the game. First question, Your girlfriend's counting on you, Name your girlfriend's character in STAB 2?

Person1: You watch yours, soldier, or my worker friend will beat you up!
Person2: Oh, that's okay, I'll let him off this time.  Are you crazy?  This guy's built like a pebble!  You know they do great prosthetic antennas nowadays --
Person1: Aren't you gonna stand up for yourself?

Person1: Dislocated collar bone.  If any more tendons snap...  It wont just be two weeks out of action.
Person2: I need you to pass me fit now, Molly.

Person1: Chopin prelude.  Stodgy, but nice.  Here's the deal.  I didn't want you involved in this.  Still breathing? But now that you are, we have to make the best of it, Max.  Improvise.  Life is that way.  Adapt to your environment.  Survive.  Darwin.  "Shit happens."  The I Ching.  Whatever. Roll with it.
Person2: I Ching?  You threw a man out a window!
Person1: I didn't throw him, he fell.
Person2: What'd he do to you?
Person1: Nothing.  I only met him the one time.
Person2: How can you kill him like that?
Person1: I should only kill people after I get to know 'em?  Six billion people on the planet, you're getting bent out of shape 'cause of one fat guy?
Person2: Who was he?
Person1: What do you care?  Ever hear of Rwanda?
Person2: Rwanda-Burundi.  Central Africa.
Person1: Tens of thousands killed before sundown.  Nobody's killed that fast since Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Did you bat an eye, Max?  Join Amnesty International?  No.  I off one Angeleno, you throw a hissy fit...

Person1: How come you don't hate their guts?
Person2: I don't know. I guess I'm not afraid of them.
Person1: You were plenty scared that night in the car.
Person2: Just of getting hurt. They can't touch me inside.
Person1: Like hell they can't.  They can reach right in with their damn white hands and turn you off and on.
Person2: Not if you see them for what they are, Duff.
Person1: Jesus, baby, you're so full of talk! Well, you ain't never really been a nigger, have you - livin' like that in your father's house! So just shut your mouth.

Person1: Ahh-hem! Now, Rose, get off my lap. What are you doing, girl? Are you crazy?
Person2: Yes, crazy about you! Kiss me, Mr. Hillyer!
Person1: Why, I'm not going to kiss you, you crazy girl. Now I'm telling you again, get off my lap. Come on, Rose, get up. Now you get up, I say, and stop this!
Person2: No, no! You don't understand, I love you! It's real love and I can't help it! Please kiss me, Mr. Hillyer, I love you, I love you so much...

Person1: But if you're one of the misfits... that's where I come in.
Person2: I didn't say that I would run... I just...
Person1: Are you a 5 or a 6?
Person2: Six. I go red next year.
Person1: You're years away... I don't know why you're thinking of these things, much less talking about them.  Want to try?

Person1: I'm out here for you!  You don't know what it's like to be me out here for you. It is an up-at-dawn pride-swallowing seige that I will never fully tell you about! Okay?! Help me help you help me help you.
Person2: You're hanging by a very thin thread, dude.  And I dig that about you.

Person1: Come on, Ellie. Stop being silly. You know I'm going to have my way.
Person2: I won't stand for it! I won't stand for your running my life! Why do you insist on it!
Person1: You ought to know why. Because
Person2: Yes. I know.  Because I'm your daughter and you love me. Because you don't want me to make any mistakes. Because
Person1: Because marrying that fool King Westley is
Person2: You're wasting your time. I'm already married to him.
Person1: Not so far as I'm concerned, you're not.  Yes?

Person1: It must be the most marvelous supper. We may not eat it, but it must be marvelous.
Person2: Yes, Baron.
Person1: And, waiter--you see that moon?
Person2: Yes, Baron.
Person1: I want to see that moon in the champagne.
Person2: Yes, Baron.  Moon in champagne.
Person1: I want to see--
Person2: Yes, Baron.
Person1: And as for you, waiter--
Person2: Yes, Baron?
Person1: I don't want to see you at all!
Person2: No, Baron!  I beg your pardon.
Person1: Thank you.

Person1: Mookie, I always liked you.  Not the smartest kid, but you're honest. Don't make me dislike you.
Person2: Sal, I want my money.
Person1: Don't even ask about your money. Your money wouldn't even pay for that window you smashed.
Person2: Forget a window, Radio Raheem is dead.
Person1: You're right, a kid is dead, but Mook, this isn't the time.
Person2: Forget that. The time is now. You know I'm sorry 'bout Sal's Famous Pizzeria, but I gotta live, too. I gotta get paid.
Person1: We both do.
Person2: We all know you're gonna get over with the insurance money anyway! Ya know da deal.
Person1: Do we now?
Person2: Quit bullshitting.
Person1: You don't know shit about shit.

Person1: I'm not an intellectual.... I mean, I read, but... Fund-raising isn't what I...
Person2: Look, if you want to kill Jews on your free time, fine. We need you to raise money. Will you do that for us?

Person1: He's not coming. I thought he was just...
Person2: Julie, you left four messages... Four.
Person1: But, he said he'd try.
Person2: He said he'd try. Try is like maybe. Try is nothing!
Person1: He does work hard.
Person2: Work hard, huh? He's breaking your heart just because he can.  And I don't want to have to say I told you so...
Person1: Then, don't.

Person1: Now listen up, Ruben.  You never, never, never mess with somebody inside the case!
Person2: Excuse me?  Excuse me?!  What do you...
Person1: You damn well better start working on that impulse control.  A woman who is implicated in this case? Someone who's practically a piece of evidence?
Person2: It's against your rules that I try to help a witness who's scared shitless?  Who's...
Person1: The woman's unstable.  You could wind up with a harassment charge. Anything.  You're like some horny little teenager.

Person1: Your expenses are your own.
Person2: I thought Latisha said you would --
Person1: -- she didn't know what she was talking about --
Person2: It's....whatever....that's not cool.
Person1: David, Don't. Just. Seriously. It doesn't make sense if you think about it in a fair deal like sense. Ok? It's business. Seriously. One hundred dollars for two days work is a lot more than your family is making sitting around your house. I'm serious now. Ok. Please. Now. Just stop.

Person1: You can go get your stuff right now. I'll walk you down.
Person2: No, that's not, I couldn't...
Person1: Listen, when someone does the kind of thing you did, you gotta do something in return. So, you stay with me until you find your David and live happily ever after. Okay?

Person1: I love you.
Person2: Right.  That's why you tried to kill me.
Person1: Nooo!  I would never do anything to hurt you.  I want you to come back to me.
Person2: Bullshit.

Person1: Um... Harry?  Did I ever keep the books here?
Person2: No, your mother did, then I did after she passed.
Person1: Well, I'm the first one to admit that I don't know anything about bookkeeping, but there are some very interesting things in here.

Person1: You're back.
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: I'm glad. Seriously... I'm very glad.
Person2: Angela, I just heard Sal was alive.
Person1: Sure. Why not.
Person2: Where? Where is he?
Person1: Nick, he's fine. He's in a hospital and they're fixing him up.
Person2: You talk to him?
Person1: Oh, sure... Twice a day.

Person1: I have good news for you, Mr. Cosgrove.  The firm of Bracegirdle and Chatwick, in the city of London, are prepared to lend you 20,000 pounds, pledged against your interest in the Edric mines.  They will redeem the encumbrances against the property, which amount to some 10,000 pounds, and take a twenty- year working lease on the mines. They will lend you the 20,000 pounds against the lease income, which they will apply to the loan as it comes in, and they will make a charge of 18% per annum interest on the outstanding loan balance.
Person2: Mr. Newcombe, I have made some difficult loans during the past few years, at very onerous terms, but 18% a year interest seems very stiff indeed.
Person1: Considering your financial circumstances, Mr. Cosgrove, it has been impossible to find anyone at all prepared to do any business with you.  I think you may count yourself lucky to have this opportunity. But, obviously, if you would reject this offer, I shall keep trying to find a better one.
Person2: I am prepared to accept the terms, Mr. Newcombe.
Person1: There are a few other points we should discuss.  The loan agreement can only be executed by her ladyship's signature, and provided that Bracegirdle and Chatwick can be assured of her ladyship's freewill in giving her signature.
Person2: Provided that they can be assured of her ladyship's freewill?  Are you serious?
Person1: May I be quite frank with you?
Person2: Yes, of course.
Person1: Mister Bracegirdle said to me that he had heard her ladyship lives in some fear of her life, and meditated a separation, in which case, she might later repudiate any documents signed by herself while in durance, and subject them, at any rate, to a doubtful and expensive litigation. They were quite insistent on this point, and said they must have absolute assurance of her ladyship's perfect freewill in the transaction before they would advance a shilling of their capital.
Person2: I see.
Person1: When I asked them in what form they would accept her ladyship's assurances, they said that they were only prepared to accept them if her ladyship confirms her written consent by word of mouth, in their presence, at their counting-house in Birchin Lane, London.  I requested they come here, and save her ladyship and yourself the inconvenience of the trip to London, but they declined, saying that they did not wish to incur the risk of a visit to Castle Hackton to negotiate, as they were aware of how other respectable parties, such as Messrs. Sharp and Salomon had been treated here.

You try flogging the stories on CNN I've had to come up with about what's been going on around here the last few days.  At any rate, it's been most instructive -- what they'll swallow, or what they'll broadcast with a straight face.  Miss Hall's blood, it appears, has absolutely no elements of the Chimera virus.  Not even antibodies.

Person2: Did I?  Or was that you?  When you were hiding in the bathroom -- all conspiratorially like you were -- you became frightened, didn't you?  Terrified.  Like you were with the snake earlier -- and suddenly you have snakes slithering all over the floor.  You did that, Norman.
Person1: You're insane.
Person2: Am I?  Or am I making so much sense that you're going insane?

Person2: You don't remember you did.  But I'm sure you remember running like some hero to get Harry, don't you?  You remember that.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: You remember before you picked him up -- when you looked up at the sphere, you remember that -- when the sphere opened?  That's right.  But you can't remember going inside, can you?  No, of course not.  Harry couldn't either, could he?  "Like everything's on the tip of my tongue", he said.
Person1: That's nonsense.
Person2: Is it?
Person1: Beth, the message said Harry.  "My name is Harry".  My name isn't Harry.
Person2: No, it isn't.  Your name is Norman. But your younger brother -- what was his name?  The one who was stung when you were younger.  The one that died. The one you couldn't save.  What was his name?  "Mommy, we're going out to the ocean -- to go swimming." "But I don't want to go swimming, Norman.  I'm scared." "C'mon, Harry, it'll be fine, it'll be fun."  You heartless fuck.  That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?
Person1: Stop it, Beth --
Person2: When you were in that sub -- and that squid was attacking you -- are you sure it was the squid that was attacking?  Do you know?  "I can't get Beth on the radio.  I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the ocean.  All alone.  Surrounded by all this water." Was it really the squid that was attacking you, Norman -- or was it something else -- one of your fears?  You never really saw what it was, did you?

Person1: Bent.

Person1: Oh lord. You think I'm so dense. And now you want to be seen with your dense wife at the cocktail party. You want to wear that ridiculous shirt which doesn't go with those pants at all. You want to wear that, and you want me to shake hands with your friends and make conversation and dress up in an outfit that shows a lot of cleavage and you're not going to accord me the respect of talking honestly about this... You don't really know what this feels like.

Person1: What time have you, Gaston?
Person2: Eight forty-two, sir.
Person1: I guess it is eight forty-two.
Person2: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.
Person1: I am, Gaston.
Person2: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.
Person1: Have you?
Person2: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.
Person1: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.
Person2: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.
Person1: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!
Person2: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.
Person1: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?
Person2: No, sir.
Person1: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?
Person2: No, sir.
Person1: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?
Person2: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

Person1: Summers are short here, Annie. There isn't much of a fall. Before you know it, the roads are closed... the nights get long.

Person2: I can't do this. I can't leave you...

Person1: Brian. What's wrong?

Person2: -- Bullshit! You knew what I told you wasn't ready for the papers --

Person2: -- I work for the city.

Person1: Don't tell me I don't have a choice!
Person2: Right.

Person1: I don't need you to get the money -- my money!
Person2: If it hadn't been for me, you would be dead.

Person1: Don't you want to know where I'm going?
Person2: No.  Yes, I want to know what for. But I don't want to ask.
Person1: I'm going to Kentucky. To Louisville. With a friend. Try to make some money. I need it, the money. I'll be leaving early in the morning.
Person2: Leave now.
Person1: Oh, grow up.
Person2: Why should I?
Person1: Sarah, I'm going to Kentucky to play pool, with a guy by the name of Findley. Now, I need the action and I need the money. I told you I'd be back.
Person2: If you were going to come back you wouldn't have taken me out tonight. You wouldn't have bought this dress. You're hustling me, Eddie. You've never stopped hustling me.
Person1: Now, I never hustled you. Even when I thought I was. You know it.
Person2: What do you want me to do? Just sit here and wait? Faithful little Sarah. Pull the shades down and sit. When you feel like coming back, you'll come back. And you'll love me. And then you'll go away again. Is that your idea of love?
Person1: I got no idea of love. And neither have you. I mean, neither one of us would know what it was if we saw it coming down the street.
Person2: I'd know it, Eddie. I'd know. For God's sakes, what are you trying to do to me? I love you.
Person1: Well, what's your idea of love? Chains?
Person2: No.  I made you up, didn't I, Eddie? You weren't real. I made you up, like everything else. There was no car crash, Eddie. When I was five, I had polio. I was never an actress. The rich old man is my father. He walked out on us when I was seven. He sends me a check every month. That's how he buys his way out of my life. The men I've known... after they left, I'd say they weren't real, I made them up. But you, Eddie. I wanted you to be real.

Person1: You're rationalizing.
Person2: That's what you do to go through with the shit you start. You rationalize. I can do this, Max, I know I can. But I can't do it without you.

Person2: Shoot!

Person1: There's a tiny door in that empty office. It's a portal, Maxine. It takes you inside John Malkovich. You see the world through John Malkovich's eyes, then, after about fifteen minutes, you're spit out into a ditch on the side of The New Jersey Turnpike.
Person2: Sounds delightful. Who is John Malkovich?
Person1: He's an actor. One of the great American actors of the 20th century.
Person2: What's he been in?
Person1: Lots of things. He's very well respected. That jewel thief movie, for example. The point is that this is a very odd thing, supernatural, for lack of a better word. It raises all sorts of philosophical questions about the nature of self, about the existence of the soul. Am I me? Is Malkovich Malkovich? Was the Buddha right, is duality an illusion? Do you see what a can of worms this portal is? I don't think I can go on living my life as I have lived it. There's only one thing to do. Let's get married right away.
Person2: Is this Malkovich fellow appealing?
Person1: Yes, of course. He's a celebrity.
Person2: Good. We'll sell tickets.
Person1: Tickets to Malkovich?
Person2: Exactly. Two hundred dollars a pop.
Person1: But there's something profound here, Maxine, we can't exploit it.
Person2: Fine. I'll do it myself. I was going to offer a partnership to you, but this way it's more money for me.
Person1: You wanted to be partners with me?
Person2: Sure. It'd be fun.
Person1: Really?  But, Maxine, can of worms! End of the world! Illusory nature of existence!
Person2: I'll protect you, Dollface.

Person1: What are you doing here?
Person2: Your door was unlocked.
Person1: Still is, so let yourself out.
Person2: We need to talk.
Person1: We ain't got nothing to talk about.
Person2: I messed up, okay, I know that.  But I ain't that kid's father.
Person1: Lucky kid.
Person2: Look, I ain't saying it was right, but sometimes things happen.
Person1: And some things should never happen!
Person2: Boy, you're so perfect you can look down on me?
Person1: I ain't a damn liar.
Person2: Your mom was real quick to show you those pictures, wasn't she? Well, she was nineteen when she got pregnant and don't get me wrong, you're the best thing in my life, but she knew I wasn't ready for no marriage.
Person1: So now you're saying my mother trapped you?
Person2: I'm saying I handled my responsibilities like a man.  But when you're in the NBA, you pull into a city and there's a hundred women waiting at the hotel.  And another twenty that made it past security on your floor.  And the boldest one is standing right at your door.  And after awhile, it just becomes part of the game.  I'm sorry I lied to you, I shouldn't have.  But I did it cause I love you.

Person1: Good book, huh?

Person2: What night?

Person1: From the club. You didn't answer.
Person2: I must have fallen asleep. I was asleep when you got home, wasn't I?

Person1: Of course, John.
Person2: Yes, they were playing the queues outside the picture palaces of Liverpool. Scruffy young lads, lacking even the price of a jam roll. Orphans, every Paddy's son of 'em. I saw their potential at once although I had me doubts about the little fella, a savage primitive, that Ringo, but it was him what gave in first. He picked up a brick and heaved it at me and I quelled him wid one fierce flash of me eyes. "Mister, can you spare us a copper?" he said. I was disarmed by the grubby little outstretched mauler ... So, I took them under me managerial banner.
Person1: The usual ten per cent?
Person2: Oh, not at all, I let them have twenty-five; sure aren't there four of them?
Person1: How fascinating. Do go on ...  ... John.
Person2: ... Oh, I'm all heart, Ma'am, all heart ... Well, I let ...

Person1: I want that cat.  I'll pay you one thousand dollars - cash.

Person2: I can't talk right now.
Person1: What do you want for it?  Two thousand? Three thousand?
Person2: No...look I'm busy...
Person1: Listen to me...I don't want to lose this piece -
Person2: I'm holding for Lieutenant Beldere!
Person1: Listen to me, listen to me...I've been collecting art pieces all over the world for years and let me tell you something.  This newcomer Walter Paisley has it, whatever it is, the X factor, that indefinable quality that separates the greats from the hacks, and I want that cat in my hands.  Are you listening to me?

Person1: 'Cause if it was me, I could just catch a Greyhound back.

Person1: Come now, Sam.  This is a gathering of old friends.  I know how difficult this must be for you -- a man of your upbringing and integrity -- but now that I'm in charge I felt it was only fair that you finally know the truth.  After all, you're the only one around here who's still in the dark, as it were.  This isn't the way I wanted to tell you, but you've really given me no other choice.
Person2: This is madness, Wynn.
Person1: Your madness is another man's greatness.  This is the way things have always been.  You've just been too blinded by your own reality to see.  But having you on the outside has been convenient for us in many ways.  You always did come through -- our loyal watch dog. Finding him. Bringing him back to us once he'd finished his work.  Although after you had that nasty stroke the last time, I had to go after him myself.  And what a terrible time we had getting him out of that jail cell.
Person2: It was you.
Person1: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.
Person2: Why did you take Jamie?
Person1: She has the gift -- the blood of Thorn running through her veins.  Michael's mother had it, too.  So for six years I incubated her, prepared her for this night.  Michael has served his purpose.  And soon we will have a new progeny.
Person2: Jamie's baby ...
Person1: There you go trying to make sense again.  It's a curse.  Handed down through countless generations. As ageless as this celebration which you call Halloween.
Person2: Samhain.
Person1: And I'm its deliverer.  Its calling card, if you will.  I follow it.  Protect it. Act as its guardian.  In a sense, Sam, so do you.

Person1: Bernie.
Person2: Well, obviously it's me, isn't it -- I work in the City in a job I don't understand and everyone keeps getting promoted above me.  I haven't had a girlfriends since... puberty and, well, the long and short of it is, nobody fancies me, and if these cheeks get any chubbier, they never will.

Person1: Take the radio, stay down here in the lobby, watch the elevator.

Person1: But I allus loved you...You know that, without my sayin' it...I couldn't bring myself to ask you to wait...the little I had... not knowin' how much longer until we found Debbie...

Person1: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge.  How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?
Person2: Kay... Kay...
Person1: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings?  He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo.  He heard Connie.
Person2: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.
Person1: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom.  It's not your best side.
Person2: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?
Person1: He's not the same as when I met him.
Person2: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow.  You'd have no problem.
Person1: What the hell does that mean?  Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life.  I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being.

Person1: Your brother stumbled upon Adoniss little secret, didnt he? And traded his silence for a kid and some cash. And Adonis fell for it, bought him his kid, sent him away, and then killed him when he came back for more.  Leon didnt come here to borrow money for prints. He came to extort a second kids life. Your flunkey let him in, so his visit couldnt be concealed, hence the exhibition story. There was no exhibition. Just as you suspected. Remember, Deborah? Leon does his own prints. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art.  I should have paid more attention to your words. Perhaps its the way you say them...
Person2: If-if my car is there, I could be the one who... Why dont you accuse me of killing my brother?
Person1: Kids are not your thing, Deborah. Youd have been ready for me when I turned up with Sleeping Beauty. Damn it! Then too I should have paid more attention. Not Leon, you said. It struck me at the time, but obviously not hard enough. You didnt say My God!, or whatever else well-bred ladies squeak on hearing Uncle Henry misbehaved. Not Leon. Who then?  You sure were right about one thing, Deborah, the job was too formidable for me. I should have thought a little more before I left for Los Angeles. But there I was focused so hard on Friedman Id stopped thinking. Nothing added up - Leon soliciting money for prints while buying kids at 15,000 a go; infiltrating the world of child traffickers; duping Friedman into selling him a little boy... You sure were right. The job was too formidable for me. But you knew that, didnt you?
Person2: Leon could still have hung himself.
Person1: Oh no. At long last Leon had found a mission. Hed never have killed himself when glory beckoned. Your husband killed your brother. And thanks to you, almost got me killed too.

What's the difference between giving me a bracelet or giving somebody else a hundred thousand dollars for a statue you're going to keep crated up and never look at?  It's only money.  It doesn't mean anything. You're not really giving anything that belongs to you, that you care about.

You're -  - it's like you were bribing me!  That's what it's been from the first moment I met you.  No matter how much it cost you - your time, your money - that's what you've done with everybody you've ever known.  Tried to bribe them!

Person2: Five years, maybe, for a trial.  Double that for the appeal.

Person1: Forget legal terms.  We're talking about human beings here.  Sick people.  A whole bunch of them are gonna be dead in ten years.  They need their money now!  We gotta get 'em to agree to the arbitration, Ed.  We gotta get every damn one of those plaintiffs to --
Person2: I know.  We're having a meeting, it's all set up --

Person2: Tuesday at seven, at the Hinkley firehouse.

Person2: You're not gonna be there.

Person2: Erin --
Person1: No, I'm serious.  You know what Kurt Potter is?  He's the kind of guy who never would have taken this case in the first place. He's the kind of guy who would have sold these plaintiffs down the river when PG&E offered 20 million.  He doesn't work like us, Ed.  There's no little voice in his head telling him to do the right thing.

Person1: You won't find it because no such telegram exists.
Person2: Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it.
Person1: Then you are wrong.
Person2: Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for?
Person1: We never, never officially represented the regime when we played abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance conductor.
Person2: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?
Person1: have no idea what ordinary people thought.
Person2: No!
Person1: No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.
Person2: Tell me about von der Null.
Person1: Von der Null?
Person2: Yes, von der Null.
Person1: Von der Null?
Person2: How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.
Person1: Yes, I know who he is.
Person2: Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
Person1: That's an outrageous lie!
Person2: You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?
Person1: Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.
Person2: And what did he say?
Person1: He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'
Person2: And what happened to Von der Nul?
Person1: I have no idea.
Person2: You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.
Person1: I'm sorry.
Person2: Now, that young conductor what's his name?  That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?

Person1: Recent hours have been a shock.

Person1: Phillippe... there is something I hope you understand.  Terrible cruelty has been used against you. And... you must understand that you did nothing to deserve it.
Person2: There is... wrath... in me.  I have learned to hide it.  Those years in the cell, I dreamed that freedom would someday just happen, the way the mask happened.  Now I am free. And with each free breath I feel the growing desire to make someone suffer for all I lost.  Look at this, all this that for ten years I could not see!  What if I become a king -- a king no different from my brother?
Person1: The desire for vengeance... can be a poison.
Person2: What is its antidote?
Person1: I suppose... it is to remember there are many people who have never been in a prison, who pass such beauty every day, and never see it.

Person1: The Matrix is everywhere, it's all around us, here even in this room. You can see it out your window or on your television.  You feel it when you go to work, or go to church or pay your taxes.  It is the world that has been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the truth.

Person1: That you are a slave, Neo.  Like everyone else, you were born into bondage, kept inside a prison that you cannot smell, taste, or touch. A prison for your mind.

I always felt lucky... a little amazed... that such a vibrant, beautiful woman would want to be with a man like me... And I guess I thought as long as I did everything right -- if I was the best husband I could be, the best father... even being a good lawyer only mattered to me because of what it meant for us... if I could do all that, it wouldn't make any difference if we loved each other the same or not... I wasn't asking for more. I told myself I didn't need more.  But you don't know how you feel about me. You don't know... if you want a life with me anymore...  And I don't want you to come home until you do know...  ... one way or the other.

They can't seem to figure out what those same two guys were doing in an Iraqi outpost.  It's almost as if they were Iraqi spies, or something. In fact, I don't even see any point in your changing hotels. Please help us, Mrs. Lampert. Your government is counting on you.

Person1: It's all kind of lost in the... in the dense mists of time now... It wasn't that I really liked Marco more.  In fact I thought you were more, shall we say, attractive than him.  It was just that he knew he was good-looking and you didn't, and that made a difference somehow.  You used to act as if I was weird for wanting to spend time with you, and that got kind of beat, if you know what I mean.  Your self-image started to rub off on me and I ended up thinking that I was strange.  And I knew that you were kind and thoughtful... you made me laugh, and I dug the way you got consumed by things you loved... and Marco seemed a bit more, I don't know, glamorous? More sure of himself?  Less hard work, because I felt like I was dragging you around, sort of.  A little sunnier.  Sparkier.  I don't know.  You know what people are like at that age.  They make very superficial judgements.  Do you think that's superficial?  He was a clown, if it's any consolation.

You know some- times somebody would like a few min- utes alone with W.P.  That means without you.  Okay, pal?  Let's eat.

Person1: I saw the flag signal--what's up?

Person1: You thought I'd help out on specifics?  I'll confirm what you get, try to keep you on the right track, but that's all.  Are you guys really working?  How much?
Person2: I don't know maybe sixteen, eighteen hours a day--we've got sources at Justice, the FBI, but it's still drying up.
Person1: Then there must be something, mustn't there. Look, forget the myths the media's created about the White House-- the truth is, these are not very bright guys, and things got out of hand.
Person2: If you don't like them, why won't you be more concrete with me?
Person1: Because the press stinks too--history on the run, that's all you're interested in.  You come up with anything?
Person2: John Mitchell resigned as head of CREEP to spend more time with his family. That doesn't exactly have the ring of truth.  Howard Hunt's been found--there was talk that his lawyer had 25 thousand in cash in a paper bag.
Person1: Follow the money. Always follow the money.
Person2: To where?
Person1: Go on.
Person2: This man Gordon Liddy--he's going to be tried along with Hunt and the five burglars--we know he knows a lot, we just don't know what.
Person1: You changed cabs? You're sure no one followed you?
Person2: I did everything you said, but it all seemed--
Person1: --melodramatic?  Things are past that--remember, these are men with switchblade mentalities who run the world as if it were Dodge City.
Person2: What's the whole thing about--do you know?
Person1: What I know, you'll have to find out on your own.
Person2: Liddy--you think there's a chance he'll talk?
Person1: Talk? Once, at a gathering, he put his hand over a candle. And he kept it there. He kept it right in the flame until his flesh seared. A woman who was watching asked, "What's the trick?" And he replied. "The trick is not minding."

Maybe he's a German the Krauts planted in this barracks. They do this type of thing. Just put an agent in with us -- a trained specialist. Lots of loose information floating around a prison camp. Not just whether somebody wants to escape, but what outfits we were with and where we were stationed, and how our radar operates. Could be, couldn't it?

Or you kill him off and the Krauts turn around and kill off the whole barracks. Every one of us. So what do you do?

Person1: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?
Person2: How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby.  We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.
Person1: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.
Person2: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.
Person1: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.
Person2: I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?
Person1: No, I never saw him before in my life.
Person2: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us.  There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.
Person1: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.
Person2: What was so appealing about Houston?
Person1: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.
Person2: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?
Person1: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.
Person2: I see.  And where did you drive?
Person1: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.
Person2: Why Galveston?
Person1: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.
Person2: And then Sunday?
Person1: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.
Person2: Did you bag any geese on this trip?
Person1: I believe the boys got a couple.
Person2: But the boys told us they didn't get any.
Person1: Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.
Person2: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?
Person1: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.
Person2: I see.  Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong?
Person2: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.

Person1: No, we never got busted. We were done with a shift one night, both a couple of Percocets down and I was telling Glenn about my boyfriend, about how we were thinking about doing it, you know? I was thinking about letting him be my first because I loved him.  What the hell was his name?

Person1: That's him. Let him in.

Person2: Jim, you can't come here and pull that steamroller stuff. Your methods won't do here. This boy is a Senator, however it happened, he's a Senator. This is Washington.

Person1: Well, what do you want me to do? Stand around like you chump and let that drooling infant wrap that Willet Creek Dam appropriation around my neck. Either he falls in line with us and behaves himself or I'll break him so wide open they'll never be able to find the pieces.

My methods have been all right for the past twenty years, Joe, since I picked you out of a fly-specked hole in the wall and blew you up to look like a Senator, and now you can't stand it. Well, maybe you won't have to stand it, Joe. Maybe we can fix it so you and your Boy Ranger can go home together.
Person2: Jim, you don't have to--
Person1: Oh, it's all right--it's all right. It seems a shame, though, to part company like this after all these years, especially now with a national convention coming up. Joe, I've put everything I have behind you. And so did all of our friends, but I guess we'll survive. We'll just have to find somebody else that's got a little more sense, that's all. In the meantime, you explain to Mr. Smith about Willet Dam. It's your bill-- it's your reputation, and if he can't find enough facts to break you with, you just send him to me and I'll give him a couple of good ones. I'm taking the next plane home.

Person1: Apart from that, you look pretty chipper for a man who's two thousand and thirty one years old.  I read the clocks. They bear out Hasslein's hypothesis. We've been away from Earth for two thousand years, give or take a decade.  Still can't accept it, huh?
Person2: long pause) You know it.

No, first tell her about being in the trunk with him, in the dark for half an hour, and see how she takes it.  If she's in on it, what does she get for all the aggravation; cops breathing on her?  I bet nothing.  So she still likes him enough to stick her neck out.  You think that's possible?  What kind of guy is he?

Reckless, quick to anger --  You said it yourself, Whistler.  Those vampires knew our defense system backwards and forwards.  Where'd they get their intel?

Person1: So.  I'm assuming they sent you here to administer last rites?

Person1: You're sure you want to?  In the universe I saw we're not exactly the stars of the show.  What happened to me makes us all seem pretty damn small.
Person2: It also makes God enormous.  I think of the scope of your universe, Ellie... and it takes my breath away.  As it will everyone else's.
Person1: I don't have any proof, Palmer.
Person2: Ellie, you're the proof.  You tell them your story.  Ultimately they'll have no choice but to believe you.
Person1: It's not enough, don't you understand?  I know it happened -- but by every standard of science, by every standard I've lived my life by that fact is utterly beside the point.  It may be true but it doesn't matter because I can't prove it's real.
Person2: Ellie, the only one holding you to that standard is you!  The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!
Person1: But --
Person2: Have you seen what's happening out there?  The terror, the despair? The world is on fire, Ellie.  People need something they can believe in, something worthy, and you can give it to them!
Person1: I want to, Palmer -- more than anything.  But it has to be real. It has to be true.
Person2: Ellie... if you go out there like this -- if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen -- I'm afraid they really will crucify you.  Please.  For your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth.  Tell them it really happened.

Person1: Who'd ever think, to look at you?

Sometimes words were enough -- but I wasn't beyond inflicting physical pain in order to be taken seriously.  I enjoyed seeing the shock on their poor faces when they realized who I was.  That same look you gave me when I turned the gun on you.

Person1: No matter how I keep turning it around in my mind -- it doesn't seem like the right thing.
Person2: For who?
Person1: For anyone. They'll never be able to live through the talk. Richard will never be able to. He doesn't deserve that. He hasn't hurt anyone in his life.
Person2: Then he can move! People move!
Person1: His family's lived for almost a hundred years. Richard doesn't know how to live anywhere else. And the kids...
Person2: The kids are grown! They don't need you anymore. You told me that. They hardly talk to you.
Person1: No, they don't say much. But Carolyn's 16. She's just about to find out about all this for herself -- she's going to fall in love, she's going to try and figure out how to build a life with someone. If I leave what does that say to her?
Person2: What about us? What about me?
Person1: You've got to know deep down that the minute we leave here. It'll all change.
Person2: Yeah. It could get better.
Person1: No matter how much distance we put between us and this house, I bring with it with me. And I'll feel it every minute we're together. And I'll blame loving you for how much it hurts. And then even these four days won't be anything more than something sordid and... a mistake.
Person2: Francesca, listen to me. You think what's happened to us happens to just anybody? What we feel for each other? How much we feel? We're not even two separate people anymore. Some people search their whole lives for it and wind up alone -- most people don't even think it exists and you're going to tell me that giving it up is the right thing to do? That staying here alone in a marriage, alone in a town you hate, in a house you don't feel apart of anymore -- you're telling me that's the right thing to do!?
Person1: We are the choices we've made, Robert.
Person2: TO HELL WITH YOU!

Person1: Excuse me...

You be as cold as you want. A child would know it, he's right.  You're going to make something up, be sure it will help or keep your mouth closed.

Same way Grace played us this morning.  I don't like that, Jake.  Not twice in one day.  And maybe I'm so pissed I'd twist the next off my own Grandma to get out of here.

Person1: Damn it, Jake.  If I don't get out of here some guys are going to come gunning for me.  And if it comes down to me or Grace, then I pick Grace.  You were going to give me thirteen-thousand.  Give me two- hundred.  I'll kill her and dump the body where no one will ever find it. But I need the money.  I've got to have the money.

Trust me...I can take care of this.
