Person2: No, but deep down, beneath the "tolerance" they learn on television, nothing's changed. The very word makes their skin crawl.  It isn't even hate, really. It's more the way we feel when a rat runs across the floor. We want to step on it. Crush it. We don't even know why. It's a physical reaction. Everyone feels it.

Person1: Ugh, I missed the bus again!
Person2: Oh no, do you need a lift?
Person1: No, it's just frustrating. This kind of thing always happens to me.
Person2: Maybe you need a more reliable alarm or to adjust your morning routine.
Person1: It's not just the bus, Evan. It feels like I'm always a step behind in everything.
Person2: We all have rough patches. Let's work together to get you back on track.

Person1: Captain... We're waiting. What's the delay?
Person2: All is well, sir. You have the coordinates to beam up Genesis...
Person1: First things first, Captain. Kill Admiral Kirk.

Person1: I've been putting this together for over a year.  I have personal suggestions for your entire team, phone numbers, contact people.  They won't believe you about what they're going to see, so don't bother trying to convince them.  Just use my checkbook to get them there. I'll fund your expedition through my personal accounts, as such money and equipment as you need, but only if you leave immediately.  If we hesitate, all will be lost.
Person2: John . . .
Person1: You'll need an animal behaviorist, someone with unimpeachable credentials.  I believe you already know Sarah Harding.  She's got theories about parenting and nurturing among hunter/scavengers I bet she'd be dying to prove on a scale like this.  If you convince her to go, it'll be a major coup.  When she publishes, the scientific community must take it seriously.

Person1: How would I get a loan, anyway?
Person2: You need collateral.
Person1: Like this?
Person2: That thing? Who'd you steal it from?
Person1: My daddy gave me this watch.
Person2: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from?
Person1: My daddy is dead so watch your mouth. You can say what you want about me, but don't be dragging my daddy into it. This watch means the world to me. Solid gold. Keeps perfect time.
Person2: Looks like a fake to me. Loan denied!

Person1: Ow, you're hurting me!
Person2: Listen guy, you're embarassing me in front of my friends!  You know how I get mad when I get embarassed.

Person1: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?
Person2: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.
Person1: That's right. Take a little, leave a little.
Person2: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?
Person1: You're a thousand percent right!
Person2: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.
Person1: You know it, Lilly.
Person2: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.
Person1: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.
Person2: Well, you can tell them I said they're right.  I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.
Person1: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.
Person2: I will. So long, Bobo.

Person1: Wholesome.
Person2: Unwelcome.
Person1: Unwelcome?  I guess someone still has her panties in a twist.
Person2: Don't for one minute think that you had any effect whatsoever on my panties.
Person1: So what did I have an effect on ?
Person2: Other than my upchuck reflex? Nothing.

Person1: Not right now.
Person2: Not right now?  Okay, when?
Person1: Right after you change your wardrobe, your personality and drop about thirty pounds.
Person2: Quite a mouth on a girl so young...  ...but my guess is talking is not what it does best.
Person1: Only way you're ever gonna find out is reincarnation... Fact is, you are gonna pay me, and I am gonna provide you with a service.
Person2: I actually know how this works.
Person1: You're gonna pay me fifty thousand dollars...

Person1: There's another promise you must make me. That little girl who comes here...she mustn't ever come to see you again. Promise me you won't see her.
Person2: I-shan't see her. No, Barbara, no.
Person1: If that child comes here...if I find her trying to steal your love from me...I'll kill her. Yes, I'll kill her.
Person2: I'll not see her, Barbara. I promise.

Person1: But -- if you're a User -- then everything you've done has been part of a plan ...
Person2: You wish. Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got down here. I mean in here. Out here. Whatever.
Person1: Then...
Person2: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doin' what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell your User knows what's goin' on.
Person1: Well -- that's how it is for programs, yes, but --
Person2: I hate to disappoint you, pal, most-the time, that's how it is for Users, too.
Person1: Stranger and stranger...

Person1: Sal, I'm sorry about this.  But we can get outta this thing.  There's a way outta this.
Person2: Are you serious?  About throwin' a body outta here if we have to?
Person1: Well, I stalled him for a while. When it comes the time, then we'll work it out.  Okay?
Person2: But do you mean in? ... But you just told him that if worse comes to worse...
Person1: I want him to think that.
Person2: But I want to know what you think.
Person1: We won't have to.
Person2: I'll tell you right now - that I'm ready to do it.

Person1: I'magine they asked who you givin' it to, too.
Person2: They asked.
Person1: And what was your answer?
Person2: I said I wanted to talk to a lawyer.
Person1: You positive about that? You weren't nervous and let something slip by mistake? If you did, I ain't mad, I just gotta know.

Person1: No, no, no! Not this time. I am doing this for your own good! You guys have got to learn when to stop. You with the Armani! You with the hookers!
Person2: Escorts!
Person1: Do you even remember Al? Do you remember what he looked like sitting there?

Person1: What?
Person2: Can you live with it?
Person1: Live with what?
Person2: With that jerk walkin' around breathin' the same air as you? And gettin' away with it every day. Are you haunted?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: You wanna get unhaunted?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Then shoot 'em. Shoot 'em in the face. And feed that boy to the dogs.
Person1: I can't believe what you're tellin' me.
Person2: I ain't tellin' ya nothin'. I'm just sayin' what I'd do.
Person1: You'd really do that?
Person2: He don't got no right to live.
Person1: Look, Elvis, he is hauntin' me. He doesn't deserve to live. And I do want to kill him. But I don't wanna go to jail for the rest of my life.
Person2: I don't blame you.
Person1: If I thought I could get away with it -
Person2: Killin' 'em's the hard part. Gettin' away with it's the easy part. Whaddaya think the cops do when a pimp's killed? Burn the midnight oil tryin' to find who done it? They couldn't give a flyin' fuck if all the pimps in the whole wide world took two in the back of the head. If you don't get caught at the scene with the smokin' gun in your hand, you got away with it.

Person1: He told you he's failing in love with you? I've never known him to say those words before.
Person2: Really? I thought he said it all the time.
Person1: That's not his style. one thing I can say about Valmont. He always speaks the truth.

Person1: I couldn't sit home and play the mournful widow anymore, and the police didn't need me, so I tried watching a Lakers game on TV, but the announcer talked to fast and I couldn't understand a lot of what was happening, so I figured if I came down here maybe you could explain the rules to me, and besides, I missed you.
Person2: No problem.

Person1: Victor was not a stranger, he was our neighbor.
Person2: He was not family. Family is all that matters. Do you think if you or I were being dragged from here, any one of them would lift a finger to help us?
Person1: They do not have your connections.
Person2: Connections? I have no connections, only favors. If I call to help Victor, a General will think "Paul Rusesabagina is a fool. He thinks my favors are so numerous and so insignificant as to waste them on everybody." Then my hard work is doubly squandered. I insult the General and I do not get to use my favor at all. Please leave these things to my good judgment.

Person1: Santos... What's happenin' here?
Person2: Hey... Stop the nervous cry-baby routine... You're my girl now... Santos is gonna wipe away those tears and make you happy... Come on, let's get outta here.
Person1: Where we goin'?
Person2: Got word the kids are moving through Texas... I think an ending is being arranged there... Come on, lemme see a smile.
Person1: Please Santos... Where's Johnnie?

Person1: So I assume we're regarding this As just a kind of interlude.
Person2: Look, it's too much of a tangle. I already cast my lot.  I can't go Back and I can't sneak, feel back Enough as it is.
Person1: You feel bad about this?  About me?
Person2: I didn't mean it that way.
Person1: You know you don't have to sneak. You could stay with me.  I know Things, Wyatt.  Sweet things.  I Could make you so happy.
Person2: I can't, I'm sorry.  Forgive me.

Person1: Excuse me... your voice is familiar and I'm sure I know you from somewhere...
Person2: Awww-rr, Buddy, come on, you know me!
Person1: Well, I... I... ah-h, let's see...
Person2: It's Dave Wilkie! I'm Dave Wilkie, don't you remember me?
Person1: Oh. Oh, God. Of course, Dave, how are you?

Person1: She was alive all these years... You NEVER let me know her. Who gave you that right...?!
Person2: A Mayfair it ever I saw one.
Person1: I might as well be Rowan Smith - or Jones!   you cut me off from every -
Person2: I'm tired.  I need to rest.
Person1: There are things I have to know!

Person1: I'm trying to tell you -- and this is where you have to trust me -- but, I think your life might be in real danger.
Person2: What?
Person1: You have to get out of here.  Leave as soon as possible.  Go to any rural town, away from any major city...
Person2: You are an insane person.
Person1: Marla...
Person2: No, no, shut up!  I've had enough. I tried, Tyler... I have tried...

Person1: They are all Tutsi cockroaches.
Person2: Let me explain.

Person1: By the way, I'm not much of a pool player.
Person2: Shit, it ain't hard to play pool. I can teach you everything ya need ta know.
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: Hell yeah! I'll even spot ya a few points first game.
Person1: Wait a minute. You're gonna hustle me?
Person2: Nah... how much money have you got?

Person1: There!  Happy?  I asked for one thing from you... one simple promise.  Now look what you've done!
Person2: This isn't possible...
Person1: We're going to have to do something about Marla...
Person2: What... what are you saying?
Person1: It's okay.  We okay... a little codependent, sure, but...

Person1: You're a good liar.
Person2: Almost as good as you.
Person1: I always win, Jack. One way or another.  Pity I didn't keep that drawing. It's going to be worth a lot more by morning.

Person1: See! The big guy likes it.
Person2: I just saw the woman I'm going to marry, I know it. But then I lost her.
Person1: Tough break. Most men have to get married before they lose their wives.
Person2: I'm going to spend the rest of my life looking for her. That or die alone.
Person1: Jesus, kid.  Let me guess. Real pretty, blonde hair, blue hat?
Person2: Yes!
Person1: I know her uncle. Friends of the family.
Person2: Who is she? Where does she live?
Person1: Kid. Don't waste your time. She's out of your league.

Person1: That's a fantastic idea --
Person2: See, I just take your gun to the morgue and fire it into one of their skulls; then I call every newspaper in the country with the story about how Senator Kendall's gay son went nuts on a training mission --

Person1: Look, Snoop, I don't know what Glenn promised you or what you think you're gonna get, but the deal is me and Buddy get half of whatever we take from Ripley, understand?  How you and Glenn cut up the rest is up to you.
Person2: Let's go outside and talk.
Person1: What's the matter with right here? It's nice and warm.
Person2: Warm?  Man, it's ninety-five degrees in here, sometimes a hundred -- the way Emanuel always kep' it so his boys'd sweat, get lean and mean like Tommy Hearns.  No, I ain't talking any business in here.  To me this is holy ground, man.  You understand?  I got to be someplace anyway.  Y'all want to talk, come to the fights tomorrow night, we'll sit down and look at it good. The State Theater.

Person1: Now, you listen to me. You ain't gonna do a darn thing, you hear me! Nobody cares what you think, I'm running this show, I make the decisions.
Person2: He's running the show.
Person1: I'm running the show. I make the plays, and you back the plays I make. Stop thinking with your balls. Kate in a room with a couple of desperate men with nothing to lose ain't the time to "go for it." I need your cover. Cover my ass.

Person1: Why didn't you ask me to go with you?
Person2: Do you know why? Because if you saw those ruins I'm sure you would have said they were very, very beautiful. You always say "how beautiful" to everything -- whether it's the sea, or a baby, or a cat! You have such a sensitive little heart that it throbs for anything.
Person2: But Corrado...  If something is beautiful why shouldn't one say so?
Person1: He never misses a chance to humiliate me, to let me know that he doesn't care about me any more.
Person2: Giulia, that remark is not worthy of our twelve years of honest concubinage. I repeat, once and for all, and publicly, that I admire you. Does that please you?

Person1: Who's this person?
Person2: He's a friend. from the neighborhood. we were just talking.
Person1: From the neighborhood?  Shut up.  You like telephones? Huh? You wanta go for a ride?

Person1: Two minutes til Krieger shows.  Thisll have to be quicker than Id like. Certainly quicker than youd like.
Person2: Ethan, if you knew about Jim?..Why..
Person1: Why the masquerade?  Why take the risk? Well, Claire, youve asked the question and you are the answer.

Person1: Says here you're getting Martin Weir for the part of Lovejoy.
Person2: Yeah, we're getting Martin.
Person1: No shit, come on. How you gonna do that?
Person2: I put a gun right here...  ...and I tell him, 'Sign the paper Marty or you are dead.' Like that.
Person1: I wonder, would that work?  You know who I see for Al Roxy? Harvey Keitel. The man could do it in his sleep.
Person2: Harvey Keitel. Yeah. Maybe. He was pretty good in the movie "Fingers".
Person1: I missed that one. Or, hey, you know who else? Morgan Freeman. You know Morgan?
Person2: Yeah, Morgan Freeman. But he's a colored guy.
Person1: So what? Where's it say in this script he's white? Color is what the part needs, man, somebody to do it has some style. The way it is now, Ronnie could do it, play himself, some cracked out asshole.  So whatta you think of the script?

Person1: You miserable little tripe-hound. I'm the one who should be fed up, sacrificing my last sup of black market petrol to take you to school.
Person2: I have to live in Rosehill Avenue as well.
Person1: Only till they get you into the local school.
Person2: With Mrs. Evans. I hate her.
Person1: You'll be at home for the weekends. Now shut up, or walk.

Person1: You've got sand, for a maid.
Person2: Thank you, sir.
Person1: And how does a maid come to own a trinket such as that?  A family heirloom, perhaps?
Person2: Of course.  I didn't steal it, if that's what you mean.
Person1: No, no, nothing like that.  Very well.  You hand that over, we'll put your town to our rudder and ne'er return.
Person2: Can I trust you?
Person1: It's you who invoked the parlay! Believe me, Miss, you'd best hand it over, now ... or these be the last friendly words you'll hear!

Person1: There, okay? Now that's just plain old hamburger.
Person2: Some of the brown stuff is still there.
Person1: Then eat around it.
Person2: No.
Person1: Now listen to me, young man. Do you know what I had to go through to put this goddamn food on the goddamn table?
Person2: I don't care.  I hate it.  I want pizza.
Person1: Not on your life.  That's it. I've had it with crap around this house.  From now on, no more pizza!  Get it?  Starting right now you can eat real food like a normal human being!
Person2: No!
Technique: Brandishing Anger,Persuasion or Seduction,Shaming or Belittlement

Dialogue:
Person1: What was that?  Did you hear that?
Person2: It's nothing.  My men take great delight in routing the enemy.  Don't trouble yourself, beauty.
Person1: It sounded like it came from the courtyard.
Person2: From the parapets most likely.  The men are amused by a battlefield entertainment of my own contriving.
Person1: Might we watch, too?
Person2: Later, beloved... Now I wish only to be with you...

Person1: Kill me, Peter, do it, now.
Person2: No.  Not yet.
Person1: Do it.  If that's what all this carnage is about, then do it.  Have enough guts to do it.
Person2: Don't talk to me about courage.  I know death, what it's like to kill. You're not a killer -- you watched Daryll Lee kill that cop and you didn't make a peep, because you were paralyzed with fear.  You chocked.  I know something else about you.

Person1: You're not going to die.
Person2: What did you say?
Person1: Shut up. You're going to die and he's not. Got it.

Person1: I'm gonna quit.
Person2: What?!?
Person1: Each show is worse than the next.
Person2: Are you nuts?!  40 million people watch you every week!
Person1: So?  What do they know?
Person2: Absolutely nothing!  That's the beauty!  It's credibility.  You make them love you... and then later, on your special, you'll screw with their heads!

Person1: Where'd you say the showersand thingswere?
Person2: Heyyou're little, aren't you?
Person1: Where is the shower?
Person2: Your hair's cute like that. You should never comb it.
Person1: I'll find it myself.

Person1: I told her she was going to meet her father.
Person2: You what?
Person1: It was the only way, Auggie. Otherwise, she wasn't going to let me see her.
Person2: I think you'd better stop the car and let me out.
Person1: Relax, okay? You don't have to do anything. Just go in there and pretend. It won't kill you to do a little favor like that. Besides, you might even learn something.
Person2: Yeah, like what?
Person1: That I wasn't bullshitting you, sweetheart. At least you'll know I've been telling the truth.
Person2: Look, I'm not saying you don't have a daughter. It's just that she's not my daughter.
Person1: Wait till you see her, Auggie.
Person2: And what's that supposed to mean?
Person1: She looks just like you.
Person2: Cut it out. Just cut it out, okay? It's starting to get on my nerves.
Person1: When I told her I was going to bring her father, she kind of melted. It's the first time Felicity's talked nice to me since she left home. She's dying to meet you, Auggie.

Person1: You always hurt the ones you love.
Person2: You mean the ones you pity.
Person1: Say anything you want... I know you love me and I love you.
Person2: I do love you.  Let's get lost together.

Person1: Where are you?
Person2: Closer than you think.
Person1: Alright I'm here. What do you want from me?
Person2: To see your reaction.
Person1: Reaction to what?

Person1: Hey, I've got a great compliment for you.
Person2: You know what? I...
Person1: Just let me talk.  I'm the only one on the face of the earth who realizes that you're the greatest woman on earth. I'm the only one who appreciates how amazing you are in every single thing you do -- in every single thought you have... in how you are with Spencer -- Spence...  ... in how you say what you mean and how you almost always mean something that's all about being straight and good...

Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: Don't sweet lip me.
Person1: I don't understand where this personal attack is coming from...
Person2: You're a liar. I want to know what happened in Vegas.
Person1: Nothing happened in Vegas.
Person2: I don't want to hear it from the liar. Stick a plug in it Boyd. Fisher? What happened in Vegas?

Person1: So, you're looking great, how have you been?
Person2: Well, I actually might need a little surgery after last time.
Person1: Really?
Person2: My friend told me I should maybe even get a lawyer.
Person1: Oh, lawyers are so complicated-don't do that. Here.

Person1: I'm sorry you can't see that, I know you could once -- you made a little speech once, that I'll always remember and I know the others do too --  They remember and they see how you have changed. That's why they didn't want to come tonight to you, Jabez -- you're as blind as a Burma bat, with your gold pot! Mind you, it's not the money, I've been talking about, it's what you make of it.
Person2: I -- I don't know what you're talking about! I -- I haven't time to listen to all this --
Person1: No -- you haven't time -- You haven't time for your mother, or your wife, or your child.
Person2: It's your fault! You brought Daniel Webster here -- just to try to make a fool of me! You played the sneak behind my back -- made up all sorts of lies against me! You can get yourself out of my home -- go back to the other house -- that old place, where you belong -- I don't want to -- to talk to you again!

Person1: What'd you fight, middleweight?
Person2: Light to super-middleweight, as my body developed.  You go about what, bantam?
Person1: Flyweight.
Person2: You know your divisions.  You like the fights?  Like the rough stuff?  Yeah, I bet you do.  Like to get down and tussle a little bit?  Like me and Tuffy, before she got run over, we use to get down on the floor and tussle.  I say to her, "You a good dog, Tuffy, here's a treat for you."  And I give Tuffy what every dog love best.  You know what that is? A bone.  I can give you a bone, too, girl.
Person1: You're not my type.
Person2: Don't matter.  I let the monster out, you gonna do what it wants.
Person1: Just a minute.

Person1: You're wrong.
Person2: Am I...?  Would you be willing to plant corroborative evidence on a suspect you knew was guilty in order to ensure an indictment?
Person1: Dudley, we've been over this.
Person2: Answer yes or no.
Person1: I... No.
Person2: Would you be willing to rig crime scene evidence to support a prosecuting attorney's working hypothesis...?  Yes or no, Edmund.
Person1: No.
Person2: Would you be willing to beat confessions out of suspects you knew to be guilty?
Person1: No.
Person2: Would you be willing to shoot hardened criminals in the back to offset the chance --
Person1: No.
Person2: Then for God's sake, don't be a detective.  Stick to assignments where you won't have to make those choices.  Patrol, Internal Affairs, but not the Bureau.
Person1: I know you mean well, Dudley, but I don't need to do it the way you did.  Or my father.
Person2: At least get rid of the glasses. I can't think of one Bureau man who wears them.

Person1: Pay money?
Person2: Yeah, dummy.  Money.
Person1: I never paid for it in my life.
Person2: It's better when you pay... they let you do anything.
Person1: They always let me do anything. I don't want to pay for it.  I never paid for it in my life.
Person2: Just do what I say, okay? We'll pay for the girls and have a good time... Don't you trust me?

Person1: Dad, maybe I shouldn't go with all that's happening to you.
Person2: You're going.
Person1: But listen, if I had a friend in the same position, I would tell her to delay a year.
Person2: You're going.
Person1: It doesn't feel right to me.  I, I don't even have the right luggage yet.
Person2: Bon voyage.
Person1: You're not listening to me.
Person2: Diane!  Alright, let's stop this right now.  Let's not put our energy into something ridiculous.  This isn't even smart thinking.
Person1: Dad, why are you acting this way?  Is this because of the other morning?

Person1: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't expect a fellow who never saw Lednov and never heard his name until a while ago to do too much worryin'. You've been sorta close mouthed about him.
Person2: I guess I have. You were pretty little when they locked him up. I don't suppose you even remember that time I was gone two months.
Person1: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico lookin' for cattle.
Person2: You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used to go fishing and hunting with him when you were so high.
Person1: Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico or something...
Person2: That's what I told you then. Only he didn't. Lednov killed him.
Person1: Oh... that's the time you went away.
Person2: I caught up with Lednov in Nogales. He didn't like the idea of comin' back across the border but he came. I turned him over to the sheriff and -- that's the story.
Person1: Maybe you shoulda killed him.
Person2: Maybe I should. But I was never much on killin'. Anyway, he moved too quick and I just got him through the shoulder.  Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.
Person1: Yeah, it does.
Person2: But you never can tell. Why don't you get that new rifle out of the wagon?

Person1: I ate a guy last night.
Person2: And how did you feel when you ate this guy?
Person1: I don't know. I don't remember doing it.

Person1: You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about ordinary, everyday reasons. Which is why I want to discuss your private life.  How many illegitimate children do you have?
Person2: Major, I don't see how this line of questioning could...
Person1: David, what are you Counsel for the Defence now?  Did you hear the question?

Person1: Wait a minute. Wait a minute.  Matt, do you realize you're up against something? You're being charged with murder. It's serious, son. Now come on, I know you didn't do it.  But we've got to make them believe it. Come on, tell the truth, where were you last night?
Person2: I can't tell you.

Person1: I can't do it, Rita -- that's the policy here on colored prisoners, and I ain't about to change it, not even for a friend like you.
Person2: Charlie, just because a man and his family are colored, you--
Person1: Now look, Rita, I don't make the rules -- you puttin' yourself on a limb, comin' here, askin' me to do a thing like this. And I be damn if I'm going to jeopardize my job because you are in love with a little colored boy!

Person1: I want to see him tomorrow, Clyde.
Person2: Edgar, think twice.  He works in the kitchen.
Person1: Not Joaquin, you idiot.  Nixon.  Did you hear what he said in Oregon? About me having too much power.
Person2: It's between Nixon and a Kennedy again, Edgar ... Who do you want?
Person1: Kennedy -- never.  He'll fry in hell for what he did to me.  But Nixon doesn't know that, which is why I'm gonna have to remind him he needs us a helluva lot more'n we need him.

Person1: You mess with this guy -- get him to do your dirty work and you think you can take the money and dump me?
Person2: No baby, you got it wrong.
Person1: This road don't go to Globe, Grace -- where were you going to meet me?

Person1: Zorg. Jean-Baptiste Emmanuel Zorg... nice to see you again
Person2: I remember you now..the so called art dealer.
Person1: I'm glad you got your memory back, Father... Because you're going to need it... Where are the stones?
Person2: ...Why on earth do the stones interest you?
Person1: Personally, they are of no interest to me, I'd rather sell weapons..but I have a customer... so tell me...
Person2: Even it I did know where the stones were I would never tell somebody like you.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong with me?
Person2: ...I'm a priest! I'm here to serve life, All you want to do is destroy it.
Person1: Ah, Father... You are so wrong. Let me explain...

It happened in your room, and you came to Vancouver with him.. At any rate, he made your hotel reservation.. And you arrived together. Here in this room he behaved nastily to you, and you said something to him which might be taken as a threat.  A few hours later he was found dead on your balcony. Would it be too much too suggest that all these circumstances taken together are a little suspicious?

Person1: -- and when my husband died I felt helpless. They disobeyed me -- things went from bad to worse. All my husband's dreams of good health, good sanitation, good morals for these sweet and gentle people seemed to die with him.  Then, almost accidentally, I discovered the secret of how to deal with them. There was a girl with a baby -- again and again I begged her to boil the drinking water. She never would. Then I told her the god, Shango, would be pleased and kill the evil spirits in the water if she boiled it. She boiled the water from then on.
Person2: But you didn't have to come up here.
Person1: Perhaps not.  But I did come here and I found it was so simple to let the gods speak through me. Once started, it seemed such an easy way to do good.  I should have known there was no easy way to do good, Betsy.

Now Rose, the little girl sitting across from you with the blue eyes is Doll Baby. She looks like an angel and she is an angel, but she can be a naughty angel sometimes, although her father won't believe it. Her real name is Frances, but we call her Dolly or Doll.

Person1: Have you contacted the British Home and the Royal Hospital?
Person2: Ah, no sir. I had planned to see them in the morning.
Person1: Good! How is the patient?
Person2: He's doing very well. In fact that's why I came to see you. I think that if I were to present Mr. Merrick to the hospital committee, then they would have a chance to see for themselves not only the extraordinary nature of the disease, but of the man as well. If the committee had a chance to speak with him, hear him say a few words for himself, I'm sure they would see him as a patient, rather than as a violation of the rules.
Person1: A few words? I thought he was imbecile?
Person2: Well sir, perhaps I should explain...
Person1: I really don't think that's necessary Treves. I'm quite sure the committee will be able to make an equitable decision on the merits of the case, such as they are.
Person2: I don't agree. No one can make a reasonable decision about this man's future without at least meeting him. No doctor would presume to diagnose a patient he had never met.
Person1: No, Treves, it's out of the question. Now if it was up to me, I'd say "Certainly, let's meet the fellow, by all means," I'm sorry, I simply can't speak for the other members of the committee.
Person2: Then will you meet him, as a representative of the committee.
Person1: Mr. Treves, it's out of the question. I want to hear as soon as possible what the other hospitals can do. I'm sorry.

You're living at home, and you got your father and mother there, and you can go on like that -- being a little girl all your life.

I'll borrow my brother Freddie's car, or you can call me up when you feel blue, or I'll call you up. And it's gonna be nice. Don't be so afraid.

Person1: Murdered?  Why?

Person2: He didn't just kill three women anymore. He killed ten.
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: Something we did changed the case...changed history.  Mom wasn't dead.  But then after you didn't die in the fire something must have happened.  And this guy, this Nightingale guy, he kept on killing...it was like a spree...seven more women.

Person2: I don't know...  What about the other women?
Person1: I'll warn them.

Person2: No.  Nobody got...  Wait a minute.  I might not know who he is, but I know where he's gonna be.  I got the case file.  We know what he's gonna do before he does it.
Person1: So what should I do?  Call the police? You think they'll believe me?
Person2: They will if they catch him in the act. You can make that happen, Dad.  You can tail the victim and call it in at just the right moment.

Person1: You know why I'm such a good officer? Because of my mother.  Have I ever told you about her?
Person2: Bits and pieces.
Person1: She's the best poker player you ever saw.  My father used to go to these Saturday night games and lose his shirt.  Finally, my mother gave him an ultimatum, either she gets a regular seat at the table or she locks him in every Saturday night. He squawked and so did his buddies but after a while they gave in and from the first night she sat down, she never lost.  She could read those cocky bastards like they were playing open hands.  And he bluffs?  He had sixteen levels of bullshit.  Her eyes, the tone of her voice, her bets, her jokes, the way she sipped her coffee, she was a master.  She won more money on shit hands than anyone in the history of the game. Every Saturday night, my father would lose two, three hundred bucks and she'd win it all back and then some. And I'd stand there, glued to her shoulder, from the time I was five years old, watching every hand, every move, studying how she did it.  That's why I'm such a good officer, I can look at a man's face and tell you exactly what he's holding, and if it's a shit hand, I know just what cards to deal him.
Person2: And what about your own hand?
Person1: No problem.  A pair of deuces?  Less? So what?  I bluff.  It used to tear me apart when I'd get one of my men killed, but what was I supposed to do?  Break down in front of the ones who were standing there waiting for me to tell them what to do?  Of course not, so I bluffed, and after a while, I started to fall for my own bluff. It was great, it made everything so much easier.  Sarge Is that why your hand's been shaking?
Person1: It could be worse.  You know the first thing they teach you at O.C.S.? Lie to your men.
Person2: Oh, yeah?
Person1: Not in so many words, but they tell you you can have all the firepower in the world and if your men don't have good morale, it's not worth a damn.  So if you're scared or empty or half-a-step from a Section Eight, do you tell your men?  Of course not.  You bluff, you lie.
Person2: And how do you bluff yourself?
Person1: Simple, numbers.  Every time you kill one of your men, you tell yourself you just saved the lives of two, three, ten, a hundred others. We lost, what, thirty-one on the cliffs?  I'll bet we saved ten times that number by putting out those guns.  That's over three hundred men.  Maybe five hundred.  A thousand. Then thousand.  Any number you want. See?  It's simple.  It lets you always choose mission over men.
Person2: Except this time, the mission IS a man.
Person1: That's the rub.  I liked Wade.  Who's Ryan?  If they're both standing in front of me and I have to shoot one or the other, how do I choose?  Look at my hand, there it goes again.
Person2: John, I've got to tell you, I think you're about used up.
Person1: I think you're right, Keith.
Person2: You want me to take over?

Person1: And then, there's Richard's Burrito.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: That's my own theory based on a Mexican food called the burrito. I had it once when my parents took me to Disneyland.
Person2: I know what a burrito is.
Person1: Well, I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.
Person2: What's inside?
Person1: You can till it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universes
Person2: So you think time travel is possible? For people?
Person1: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants.
Person2: Listen, you've gotta keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul. Promise?
Person1: Okay. I promise.
Person2: This is serious. Nobody can know. Ah, I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.
Person1: You probably are crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke? I know what you all, think of me.

Person1: You won't?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: But you might.
Person2: I might.
Person1: Is that so? You might marry me?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: When?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: How about tomorrow? I don't mean to be pushy but --
Person2: I don't know. I don't know what's happening.
Person1: You mean you're confused?

Person1: Listen, I want to talk to you.
Person2: Not now.  I don't have time.
Person1: I saw that look pass between you And Wyatt at the fight.  Listen to Me!  You're mine!  Understand? You're my woman and I'm your man.
Person2: My man?  You told Wyatt you'd Disarmed those men.  Do you Actually believe after that I Could see you as my man?  You're Just a dirty little fixer.
Person1: You whore!  You filthy whore!

Person1: There's a tunnel out of the crypt into the barn. Did you know about that? There's an answer Mother. That's how she got out.
Person2: That's crazy. How could she find out about it?
Person1: Somebody told her.
Person2: Who?  That tun... that tunnel hasn't been used in fifty years.
Person1: Oh, would you stop lying Mother!
Person2: Why would I lie?
Person1: Because it's murder we're talking about. Aren't you concerned about what she told us about the other person in her room.
Person2: I'm concerned about her health.
Person1: Who was that person Mother?  Was it you?
Person2: If you believe this is murder, it is the Crown attorney you have to talk to, not me. And definitely not Agnes.

Person1: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves. Well, let me ask you this: what kind of settlement do you seek? What are, for you, the parameters of the possible?
Person2: That's the problem. I can't afford to give her anything.
Person1: Nothing?
Person2: I know that sounds rough but I'm about to close on a deal to develop some mini-malls, and I'm mortgaged up to my ass. If this deal goes south, I'm ruined -- I'll lose millions.
Person1: So, you propose that in spite of demonstrable infidelity on your part, your unoffending wife should be tossed out on her ear?
Person2: Well -- is that possible?

Person1: Some chance at ten percent a week! And if he don't borrow, he don't work.
Person2: You'll work.
Person1: I ought to belt you one, J.P.
Person2: Raise a hand to me and... .
Person1: ... .and you'll tell Johnny Friendly.
Person2: You'd be off the pier for good.

Person1: Want to dance?
Person2: Dance? Here?
Person1: Why not?
Person2: They know you here--know your name.
Person1: I know everybody. I don't look at half of life, just the nice half, I look at all of it.

Person1: This is not a sexist thing. If you were a waiter I would still be here saying...
Person2: Are you totally gone? This is my private home...
Person1: I am trying to keep emotions out of this. Even though this is an important issue to me and I have strong feelings about the subject.
Person2: What subject? That I wasn't there to take crap from you and bring you eggs? Do you have any control over how creepy you allow yourself to get?
Person1: Yes, I do, as a matter of fact... and to prove it I have not gotten personal and you have. Why aren't you at work? You're not sick -- you don't look sick... just very tired and bitter.
Person2: My son is sick, okay?

Person1: I'm going to go in.
Person2: Just play one set of downs. I told them you were great.

Person1: Jeremy.  I'm going in. I have to do some things.
Person2: What things?
Person1: I'm going to work out.
Person2: I'll help you.
Person1: There's nothing to do.

Person1: What you want to watch this trash for? Ain't one of those people have a real thought in their brain.
Person2: That so?  You want to tell me what, if any, real thoughts you had lately?
Person1: What you have to get personal about so quick? All I mean is you could possibly read a book.

Person1: We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.
Person2: We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.

Person1: Ah, go chase yourself. I'll take my business elsewhere. And for future reference, you are no longer welcome at Ray's Boom-Boom Room.

Person2: You're always your harshest critic.

Person2: Okay, I saw this in a movie once. Open the dining room window and follow my lead. Say what I say.

Person1: I'm sorry.  Would you like a taste?
Person2: No, I'm good.
Person1: I insist. It's delicious. Just a taste.

Person2: This conversation is finished.

Person2: Did not.
Person1: Did too.
Person2: I can't know what I said, but we're not going.
Person1: I'm not leaving this room until you say yes.
Person2: Get out.
Person1: No.
Person2: Goddammit, I am sick of this --

Person1: Don't bullshit me! Don't bullshit me!
Person2: You know what I want to hear? I want to hear that you don't love me. If you tell me that, then I'll leave you alone. I won't ask any questions and I won't be in your life.

Person1: The girl is looking to party, and you tell her we're going to go back to our motel room and crash? Jesus, Miles!
Person2: Well, I'm tired. Aren't you tired?
Person1: The chick digs you. She lit up like a pinball machine when she heard your novel was getting published.
Person2: Now I've got another lie to live down. Thanks, Jack.

Person2: Didn't seem to me like that's what was going on. You were all over her.
Person1: Somebody had to do the talking. And by the way, I was right. She's not married.
Person2: How do you know?
Person1: No rock. When she came to the bar, sans rock.

Person1: What are your intentions?  To make little dreams in coffee shops, turn a woman's head, and I don't mind admitting it was turned, I liked it, but ten hours later I feel like a fool.  I don't get it.  You, my father, here in this house, the cof- fee shop, it's making me upset, and I don't like being upset.  Who are you anyway?  And what are you eating?
Person2: Peanut butter.

Person1: Shut up, yous guys. Look, Amber, I'm not gonna win. And let's be honest, a family only needs one "Liza" and you know Peter's got much better legs than me.

Person2: Lis, I want to, I really do, but... Oh, I can't.
Person1: Then do it for Peter. Mrs. Leeman used to call him a "skinny little fag" when he'd bag her groceries. He'd pop his Nancy-belt if his old jacket somehow, I don't know, got her back.
Person2: Yah?
Person1: Oh-you-beccha.

Person2: No. No...we need to try our vaccine on it.

Person2: Incinerate it. Like the others.

Person2: They seemed to buy our story about the Hanta virus. You'll make sure the families are taken care of financially, along with a sizeable donation to the community.  Maybe a small roadside memorial.

Person1: Are you going to provide me with an opportunity to prove my love to my girl? Or are you gonna save yourself some trouble and step up like a gentleman and apologize to her?
Person2: Don't mess with me, man. You look like a clown in that stupid jacket.
Person1: This is a snakeskin jacket, and for me it's a symbol of my individuality and my belief in personal freedom.
Person2: ...Asshole.
Person1: Come here.

Person1: I was thinking about our conversation the other day -- what you said about choices.
Person2: Uh huh.
Person1: Yeah, you know, that in life you really have to choose what you want to do.
Person2: Listen, I'm sorry, but it's really late -- you don't have to come tomorrow to work on the floor.
Person1: It is tomorrow.

Person1: What a weirdo that guy is!  Paranoid.  What's the matter with you?
Person2: Look I-I-I'll be okay.  I'll be okay.
Person1: It's not that big a deal.  We just didn't hit it off.
Person2: Now, look, you-you-you go on ahead.
Person1: Are you okay?  You look-- You're sweatin'. ELLIOT  Yeah.  Yeah, I just-just need so- some-some fresh air.  It's probably something I ate.  I'll-I'll walk. You go ahead.

Person1: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
Person2: - and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
Person1: In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Person2: Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
Person1: No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
Person2: Let's not get over-dramatic.
Person1: You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

Person1: What do you want?
Person2: You know what I want.  You know why I need you.
Person1: You need to leave.
Person2: I know everything about you, Diana.
Person1: That's it, we're done.

Person1: ...you don't have to come in...
Person2: ...and rob the place...
Person1: ...I thought that we were only talking...
Person2: ...they take me, then.  They're going to ask me who were my accomplices.
Person1: Me?
Person2: Absolutely.
Person1: That's ridiculous.
Person2: Well, to the law, you're an accessory.  Before the fact.
Person1: I didn't ask to be.
Person2: Then tough luck, George, because you are.
Person1: Why?  Why, because you only told me about it?
Person2: That's right.
Person1: Why are you doing this to me, Dave. Why are you talking this way to me? I don't understand.  Why are you doing this at all...?
Person2: That's none of your business...

Person1: I want you to look at one another...
Person1: ...and ask a simple question -   Are you actually prepared...
Person1: ...to die for a country that's...
Person1: ...never done a thing for you?
Person1: Because if you don't give me that cylinder, your lives will end...
Person1: ...on this miserable road to nowhere.
Person1: And I can't guarantee the end will be quick.
Person2: Elvis is dead, man.  Get yourself some CDs.

Person1: Miss Beaufort has accepted our invitation.  By this we can only suppose that she wishes to come -- as we wish her to be here.
Person2: Your Majesty has had many women --
Person1: That is my desire, and my desire is what should concern you, not the sentiments of some commoner!
Person2: It is not Raoul's heart alone that concerns me.  It is yours.  I know you find women compliant -- especially the poorer ones like Michelle.  But do they love you?  Do you love them?  What about a queen to love?  A son of your own?
Person1: What quaint notions, d'Artagnan! But they contradict my father, who picked his queen when he was old, and only then to bear me.
Person2: There is more to love than he knew, or that you know.
Person1: You dare criticize my father?!  Or lecture me?!
Person2: Not criticize -- plead.  Love.  Love your people, and you will not bear to see them hungry.  Love women, and they will love you.  Love yourself, and --
Person1: That is enough!  You are a good servant, d'Artagnan, but you forget your place!
Person2: At least help Raoul.
Person1: Silence!  I order you!
Person2: Order Fromberge to keep him in safety!  It is the least you can do, to protect your own honor!
Person1: I will consider it.  Now leave me.
Person2: Thank you, your Majesty.

Person1: I'll go with ya.
Person2: What are you gonna do? Throw your teeth at 'em? Sit down, Cocoon.

Person1: The acceptance of a secret is an obligation and in this case my dear, the obligation carried with it the necessity of dying if one betrayed that secret. You understand that don't you?
Person2: Yes, I understand.
Person1: Then, you also understand that you must die.
Person2: No.

Person1: And?  Then?
Person2: I wonder no longer.  You were out of the country.
Person1: How could you know?
Person2: I sense...  The faintest whiff of a perfume, whose base, whose base, whose base is "Hamamelis" ... it is witch-hazel--such a clean scent.  No, not a European scent. I would say it is a scent of the New World.  I would say, you have been in America.  Have I struck home?
Person1: You know America?
Person2: ...you have brought this perfume... brought this perfume.  Back.  Back from America.  To your New Wife...  You have given it to her, and some of...  Some of 'her perfume' has found its way back onto you.  Lucky man.  Lucky man, indeed.

Person1: -- is that what this is all about?
Person2: Yes and you don't have to be sarcastic about it, that's a beautiful thing he's doing -- some people do more than go to the beauty parlor and shop at Saks --
Person1: Lester, you're a miserable man. You're not helping anybody. You're just twisting arms to raise money for a lot of silly son of a bitches that are out for themselves -- this is just business, don't kid yourself. And you know the worst thing about it, even if it does somebody some good somewhere which I can't possibly imagine, you'll never know the difference. You're just sweating and kidding yourself - and you're kidding yourself if you think your new business partner is going to keep his hands off that girl -- or that she'll keep her hands off him.
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: -- think what you have time to think, Lester.

Person1: The thing about it is, threesomes so rarely work out.

Person1: Well. If Mary Beth vouches for you, and if she told you the story already...
Person2: So here we are!
Person1: Mister Hebbing, we are talking about breaking the law here, I want to be sure you understand that. No one gets hurt, but the law does get broken.

Person1: I'd like to offer my congratulations. That was a beautiful gesture of Howard's.
Person2: Howard is a beautiful person.

Person2: And don't you worry about it.

Person1: Well, I'm trying to educate him!  It's nothing personal.

Person1: She's working as fast as she can, Icarus.  It will be ready soon.

Person1: It's terrible -- the price society demands in the name of fidelity... ultimately?

Person1: Open your eyes, she's eleven years old! Her only friend in the world is dead.
Person2: I know that, but what do you want from me?
Person1: Stop hiding Harry, you run Harry. When I first came here, the idea of working with dead people, didn't exactly thrill me, but when I saw a family lived here, I thought, if I'm living without a family, at least I can work with one, and maybe once in a while i'll be invited in for supper.
Person2: Yeah, and when those suppers are disrupted because there's a car crash, or there's a fire, or a little boy steps on a beehive.
Person1: I'm not asking you to stop feeling for those people. But life isn't just death Harry, don't ignore the living, especially your daughter.

Person1: Okay, he's on base.  Can we talk about my life now?  -- Ike's going to turn that tattoo stuff into a big deal -- that I was never serious about Gill, blah blah.  He's totally out to get me.

Person2: It's probably because you got him fired.

Person2: Not that he doesn't deserve to get fired... Look!  Cory's going for second!... Sneaky!

Person1: 'Snatch them up and put on a war crimes trial. Lock them all away forever. No political risk, and big publicity.' That's what he said.  I thought I'd better tell you.

That summer we spent our vacation at the Grand Canyon - we were standing on the highest ledge, watching the sunset - suddenly we had an impulse to kiss - I took off my glasses - I took a step toward her - she took a step toward me -

He said as long as there's no infection, you're not in any danger, and as soon as the road to the hospital is open, they'll send an ambulance for you.

Person1: I'm saying it because it's true. Inside of us we both know you belong with Victor. You're part of his work, the thing that keeps him going. If that plane leaves the ground and you're not with him, you'll regret it.

Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now...

He says you're lucky if you can get out while you could still cry.  I should have quit this place  three years ago.

Person1: And what I love about molecular science is the way it revolutionizes how we have to think.  It unifies the entire world on a single level. Everything is completely connected. Sometimes I can really feel it, everything around us, just a small part of a whole.  It's really wonderful.

Person1: The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.
Person2: What is that?
Person1: Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again.  For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.
Person2: But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?
Person1: No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.
Person2: But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna?  I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.
Person1: May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors.  Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.

Person1: Is there any chance a single aircraft can penetrate the entire enemy Air Defense, when its course and target are known?
Person2: If I can speak freely, sir -- look, these guys talk big, but frankly, we think they're short of know-how.  You can't just take a bunch of ignorant peasants and expect them to understand a machine like one of our boys, and I don't mean that as an insult, Mister Ambassador.  Hell, we all know what kind of guts your people have.  Why just look how many millions of 'em those Nazis  killed and, hell, they still wouldn't quit.
Person1: General, stick to the point, please.
Person2: Well, sir, if the A/C's a really good man, I mean really sharp, why he can barrel that plane along so low - well you just have to see it some time.  A real big plane, like a Sting Ray, zig-zagging in, its jet exhaust frying chickens in the barnyard ---  Has he a chance?.....Hell, yes!  He has one hell of a chance.

Person1: Yes... the Beautiful Carlotta... the Sad Carlotta...
Person2: What does a big old wooden house on the corner of Eddy and Gough Street have to do with her?
Person1: It was hers. It was built for her. Many years ago.
Person2: By whom?
Person1: By... no... the name I do not remember. A rich man, a powerful man.  It is not an unusual story. She came from somewhere small, to the south of the city... some say from a mission settlement... young, yes; very young.  And she was found singing and dancing in a cabaret by the man... wait... wait... Ives! His name was Ives!  Yes. And he took her and built for her this great house in the Western Addition... and there was a child. Yes. This was it. The child.

Bigger fish want to eat them. That luminous water -- it takes its gleam from millions of tiny dead bodies. It's the glitter of putrescence.  There's no beauty here -- it's death and decay.

Person1: Yeah, I felt that way, too, when I first started, but now... the hours, the repetition... it's not all glamour and mall openings anymore. Maybe I should've listened to my people and tried to make the crossover to nights earlier, I don't know...  ...I just hope it's not too late for me. God! Listen to me, "Me, me, me." It's so easy to get caught up in the whole ego cycle of this business and make it all about yourself. Stop, right? That's it, no more about me tonight, I promise... Let's talk about you... what do you think about me? I'm kidding... Seriously, Betty, I'm doing all the talking here...
Person2: ...but I love listening to you, so that's okay...
Person1: Thanks. But I'd like to hear what you're feeling...
Person2: Well, I just feel that life'll be much sweeter for you now with me around. I promise...
Person1: You know, I almost believe that... you're like a warm breeze that's suddenly blown into my life...  I said that to Leslie, once, at her funeral, remember?...
Person2: I remember. You said it to her, but it was meant for me, wasn't it?

Person1: Trust me, Claire.  You hear something... change the subject.  You find something... get rid of it, throw it in the lake.  You know what happened.  The rest is only details.  And no one's ever glad they got a hold of those.  If you want to put this back together...just let it go.

Person1: Chilton? Gruesome, isn't he? He fumbles at your head like a freshman pulling at a panty girdle.  He actually tries to give me a Thematic and Apperception test. Hah. Sat there waiting for MF-13 to come up. It's a card with a woman in bed and a man in the foreground.  I was supposed to avoid a sexual interpretation. I laughed in his face.  Never mind, it's boring.

Person1: I don't know.

Person2: We'll make you better.  We can put the pieces back.  We can do that.

Person2: We have to go home, Jason.

Person1: Keep it.

Person1: Most guys we ran through this either took off or helped them rob the place. I expected you to do the same.
Person2: That shows me already that you don't have a clue. What's it to you, anyway?
Person1: Whether you thought this was for real or not, you jumped in and helped the waitress on instinct. That tells me something about your character.
Person2: Good for you. Now why don't you stop wasting my time and tell me what you want. You didn't go through all this for my benefit.
Person1: It's your lucky day. You just might get the chance to pay back our wonderful country for all the freedom you enjoy.
Person2: A Fed, I shoulda known. Who else would have this kind of budget? Now you're gonna hit me with the sales pitch.
Person1: Alright, Cage, you've got me. This is one of those moments. "Many are called, few are chosen", that kind of thing. Your government needs you. Are you up for the challenge?
Person2: ..If you're trolling around for narcs, man, have you got the wrong guy.
Person1: Why is that?
Person2: Look at me, dude, do I look like a fan of law enforcement? Forget the tests, you shoulda just asked me. I woulda saved you a lot of trouble.
Person1: Oh I don't know, I think the tests work pretty well. Sometimes they give me answers you wouldn't admit to in a million years.
Person2: Are we done now? You've got nothing on me. So if you ain't booking me, I'm walking.
Person1: You've got this wrong. You're not under arrest, you've been abducted. And until I say different, you belong to me.
Person2: Is that a fact?
Person1: Sure as gravity. I've had a feeling about you from the start, Cage. It's nausea.
Person2: You know what I hate? Any scumbag with a clean shirt and a bad haircut can get one of those tin stars and suddenly they think they're God.
Person1: You know what I hate? It's always the assholes that pass the tests.

Person1: You're a very intelligent girl, Tracy. You have many admirable qualities.  But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.
Person2: Why are you lecturing me?
Person1: This isn't the time or the place to get into it, but there is, for just one example, a certain former colleague of mine, who made a very big mistake, a life mistake.  I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences. Person1: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. The projectors were run by hand, like this, with a crank. And you wound the crank all day long. It was really rough going! If you got tired and slowed down' boom! Everything would go up in flames!
Person2: Then why don't you want to teach it to me too? Now that there's no more cranking, and it's easier?
Person1: Because I don't want to, Toto! This is not a job for you. It's like being a slave. You're always alone. You see the same film over and over again, because you have nothing else to do. And you start talking to Greta Garbo and Tyrone Power like a nut! You work on holidays, on Christmas, on Easter. Only on Good Friday are you free. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!
Person2: Then why don't you change jobs?
Person1: Because I'm an idiot. How many other guys in town know how to be a projectionist? None! Only a jerk like me could do it. Besides I wasn't lucky. When I was a kid there was the war! When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!
Person2: No...
Person1: Good for you, Toto. Good for you... I'm only saying this for your own good...  Cooped up in here you die of heat in the summer and of cold in the winter. You breathe in smoke, gas fumes, and earn practically nothing.
Person2: But don't you like anything about what you do?
Person1: With time...you get used to it. Besides, when you hear from up here that there's a full house and that people are laughing, having fun... Then you're happy too.  So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!
Person2: Alfredo, go forget yourself!

Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment.  ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.

Person1: Then I'd be delighted. I hate eating alone, and it's amazing how often I end up doing just that.

Person1: Sheila? Yes she was. Is. Was.
Person2: There's old saying my mother told me. Would you like to hear it?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Don't shit where you eat.
Person1: I'll remember that. What do you do?
Person2: I'm a housewife.
Person1: Then why are you eating alone?
Person2: I'm not eating alone. Can I ask you a question?
Person1: Go ahead.
Person2: Why do men chase women?
Person1: Nerves.
Person2: I think it's because they fear death.
Person1: Maybe. Listen. You wanna know why I chase women? I find women charming.
Person1: I teach these classes I've taught for a million years. The spontaneity went out of it for me a long time ago. I started off, I was excited about something and I wanted to share it. Now it's rote, it's the multiplication table. Except sometimes. Sometimes I'm droning along and I look up, and there's this fresh young beautiful face, and it's all new to her and I'm this great guy who's just brilliant and thinks out loud. And when that happens, when I look out among those chairs and look at a young woman's face, and see me there in her eyes, me the way I always wanted to be and maybe once was, then I ask her out on a date. It doesn't last. It can go for a few weeks or a couple of precious months, but then she catches on that I'm just a burnt out old gasbag and that she's as fresh and bright and full of promise as moonlight in a martini. And at that moment, she stands up and throws a glass of water in my face, or some action to that effect.
Person2: What you don't know about women is a lot.

Person1: Captain, I've been observing the nurses on your shift. But naturally your own opinion is more informed than mine.

Person2: That's right. We work well together.
Person1: Major Burns is far from satisfied.
Person2: That don't surprise me. If you're a good observer, you must have observed by now that Frank Burns is a jerk.
Person1: On the contrary, I've observed he's not only a good technical surgeon, he's a good military surgeon. And that includes how a man dresses and how he bears himself and his sense of what it means to be an officer in the United States Army.
Person2: And his track record, that don't count? Look, honey, when you watch the two shifts try to notice which one does the most work with the least fuss.
Person1: I've noticed that both nurses and enlisted men address you as 'Hawkeye.'
Person2: It's my name. Maybe that sounds silly to you but...
Person1: That kind of familiarity is inconsistent with maximum efficiency in a military organization.
Person2: Okay, Major, honey.  I'm going to have a couple shots scotch and go to bed. I'd normally ask you to join me but obviously you're a female version of the routine Regular Army clown. And that turns me off, so just leave my outfit alone and we'll get along fine.  See you around the campus.
Person1: I wonder how a degenerated person like you could have reached a position of responsibility in the Army Medical Corps.

Person1: I was sent as a military surgeon to South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken prisoner. Home on parole not to fight. I was a surgeon in the Great War till the end. Grenade in the face. Carried diphtheria bacilli in the wound until 1920. Isolated two years.  I've been everything.

I mean, I felt like I wanted to tell you something, but I didn't put it in the letter, and I didn't say it, but I want to say it now, I'm not sure if I should say it, you know, 'cause people always say it and don't mean it, but I think that I mean it, so, um, I just wanted to tell you...

Person1: So whaddya think?
Person2: Well, I'm not really sure what you're trying to say. It's funny, I suppose. But it seems glib and facile to just make fun of how idiotic these people are.

Person1: You don't know nothing about it.
Person2: I was raised that a girl gets married young. I didn't get married until I was twenty-eight. I met a man. I loved him. I married him. He wanted to have a baby right away. I said no. Then he got hit by a bus. No man. No baby. No nothing! I did not know that man was a gift I could not keep. I didn't know... You tell me a story and you think you know what it means, but I see what the true story is, and you can't.  She didn't leave you! You can't see what you are. I can see everything. You are a wolf!
Person1: I'm a wolf?
Person2: The big part of you has no words and it's-a wolf. This woman was a trap for you. She caught you and you could not get away.  So you chewed off your foot! That was the price you had to pay to be free.  Johnny had nothing to do with it. You did what you had to do, between you and you, and I know I'm right, I don't care what you say. And now you're afraid because you found out the big part of you is a wolf that has the courage to bite off its own hand to save itself from the trap of the wrong love. That's why there has been no woman since that wrong woman. You are scared to death what the wolf will do if you make that mistake again!
Person1: What are you doing!
Person2: I'm telling you your life!
Person1: Stop it!
Person2: No!
Person1: Why are you marrying Johnny? He's a fool!
Person2: Because I have no Luck!
Person1: He made me look the wrong way and I cut off my hand. He could make you look the wrong way and you could cut off your whole head!
Person2: I am looking where I should to become a bride!
Person1: A bride without a head!
Person2: A wolf without a foot!

Since there was no evidence on that spacecraft that anybody knew time travel through a black hole was possible -- and we all knew -- then we would all have to die before we could tell anyone. Death was the only logical explanation.  But sitting here, we still know.  So how is that possible?  Unless we make ourselves forget.

Person1: Go live in a safe-deposit box--with your things. LOOSELEAF Jesus--I wouldn't want to be married to him.  You know?

Person1: You did?
Person2: Yeah.  I practically forgot.  But after you busted that thing, I got to thinking, "Jesus--maybe I'll start the violin again." That didn't just belong to Woodly.  That belonged to everybody.  Maybe he would have sold it to me, and I could have some fun.  After you busted the violin, boy, and Penelope walked out, I thought to myself, "Jesus--who could blame her?"
Person1: Maybe it's time you got out.

Person1: You.
Person2: Okay.  Okay.
Person1: You're an imbecile.

Person1: If what?
Person2: If I hadn't done it.  If I'd said to myself, "Screw it.  I'm going to let all those people down there live."
Person1: They were enemies.  We were at war.
Person2: Yeah, Jesus--but wars would be a lot better, I think, if guys would say to themselves sometimes, "Jesus--I'm not going to do that to the enemy.  That's too much." You could have been the manufacturer of that violin there, even though you don't know how to make a violin, just by not busting it up.  I could have been the father of all those people in Nagasaki, and the mother, too, just by not dropping the bomb.  I sent 'em to Heaven instead--and I don't think there is one.
Person1: Goodbye, Looseleaf.

Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?

Do you believe you're entitled or at least expect to draw breath in the a.m.?  Open your eyes in the morning?  I don't think you do...I don't think so... Person1: I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "Jew."

You know, I was having lunch with some guys from NBC, so I said... uh, "Did you eat yet or what?" and Tom Christie said, "No, didchoo?" Not, did you, didchoo eat? Jew? No, not did you eat, but Jew eat? Jew. You get it? Jew eat?
Person2: Ah, Max, you, uh...

Listen to this- so I know there's this big tall blond crew-cutted guy and he's lookin' at me in a funny way and smiling and he's saying, "Yes, we have a sale this week on Wagner." Wagner, Max, Wagner- so I know what he's really tryin' to tell me very significantly Wagner.
Person2: Right, Max. California, Max.

Person2: Let's get the hell outta this crazy city.
Person1: Forget it, Max.

Person1: What do you want, Senator?
Person2: Saunders--it's going to go pretty bad for Jeff tomorrow. There's only one thing that can be done for him now--  I--I've written his resignation. He resigns under protest--denying all charges. No one will ever be sure if he was guilty or not. It leaves him with at least a shred of honor. The other way--branded openly in the Senate--expelled--he'll never live it down. Rather a simple compromise than utter ruin. In a year--the whole thing might be forgotten--
Person1: What are you driving at? You want me to get him to sign that?
Person2: Yes--
Person1: Why don't you do it yourself?
Person2: He's lost complete faith in me--
Person1: Well--me, too!
Person2: But--you love him, don't you, Saunders?
Person1: What are you talking about? What difference--?
Person2: Do you?
Person1: All right--yes! And what does that make me to him? Nothing! I've got to go about my own business--and forget it!
Person2: I thought I could, too.  My business--this fine future! I have no future I care about, if this boy is broken! I--I can't sleep. The only important thing in my life now is to save what I can for him. I want him to get a start again--I'll see that he's taken care of as long as he lives--!  Saunders--whether you ever mean anything to him or not--
Person1: Me! Me ! I still don't see why I should--! If you love him so much, why don't you go to him yourself and-- ? Or better still--get up in that Senate and fight for him!
Person2: It's too late now--it's impossible!
Person1: So I go right back where I was-- carrying compromises--covering up-- back to political tricks--this time for--! No! I was just getting rid of all that. If I did anything, I ought to go and tell him to stand up and--. No! I don't want any part of it! Smith or anything else! I'm all through. I want to be left alone!

Person1: Zachory ! My boy, how goes the carnage down on 44 ?
Person2: Not that well sir. I believe we have a few too many soft hearts in the building. Did we aquire a bank from Chicago or a charity ?
Person1: Relax, son. They'll learn in time that you don't mess with First Bank. This is the real deal and we aim to keep it strong. My Daddy always told me that Only The Strong Survive.
Person2: I thought that was Darwin, sir. Or perhaps Nietzsche ?
Person1: Perhaps it was. I was in boarding school for so many years, it's hard to remember. Do you have the tape of the latest exploits from my favorite hobby ?

Person1: I have to say, that I am glad you are such an amazing kiss ass.
Person2: Thank you , sir. Sir, may I ask you a question ?

Person2: While I am not morally against these little, shall we say "hobbies", as long as I am on the payroll, but why not something like a yacht club ?

Person2: I am thirty two.

Person2: I make roughly four hundred thousand a year.
Person1: Zach my boy, I can spend your yearly salary in a blink. I have had that kind of money all of my life. If I wanted to, I could fly to Paris for the afternoon.  My father formed this company over seventy years ago. When my brother became mentally challenged, it was put in my charge. Now running a bank of this size is very stressful. I need to relax on what little down time I have. A yacht club will not quite make my blood pressure decline. Understand ?
Person2: Yes sir.
Person1: I have entrusted you with a great many things. In your tenure with this company you have seen and heard things that could upset the very economic world in which we live. I think this kind of loyalty should be rewarded.
