Person1: ...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.
Person2: Your doctor?  Did your doctor say anything about a tiny, undetectable hole in your aorta?  Did he mention an irreparab- ly weak vein in the further reaches of your famous brain?  Were there any prognostications about the possibil- ilites of a fatal collision on a golf cart or suffocating in an avalanche on a ski vacation in Gstaad?
Person1: No --
Person2: I hope you realize, Bill...in your office this morning, that was your time.
Person1: Closer than that.

Person1: All right, sugar, what's on your mind?
Person2: Don't look at me like that. Auggie. It gives me the creeps.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like what you're doing. I'm not going to eat you up.  I need your help, and if you keep staring at me like that. I might start screaming.
Person1: Help, huh? And I don't suppose this help has anything to do with money, does it?
Person2: Don't rush me, okay? You're jumping to conclusions before I've even said anything.  And besides, it's not for me.  It's for our daughter.
Person1: Our daughter? Is that what you said? Our daughter? I mean, you might have a daughter, but I sure as hell don't. And even if I did -- which I don't -- she wouldn't be our daughter.
Person2: Her name is Felicity, and she just turned eighteen.  She ran away from Pittsburgh last year, and now she's living in some shit-hole here in Brooklyn with a guy named Chico. Strung out on crack, four months pregnant.  I can't bear to think about that baby. Our grandchild, Auggie. Just think of it. Our grandchild.
Person1: Stop it, already. Just stop all this crap right now.  Was that your idea to call her Felicity?
Person2: It means "happiness."
Person1: I know what it means. That still don't make it a good name.
Person2: I don't know who else to turn to, Auggie.
Person1: You've suckered me before, darling, remember? Why should I believe you now?
Person2: Why would I lie to you, Auggie? You think it was easy to come here and walk into this place? Why would I do it if I didn't have to?
Person1: That's what you told me when I shoplifted that necklace for you. You remember, baby, don't you? The judge gave me a choice, either go to the can or enlist. So, instead of going to college, I wind up in the navy for four years, I watch men lose their arms and legs, I nearly get my head blown off, and you, sweet Ruby McNutt, you run off and marry that asshole, Bill.
Person2: You didn't write to me for more than a year. What was I supposed to think?
Person1: Yeah, well, I lost my pen. By the time I got a new one, I was clean out of paper.
Person2: It was over with Bill before you ever came home. Maybe you don't remember it now, but you were pretty hot to see me back then.
Person1: You weren't so lukewarm yourself. At least at first.
Person2: It fizzled, baby. That's the way it goes. But we had our times, didn't we? It wasn't all bad.
Person1: A couple of moments, I'll grant you that. A second or two snatched from the jaws of eternity.
Person2: And that's how Felicity came into the picture. During one of those two seconds.
Person1: You're conning me, sweetheart. I ain't responsible for no baby.
Person2: Then why do you think I married Frank? I was already pregnant, and I didn't have much time. Say what you like, but at least he gave my kid a name.
Person1: Good old Frank. And how is fat Mr. Grease Monkey these days?
Person2: Who the hell knows?  He dropped out of sight fifteen years ago.
Person1: Fifteen years ago?  It won't wash, pumpkin. No mother waits fifteen years to tell a man he's a father. I wasn't born yesterday, you know.
Person2: I thought I could handle it. I didn't want to bug you. I thought I could handle it on my own, but I couldn't. She's in real bad, Auggie.
Person1: Nice try, old girl. I'd like to help you out. You know, for old time's sake. But all my spare cash is tied up in a business venture, and I haven't collected my profits yet. Too bad. You caught me at the wrong time.
Person2: You're a cold-hearted bastard, aren't you? How'd you ever get so mean, Auggie?
Person1: I know you think I'm lying to you, but I'm not. Every word I told you is the God's honest truth.

Person1: Yes, sure, we did go to San Remo. That was months ago.
Person2: November, I thought.
Person1: Was it? Did you speak to Tom?
Person2: November 7th is my information.
Person1: I don't remember the exact date.
Person2: And when did you last see Signor Ripley?
Person1: A few days ago.
Person2: Does he stay with you here?
Person1: No!
Person2: No. Here is a pattern. Two days ago Freddie Miles is dead -- he leaves your apartment and is murdered. Yesterday a little boat is found in San Remo full of rocks, and the owner tells the Police it was stolen on November 7th. We look at hotel records and we see oh! Dickie Greenleaf is staying in San Remo and then our boatman remembers two Americans taking a boat.
Person1: It's not a pattern, it's a coincidence. There must be fifty hotels in San Remo, there must have been a hundred people renting a boat on that day.
Person2: 31 people.
Person1: 31 people.

Person1: Do yourself a favor, Norman.  Are you listening?  Don't tell anyone what you just told me.
Person2: C'mon, Beth -- that report's like the blind leading the blind.
Person1: Because when we get down there --
Person2: Wait -- down where?
Person1: To the spacecraft.  To investigate.
Person2: Underwater?
Person1: What do you expect?  For them to bring it up here?
Person2: We can't go down there.  We're not prepared.  That deep?  That takes years of training, Beth.  We're just scientists.  Lab scietists.  We wear ties and lab coats to work -- not oxygen tanks.
Person1: Well, you must have realized the chances an encounter like this would happen here.  In the ocean.  70 percent of the earth's surface is water, Norman.  That's first grade geography.
Person2: It never occurred to me.
Person1: Well, let's pray that's the only mistake you made.  Have you said anything to Barnes about this?
Person2: The timing has never seemed quite right.
Person1: Just keep your mouth shut, alright? This could mean everything to our careers, you know that?  Don't jeopardize this.
Person2: What -- are you threatening me?

Person1: Who are you?

Person1: Oh, I like the sound of that.., Amy and her friend... Amy and her friend.

Person1: What is it, mother?
Person2: I wish to discuss your brother.
Person1: He is dead!  By God's choice!  There is nothing to discuss.
Person2: First they told me he had died at birth.  Then your father admitted he was alive, but well cared for, in secret.  But the message that told of his death said he had been a prisoner.
Person1: I am King, Mother!  And I do not wish to discuss this with you.
Person2: He was my blood -- and I demand to know what happened to him.
Person1: Why would you ask now?  You never asked before!
Person2: Because I have dreamed of him.  Not as the baby they took away, but as a man.

Person1: How's it feel, Tommy?
Person2: Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?
Person1: Looks like you done it.
Person2: I kinda thought so. Felt like it.
Person1: Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.
Person2: They killed Casy first.
Person1: That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.
Person2: They know what--this fella looks like?
Person1: They know he got hit in the face.
Person2: I'm sorry, Ma. But--I didn't know what I was doin', no more'n when you take a breath. I didn't even know I was gonna do it.
Person1: It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.
Person2: I'm gonna go away tonight. I can't go puttin' this on you folks.
Person1: Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us.  They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Ol' folks died off, an' little fellas come, an' we was always one thing-- we was the fambly--kinda whole an' clear. But now we ain't clear no more. They ain't nothin' keeps us clear. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn--  --she gonna have her baby, but it ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.
Person2: Okay, Ma. I shouldn't, though. I know I shouldn't. But okay.

Person1: We can't go back there.  Are you crazy? You saw --

Person1: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.
Person2: You did?
Person1: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.
Person2: Over a girl?
Person1: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?
Person2: No, I don't.
Person1: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here --  -- you know where I finally shot myself?
Person2: Where?
Person1: Here.
Person2: In the knee?
Person1: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!
Person2: That's terrible.
Person1: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.
Person2: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?
Person1: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake.  And you want to see my knee?

Person1: Five?
Person2: Five.
Person1: So, basically, I've got the life expectancy of a zit, right?
Person2: Not if you're careful.
Person1: How can you keep doing this?
Person2: It's what I was raised to do.  There aren't many of us left, the Watchers.
Person1: Watchers?
Person2: There's a small village in Hampshire, near Stonehenge...  ... near a bunch of big rocks. That's where I was born.  My father taught me about the training, about finding the Slayers, reading the signs.  There's a small cluster of us, a few families, really... most of the neighboring villagers think we're just a bunch of harmless old loonies.  I thought so myself for a time, when I was younger...  I'm sorry.  I'm not supposed to... I shouldn't go on like this.
Person1: I wish you would.
Person2: It isn't important.
Person1: I'm curious, is all.
Person2: Buffy, don't... don't start thinking of me as your friend.  It interferes with the work, and it...
Person1: And it makes it worse when I die, right?

Person1: Your place or mine?
Person2: Despite my love of weird metaphysics and my rejection of most Judao-Christian ethics, I am, within the framework of a baseball season, monogamous.
Person1: Fact is you're afraid of meeting a guy like me 'cause It might be real so you sabotage it with some bullshit about commitment to a young boy you can boss around--  Great deal.  You get to write self- indulgent little poems all winter about how hard it is to find a man even though you just sent him packing-  So what do you really want?  You wanta be a tragic woman figure wallowing in the bullshit of magic?  Or do you want a guy?

Person1: Otherwise the police will come to see you and your wife and children will be dishonored and destitute. Of course, if my information as to your gains is incorrect, I'll dip my beak just a little.  Just a little, but no less than one hundred dollars, and don't try to deceive me, eh paisan?

Person1: What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.
Person2: I need to make a telephone call.
Person1: A telephone call?  That's communication with the outside world!  Doctor's discretion.  Hey, if alla these nuts could just make phone calls, it could spread.  Insanity oozing through telephone cables, oozing into the ears of all those poor sane people, infecting them!  Whackos everywhere!  A plague of madness.  In fact, very few of us here are actually mentally ill.  I'm not saying you're not mentally ill, for all I know you're crazy as a loon.  But that's not why you're here.  Why you're here is because of the system, because of the economy.  There's the TV.  It's all right there. Commercials.  We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. But if you don't buy a lot of stuff, you know what?  You're mentally ill! That's a fact!  If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices...  SCREWDRIVERS WITH MINIATURE BUILT-IN RADAR DEVICES, STEREO SYSTEMS WITH BRAIN IMPLANTED HEADPHONES, VOICE- ACTIVATED COMPUTERS, AND...

Person1: I went on the Internet and found this article about you... It says you're a Horse Whisperer, that you... you help people with horse problems. And you have quite a success rate when it comes to traumatized --
Person2: Well, see, truth is, ma'am, I help horses with people's problems.
Person1: Well, you know, however you want to put it -- I got your information from the publisher of the article. I called Montana and your sister-in-law, I think, gave me this number.  I'm been hot on your trail you could say because I was hoping you'd consider coming to New York and taking a look at my daughter's horse and possibly --
Person2: Ma'am, I'm very sorry about your problems and I appreciate what your daughter must be going through, but I'm afraid you've misunderstood whatever it is you read. I don't do that sort of thing.

Person2: Look, even if it was nearer, that's just not what I do. I give clinics. And I'm not even doing them for a while. I'm heading back to Montana right now. I got a ranch to take care of...

Person1: He's got your prick in his back pocket, son, and you're standing naked in the display window of Macy's. He's using you. Only you're too blind to see it.

Person1: Private Johnson, are you unhappy in the Army?
Person2: No, sir--
Person1: Then how would you explain the fact that out of one hundred twenty people we tested, you're the only one who came up positive for drugs?
Person2: I'm sorry, sir.

Person1: You wanted by the law or somethin'?

Person1: You're crazy carryin' that kinda money in this neighborhood.  No wonder you got hit.
Person2: Thanks.  I'm obliged to ya, but I gotta get goin'.
Person1: You ain't goin' nowhere on that leg.
Person2: I gotta!  Look, I run some slots down in West Bend for a mob here. I got a little behind on my payoffs so they figure I been holdin' out on 'em.  They gave me to 4:00 to come up with the cash.  I don't get it there I'm dead.
Person1: It don't look good, gramps, it's ten of now.
Person2: I got a hundred bucks for you and your friend if you deliver the money for me.
Person1: I dunno.  That little mug that got ya is mad enough at me already -- what if he's out there waitin' around a corner with some friends.
Person2: He won't know you're carryin' it. C'mon, you gotta help me out.
Person1: Sorry, pal.  I'll fix you up, call you a doc, but I ain't gonna walk into a bunch of knives for ya.
Person2: How bout you?  I'll give you the whole hundred!
Person1: What makes you think you can trust him?  He didn't do shit.

Person1: Now... here we have two very handsome soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose hens mind what happens to their eggs? Probably not. They have such unfeeling eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of butter, plenty of pepper and salt... Darling, I haven't seen you for three livelong days... seventy-two hours!
Person2: Oh, please, Swana! I don't know whether I'm standing on my head or my heels. Here you are blaming me for neglecting you when I'm trying to concentrate on another woman and can't get near her.
Person1: You haven't seen her yet?
Person2: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...
Person1: That proletarian! In the old days we'd have had her flogged.
Person2: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her.  She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.
Person1: You just told me you hadn't seen her.
Person2: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of her when she walked through the lobby.
Person1: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?
Person2: You can't imagine.
Person1: That bad?  Old or young?
Person2: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli. What a woman! What a woman! There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes.
Person1: You saw all that in one glimpse?
Person2: Darling, if we're going to get anywhere someone has to keep his eyes open!
Person1: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful pine bath and let Gaston shave you.

Like, I can smell your sheets, Norman.  You tried to wash it out earlier, But I can still smell the urine.  Don't worry, I'm not going to tell the others.  It's normal, really, isn't it?  In a crisis.  The stress. The panic.

Person1: I want to ask you a big favor, Gordon. Please drop the Bluestar deal.
Person2: Now tell me, why would I want to do that?

Person2: Don't worry Sunshine. Bud and I had a little talk. We came to an understanding.  I want you to go back to him. Soothe him. Help keep his head straight. Okay?
Person1: I can't...and I won't.
Person2: Come on, we both like Buddy. But this bleeding heart puppy love act is over the top... It doesn't fit.
Person1: Maybe it does. Don't patronize me Gordon.
Person2: You and I are the same, Darien. We're smart enough not to buy into the oldest myth running: love... A fiction created by people who got nothing to keep them from jumping out of windows.
Person1: You're really twisted, Gordon. You're incapable of giving to anybody because deep down inside you there's a poverty that every last dollar in the world won't fill.
Person2: Ooh ooh, tough talk from a scared little girl all wrapped in a pretty grown-up package. Does this mean you're ready to cut the umbilical cord and step out into the world on your own? Because, Darien, if you're through with me, you're through with everything I'm a part of.

Person1: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...

Person1: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?
Person2: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.

Person2: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?
Person1: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.
Person2: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over.  I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.
Person1: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.
Person2: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.
Person1: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?
Person2: I just can't trust you anymore.
Person1: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...
Person2: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!
Person1: But what has to be different?
Person2: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.
Person1: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?
Person2: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.
Person1: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us.  ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian!

Person1: Well, it does smudge after all--isn't that fascinating?

"You bought the wrong paper, Annie. I can't write on this paper, Annie." Well, I'll get your stupid paper, but you just better start showing me a little more appreciation around here, Mister Man.

Person2: Wow. You did that for me?

Person2: Oh, shit.

Person1: All in good time, Mister McMurphy. All in good time.
Person2: Yes, ma'am.
Person1: Good. Now if you'll just go along with Mister Washington, he'll see that you're properly oriented.

Person1: I'm feeling too good to fight with you, but that isn't what I said - I said you snoop.  For instance, what were you doing around my hotel the other night?
Person2: Begging your pardon, I haven't been down the bowery in years!

Person1: No, wait, no WAIT, that's too much, man, that's like overkill, nobody can take that much, you're wasting it -- !
Person2: Your pain ends now.

Person1: You want to get married...?
Person2: You tol me you wuunt ask me again til I'm ready....
Person1: You're ready now.
Person2: I'm not.
Person1: That's what you think...

Person1: Bonasera, we know each other for years, but this is the first time you come to me for help.  I don't remember the last time you invited me to your house for coffee...even though our wives are friends.
Person2: What do you want of me?  I'll give you anything you want, but do what I ask!
Person1: And what is that Bonasera?

Person1: You didn't come here to destroy Wintermute. You can to save a man you love. A man who isn't even capable of returning that love. Such a waste...
Person2: My man's coming to get my ass out of here. That's good enough for me.
Person1: Pity. Then you'll both have to die.

Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: You are writing another book, aren't you? That's why you're here. The story's not over.
Person1: You're getting obvious.
Person2: No, Gale, I'm just getting started. Seeya soon.
Person1: No, wait...
Person2: Watch your back.

Person1: I went to your place.  We talked, just like you told me.  We drove out into the desert . . .
Person2: Is the job done?
Person1: No.
Person2: You didn't kill her?
Person1: The time wasn't right.
Person2: You're out in the desert, the middle of nowhere with no one around for miles, and you say the time wasn't right?  What's the matter?  You were hoping to get it on home video?  A keepsake for the grandkids.  Thank God I waited, or I never would have gotten it on tape.
Person1: You know what I mean.
Person2: I know all right.  I know you're just enough of a shit to have a go at bedding a man's wife.  You've probably bagged a few at that. You'd probably lie, cheat and steal without thinking twice.  From that you'd just turn and walk away.  But to kill; to get that blood on your hands.  You can't wash that off. You'd be a marked man for life. Just like Cain.  And you're a sinner who wants to walk with the saints. Ain't that right, boy?
Person1: You know so much about killing why don't you do it yourself?
Person2: I guess I have what you'd call a love-hate relationship with Grace.
Person1: You love her, but you hate her?
Person2: I hate loving her.  I hate the kind of her person she is.  I hate having to tolerate the little games she plays.  I hate letting her use me. But I love her too much to do otherwise.  And I certainly love her too much to kill her.  I couldn't stand to watch her eyes roll back in her head as she sucks her last breath, or to see her pretty pink brains spill from her skull.  But you?  You got the killing in you, boy.
Person1: Shut up.
Person2: Came close this time and it scares you.
Person1: Drop it, Jake.
Person2: And next time, next time somebody is going to get dead.
Person1: SHUT UP!

Person1: ... How long was I asleep?
Person2: Long enough to die.  Listen, if you really want to die, that's your problem, but don't do it under my nose, okay?

Person1: Comical part of it is, it isn't what you want at all. In a couple of weeks you'll be looking for the nearest exit . . .  People like you spend all your life on a merry-go-round. I guess that's what makes you so dizzy.  You're always chasing after something. At least you think you are. Truth is, you're just running away.  From yourself, mostly. 'Cause you're miserable. You hate yourself. The world's full of people like you. Don't know what they want.
Person2: Do you know?

Person1: Elaborate on 'they,' okay?
Person2: There are all kinds of groups, all kinds of initials.  But they're all part of two warring factions. One: families that have held wealth for centuries. They want one thing.  Stability. Group Two:  the boat rockers. Eisenhower's military industrial complex.  They want instability. It's a trillion dollar a year business.  When there isn't a hot war, they make a cold one.
Person1: Cold War's over, Jerry.
Person2: So now they feed us terrorists. To create fear.  How much do you think an airport security system goes for?  Then multiply it by every airport in the country.
Person1: And you think Group One is at war with Group Two.
Person2: Latest casualty?  Ernest Harriman. You heard of him?
Person1: Sure. One of the richest men in America until he died a few days ago.
Person2: His obituary was in every paper. But not one of them said he was murdered.
Person1: Murdered?
Person2: Right here in Manhattan.
Person1: It said in the paper he drowned in a swimming pool.  In Newport.
Person2: Nobody dies in Newport.  They couldn't even kill Sunny von Bulow there.  Harriman drowned, but it wasn't in Newport.
Person1: Where then?

Person1: Help me with this one, I'm really screwed up.
Person2: Bring it left. Bring it left, You're high.
Person1: This is crazy!
Person2: What is?
Person1: Wait! Hell!..Something's wrong!
Person2: What?  What is it?
Person1: Were upside down!
Person2: You're crazy. We're level.
Person1: Can't you feel it? I'm hanging in my straps!
Person2: You're not. We're level. Look at the instruments, we're okay!
Person1: They must be broken. I'm hanging in my straps! We're inverted!
Person2: We're not! Trust me! We're okay.

Person1: Oh, Judy!! When he had all her money, and the freedom and the power...  he ditched you? What a shame! But he knew he was safe. You couldn't talk. Didn't he give you anything?
Person2: Some money.
Person1: And the necklace. Carlotta's necklace. That was your mistake, Judy. One shouldn't keep souvenirs of a killing. You shouldn't have been that sentimental.

Person1: He's right, Kate. Daddy's dead! He was too far away. If flinging that door and filling this room with those bat-things would save him, I'd fling it. The only thing it'll do is turn us into one of them.
Person2: He needs our help!
Person1: He's beyond our help. You saw him get bit. I saw him get bit. We all saw it. You can't help him. I've got no one left to lose but you. I can't be alone again. We're sticking together.

Person1: ARE YOU CRAZY?
Person2: She didn't need our help getting anywhere... where did she get these convenient clothes? And don't tell me that flare is standard prison issue...

Person1: I need to get my suitcase out of the garage.
Person2: What for?
Person1: I'm going back home with Harry.
Person2: I've heard some foolish things in my life.
Person1: Harry is coming to pick me up.
Person2: Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.
Person1: I'm busy.
Person2: Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.
Person1: Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.
Person2: I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  You sit right there with your no manners self.

Person1: That's the whole point, Jeffrey. That's the whole point. Anyone's. Everyone's. They are gonna look under every rock, dig up every flaw, every mistake you've ever made. They are going to distort and exaggerate everything you've ever done, man. Don't you understand?
Person2: What does this have to do with my testimony?
Person1: That's not the point.
Person2: What does this have to do with my testimony?! I told the truth! It's valid and true and provable!
Person1: That's not the point, whether you told the truth or not! Hello...?
Person2: I told the truth... I told the truth.

Person1: This is just what they want, Buddy. Don't you see it?  They want to drive us apart.  To beat us.  We can't let them do it.  We've been through too much together, Buddy ... We belong together.
Person2: That's what you said the first time we met.  You didn't even know me.

Person1: No, Daddy. Our business is journalism. We can't continue to be so irresponsible . . . or else we'll just lead everyone into a disaster.
Person2: Don't be over-dramatic, young lady. What kind of disaster could we help bring about?

Person1: ...See you tomorrow night.
Person2: Include me out.  I've had enough of the conversations.

Person2: Daddy'll do fine.  Besides, he's got Joe.  And so do you.

Person2: That may be.  But I don't like that guy.  I don't like the way he looks at you and talks to you.  And vice versa.
Person1: Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me.  And vice versa. Okay?
Person2: No, not okay.  I thought we had a good thing going here.  It shows you never know.

Person1: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.
Person2: All set for what?

Person2: Atlantic City?

Person2: Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.

Person2: He wouldn't.

Person2: I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.

Oh, by the way, you might want to take a look at these..if you have any further qualms about getting her to do the job.

Person1: Mommy?  It's not Rachel's fault I ran away.

Person1: Rachel's job is she works.
Person2: Ben, mommies work too.  They work very hard.  Mommy works harder as a mom than she did when she was working.  I just don't get paid.
Person1: Does Rachel make a lot of money?
Person2: People like Rachel who only think about themselves often do make a lot of money.
Person1: I think she's pretty, Mommy.
Person2: Yes...if you like big hair...
Person1: Mommy?
Person2: What honey?
Person1: If you want me to hate her I will.

Person1: Forget it. You're just all talk. So, when are you done with those meetin's?
Person2: Week after I'm twenty-one.
Person1: Are they hookin' you up with a job?
Person2: Yeah, sit in a room and do long division for the next fifty years.
Person1: Yah, but it's better than this shit. At least you'd make some nice bank.
Person2: Yeah, be a researcher.
Person1: It's a way outta here.
Person2: What do I want a way outta here for? I want to live here the rest of my life. I want to be your next door neighbor. I want to take out kids to little league together up Foley Field.
Person1: Look, you're my best friend, so don't take this the wrong way, but in 20 years, if you're living next door to me, coming over watching the Patriots' games and still working construction, I'll be really upset with you. And that's not a threat, that's a fact. I'll be really upset with you.
Person2: Chuckie, what are you talkin'...
Person1: Listen, you got somethin' that none of us have.
Person2: Why is it always this? I owe it to myself? What if I don't want to?
Person1: Forget you. You owe it to me. Tomorrow I'm gonna wake up and I'll be fifty and I'll still be doing this. And that's all right 'cause I'm gonna make a run at it. But you, you're sitting on a winning lottery ticket and you're too scared to cash it in. And that's nonsense 'cause I'd do anything to have what you got! And so would any of these guys. It'd be a real shame if you're still here in twenty years.
Person1: Let me tell you what I do know. Every day I come by to pick you up, and we go out drinkin' or whatever and we have a few laughs. But you know what the best part of my day is? The ten seconds before I knock on the door 'cause I let myself think I might get there, and you'd be gone. I'd knock on the door and you wouldn't be there. You just left.

Person1: I hate to turn on this light, you Daddy's awake downstairs, but I have to take the chance.  Buddy, please don't tell on me.
Person2: I said I wouldn't.
Person1: Buddy, I have to ask you, as bad as I've been please have pity on me and don't ruin me by telling them what I did. I know it was bad, it was bad and dumb. But mostly it was dumb, I didn't mean you no harm, I'd never want to hurt a hair on your head and that's the truth. I love you. But they'd think I did, they'd think I was awful, they'd despise me and hate me...

Person2: We're on our third pitcher of beer. Just ask me.

Person1: No, I...
Person2: Why don't you cut the shit and ask if you can stay at my place?

Person2: I want you to hit me as hard as you can.

Person1: Your sister said she didn't know where you were so you shouldn't write to her with return address if you're hiding.
Person2: Did you hurt her?
Person1: You know me...I never hurt anybody. Where's the money?

Person1: Today, I'm offering you a lousy job at a lousy wage.  You think you're better than that?  Fine.  Show me.  Show me that you're really willing to change and we'll talk about something better. A lot better.  But first, Jack, you gotta earn it.
Person2: How, Dick?  The way you earned it?  By marrying some rich broad owns the company, selling it off a piece at a time, then divorcing her?  What is this Knute Rockne, pull yourself up by the bootstraps bullshit?  Back in prison, guy like you, place like that, you were ice cream for freaks.  You were a goddamn dumpling.  Maurice and a dozen other guys coulda bled you till you had nothing.  Till you were nothing.  I saved your ass.  So you'll pardon me if I don't wanna sit on a damn stool all day saying "sign in here please" or "hey, pal, you can't park there."  Okay, Dick?  I can't do it.
Person1: Jack, I'm disappointed.  I guess I misjudged you.

Person1: What about Elliot Harmsway? Or is this just another one of your stunts?
Person2: No! He's crazy - he's insane. He hates everybody. He's got these plans -  You've got to help me, James. I'm sorry. I'm sorry for everything. I know I was wrong - but you've got to protect me. I know you still love -

Person1: Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.
Person2: I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.
Person1: But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?
Person2: But it is what I want.
Person1: To be killed in battle?
Person2: If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever.

Person1: I just came to say goodbye.
Person2: Where are you going?
Person1: Back to the city. I may take off to Europe for the rest of the summer. I just can't handle it around here.
Person2: I think that's for the best.
Person1: Good for you.
Person2: Sebastian, please. I don't want us to end on bad terms.
Person1: Well, I'm afraid you don't have a choice in the matter. You make me sick. You're a hypocrite and I don't associate with hypocrites.

Person1: I sacrificed so much to make sure you were comfortable and happy. After everything Iâ€™ve done for you...
Person2: I know you've done a lot, Daniel, but love isn't about keeping score.
Person1: It's not about that. I just wish you'd acknowledge and appreciate it sometimes.
Person2: I do appreciate it, but a relationship is a two-way street. We both have our parts to play.

Person1: Outrageous.  I won't let you take control of my company.
Person2: Sit down.  You'll be a billionaire.  Better than being broke.  I've got terrorists and other pharmaceutical companies standing in line.  Ball's in your court, Mr. McCloy.

Person1: I just hate to see you pining away. It makes me want to vomit, frankly.  Broken hearts are for assholes.

Person1: There's someone out there, Mack, I know, some man killing for the fun of it, sniffing human glue, without regard to age or sex, without predicable M.O. Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.
Person2: I already have an employer.

Person2: It was the mall.

Person2: Those were just fantasies.

Person1: Will? Are you awake?

Person1: Come with me to California.
Person2: What?
Person1: I want you to come with me.
Person2: How do you know that?
Person1: I know. I just do.
Person2: Yeah, but how do you know?
Person1: I don't know. I just feel it.

Person1: Yeah, I'm sure.
Person2: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're sayin'. I mean, we might be in California next week and you could find out somethin' about me that you don't like. I'm the one you lived with for two years, I'm the one you made promises to, I'm the one who spent too many nights looking up at these rocks and wondering if you were ever going to make it down in once piece or ever at all.  Believe me, there's been times I didn't know what I wanted to do more, love you or hate you.  But the one thing in our relationship that I did know and still do know is that I understand you.

Person1: Buddy, it's not a question of enough. It's a zero sum game, sport. Somebody wins and somebody loses. Money itself isn't lost or made, it's simply transferred from one perception to another. Like magic. That painting cost $60,000 10 years ago. I could sell it today for $600,000. The illusion has become real. And the more real it becomes, the more desperately they want it. Capitalism at its finest.
Person2: How much is enough Gordon?
Person1: The richest one percent of this country owns half the country's wealth: 5 trillion dollars. One third of that comes from hard work, two thirds of it comes from inheritance, interest on interest accumulation to widows and idiot sons and what I do -- stock and real estate speculation. It's bullshit. Ninety percent of the American people have little or no net worth. I create nothing; I own. We make the rules, Buddy, the news, war, peace, famine, upheaval; the cost of a paper clip.  We pull the rabbit out of the hat while everybody else sits around their whole life wondering how we did it...  ...you're not naive enough to think we're living in a democracy are you, Buddy? It's the free market. You're one of us now...take advantage of it. You got the killer instinct, kid, stick with me. I got things to teach you...

Person1: It's all your fault! It was all arranged until he spoke to you! Why can't you leave us alone?

Person1: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute! I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now. If I have to, I'll go alone. It was I who bribed the porters. If it weren't for me, you'd never get out!
Person2: I thought the porters had instructions from the High Lama not to take anyone.
Person1: The High Lama? Who pays any attention to him? The porters laugh at the High Lama. All they want to know is how much gold he will give them. Well, I gave them more gold. I've been stealing it for a year. I'd do anything to get out of this place. To get away from that High Lama - the one who calls himself Father Perrault! Why, he's been insane for years!
Person2: Father Perrault is dead.
Person1: He's dead? That's fine. You won't see me shedding any tears over him!  Oh George, you must take me with you!
Person2: Aren't you afraid to leave? You don't want to look like an old woman, do you?

Person2: Yes.
Person1: I thought so!  He tells everyone I'm old. He wants them to stay away from me. He can't stand it when anyone comes near. He's punished me for every minute I've spent with George. If it weren't for him, I would have been out of here long ago, but he always stops me. Six months ago, I tried to escape and he locked me in a dark room. I nearly went crazy.  Look at me, Mr. Conway, do I look like an old woman? Is this the skin of an old woman? Look into my eyes and see if these are the eyes of an old woman?

Today, on the bus there was this adorable couple and I felt myself giving them a dirty look -- I had no idea everything was...

I was feeling like really bad that Dr. Bettes is married.  Which is probably why I make poor Spencer hug me more than he wants to... Like the poor kid doesn't have enough problems. He has to make up for his mom not getting any.  Oh, boy. Who needs these thoughts?
Person2: Spencer's doing fine. So what are you saying, that you're frustrated.
Person1: Leave me be! Why are you doing this? Why are you picking at my sores... What is it that you want?... You want what? What's with you? I hope getting me thinking of everything that's wrong when all I want is to not do this has some purpose.  What is it, Mom? No kidding.

Person1: I've got fifty thousand dollars to invest.
Person2: Oh.  Why is it that you want to get into film financing?
Person1: Well, Bill -- mind if I call you Bill?  Let me be frank. I've made a lot of money. I've got my own business in Detroit. Rivets. I make rivets and sell them to Fisher Body.  Well, rivets, you know, can get pretty boring after a while. When my business manager told me I should shelter some money, I thought I'd try this.
Person2: What exactly do you have in mind?
Person1: I thought I'd invest in a film. I want to sort of become involved in the process of making a film, meet the people who make films, learn how it's done...
Person2: In other words, you want to socialize and network?
Person1: Not exactly...
Person2: It's cool. Why do you think I got in the movies? How much networking do you think you get in the car wash business? Look, fifty thousand dollars can provide a lot of social opportunities. You can mingle with beautiful people every night for the rest of your life for fifty thousand dollars. So why bother with the movie business?
Person1: It's an investment.
Person2: If you want to watch when we shoot a film, for fifty bucks, I let guys stand around and watch. It's a lot cheaper.
Person1: I thought you were a businessman.
Person2: Don't get me wrong. A couple years ago, I woulda jumped at fifty thousand dollars possible financing. But the Lord's been good to me. I can now finance any films I choose. Big ones, small ones. Right now we're setting up a two hundred thousand dollar feature film. Live sound. I like to keep my own money in my films. That way you don't have to share the profits. There's plenty of guys in town that'll take it, though. But if I was you, Mr... what was your name again?
Person1: Jake.
Person2: ...I'd just start my own business. That's what I did. Get into a popular niche. That's big now. Why don't you come around the set? Meet some people. If you still want to invest, I'll ask around.
Person1: Sounds all right.
Person2: Okay. Keep in touch with my secretary.

Person1: Let me guess--breakfast is served?
Person2: No.
Person1: What then?
Person2: I do not wish to be scrogged--ever. I never heard that word, but when I heard it, I knew it was one thing I never wanted to have happen to me.
Person1: That's what you're supposed to say.
Person2: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.
Person1: You don't know you want.  That's the way God built you!
Person2: I will not be scrogged.  I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.
Person1: It couldn't!
Person2: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
Person1: Fish can't feel.
Person2: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more.  Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.
Person1: Such as?...
Person2: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.
Person1: Tell me about its sexual roots.
Person2: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.
Person1: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.
Person2: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.
Person1: Go on.
Person2: And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say--  for revenge.
Person1: You learned this in some college course?
Person2: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.
Person1: The doctor.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And what is his most cherished possession?
Person2: His most cherished possession?  His violin, I guess.
Person1: And he keeps it in his apartment?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And no one's there now?
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.
Person2: What are you going to do?
Person1: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.
Person2: No you're not!
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Because if you do--I'll leave you. HAROLD  Goodbye.

I was sorry for busting you on that... and I'm sorry for busting in on you that night... when I said I was never... I was sorry and I'm sorry every time your food was cold and that you had to wait two seconds for a coffee filler...

Person1: I can't believe you're making this up - it sounds like something out of an old Clyde Fitch play...
Person2: Clyde Fitch, thought you may not think so, was well before my time!
Person1: I've always denied the legend that you were in 'Our American Cousin' the night Lincoln was shot...
Person2: I don't think that's funny!
Person1: Of course it's funny - this is all too laughable to be anything else. You know what I think about this - this age obsession of yours - and now this ridiculous attempt to whip yourself up into a jealous froth because I spent ten minutes with a stage-struck kid-
Person2: Twenty minutes!
Person1: Thirty minutes, forty minutes! What of it?
Person2: Stage-struck kid... she's a young lady - of qualities. And I'll have you know I'm fed up with both the young lady and her qualities! Studying me as if - as if I were a play or a set of blueprints! How I walk, talk, think, eat, sleep!
Person1: Now how can you take offense at a kid trying in every way to be as much like her ideal as possible!
Person2: Stop calling her a kid! It so happens there are particular aspects of my life to which I would like to maintain sole and exclusive rights and privileges!
Person1: For instance what?
Person2: For instance - you!
Person1: This is my cue to take you in my arms and reassure you - but I'm not going to. I'm too mad-
Person2: - guilty.
Person1: Mad! Darling, there are certain characteristics for which you are famous - on stage and off. I love you for some of them - and in spite of others. I haven't let those become too important to me. They're part of your equipment for getting along in what is laughably called out environment - you've got to keep your teeth sharp. All right. But you will not sharpen them on me - or on Eve...
Person2: What about her teeth? What about her fangs?
Person1: She hasn't cut them yet, and you know it! So when you start judging an idealistic dreamy-eyed kid by the barroom, Benzedrine standards of this megalomaniac society - I won't have it! Eve Harrington has never by word, look, thought or suggestion indicated anything to me but her adoration for you and her happiness at our being in love! And to intimate anything else doesn't spell jealousy to me - it spells a paranoic insecurity that you should be ashamed of!
Person2: Cut! Print it! What happens in the next reel? Do I get dragged off screaming to the snake pit?
